description: Apple Certified Support Professional (ACSP) certification confirms the candidate's understanding of macOS's core functionality as well as having the ability to configure key services, perform basic troubleshooting, and support multiple users with essential macOS capabilities. Candidates for this course may be in a role of help desk professional, technical coordinator, or power user who supports macOS users, manages networks, or provides technical support for the Mac.

episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.915
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.915 --> 00:00:07.570
Hello, and thank you for
watching ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:07.570 --> 00:00:09.840
We're talking about the show

4
00:00:09.840 --> 00:00:12.660
Apple Certified Support Professional,
with Don Pezet.

5
00:00:12.660 --> 00:00:14.590
Don, can you tell us what
the course is all about?

6
00:00:14.590 --> 00:00:15.320
>> All right,

7
00:00:15.320 --> 00:00:18.220
well the Apple Certified Support
Professional is designed to

8
00:00:18.220 --> 00:00:21.410
basically introduce or not so
much introduce but to help people that

9
00:00:21.410 --> 00:00:24.650
are working in environments where
you support Apple computers, right.

10
00:00:24.650 --> 00:00:28.000
And we were specifically talking
about macOS systems, not so much iOS,

11
00:00:28.000 --> 00:00:33.761
like iPads and iPhones but people that are
supporting iMacs, Mac Minis, MacBook Pros,

12
00:00:33.761 --> 00:00:38.730
MacBook Airs, those type of devices they
all run the macOS operating systems.

13
00:00:38.730 --> 00:00:41.770
And if you're the one responsible for
helping those people, you need to

14
00:00:41.770 --> 00:00:45.380
know the ins and outs, different services
and software that are part of it and

15
00:00:45.380 --> 00:00:48.990
the ways to be able to maintain, manage,
and troubleshoot those systems and that's

16
00:00:48.990 --> 00:00:51.880
what this series is really all about.
>> Now you already mentioned a few people,

17
00:00:51.880 --> 00:00:55.210
but who else is the show targeted towards?
>> Well, so

18
00:00:55.210 --> 00:00:58.490
the main target audience are for
people that are already working in IT,

19
00:00:58.490 --> 00:01:00.730
that are supporting
networks in that have Macs,

20
00:01:00.730 --> 00:01:03.960
but I find that it actually works out
well for a lot of other people as well.

21
00:01:03.960 --> 00:01:08.040
It's great for people that are just
getting started with macOS.

22
00:01:08.040 --> 00:01:10.380
I know it's targeted to people
that are already in IT but

23
00:01:10.380 --> 00:01:14.320
honestly, our first episodes are going
to be how to get macOS installed and

24
00:01:14.320 --> 00:01:15.618
we're gonna walk through that process.

25
00:01:15.618 --> 00:01:19.830
And we will do simple things like how
to change the wallpaper background or

26
00:01:19.830 --> 00:01:23.100
whatever, but that's the most people
are able to figure out on their own.

27
00:01:23.100 --> 00:01:25.910
So, if you're an IT enthusiast and
you wanna

28
00:01:25.910 --> 00:01:29.840
get into professionally supporting Mac
networks this is a great place to do it.

29
00:01:29.840 --> 00:01:33.850
It's also good for
Windows system administrators, maybe

30
00:01:33.850 --> 00:01:38.480
you work in a Microsoft environment and a
couple of your employees now have Macs or

31
00:01:38.480 --> 00:01:40.030
a lot of your employees now have Macs,
right.

32
00:01:40.030 --> 00:01:42.790
That how it works, they kinda get
a foothold and start to grow and

33
00:01:42.790 --> 00:01:46.650
now you find yourself in a situation where
you are very use to Windows administration

34
00:01:46.650 --> 00:01:49.130
but you've got Macs you
need to support as well.

35
00:01:49.130 --> 00:01:52.020
We tackle that here and
in fact we have another course is called,

36
00:01:52.020 --> 00:01:54.610
Mac Integration Basics,
that really helps with getting Macs to

37
00:01:54.610 --> 00:01:59.040
play nice with Windows but in this show
we're focused entirely on macOS and so

38
00:01:59.040 --> 00:02:03.040
it can help really a large audience.
>> Is there a certification available for

39
00:02:03.040 --> 00:02:04.730
the course?
>> Absolutely, right, so

40
00:02:04.730 --> 00:02:07.780
the title of the course is
the Apple Certified Support Professional,

41
00:02:07.780 --> 00:02:12.630
which is ACSP and that directly aligns
with Apple's ACSP certification.

42
00:02:12.630 --> 00:02:17.280
Now there used to be two different
ACSPs that you could get,

43
00:02:17.280 --> 00:02:20.200
there was one for the,
back then it was called OS 10,

44
00:02:20.200 --> 00:02:24.119
so there's the OS 10 support
essentials and OS 10 server essentials.

45
00:02:24.119 --> 00:02:27.950
Well Apple did away with server
essentials, now there's just one and

46
00:02:27.950 --> 00:02:32.690
OS 10 got renamed macOS and now we
just have macOS Support Essentials and

47
00:02:32.690 --> 00:02:35.020
you'll hear some people
still refer to it that way.

48
00:02:35.020 --> 00:02:39.390
If you take the official course at
an Apple training center they call

49
00:02:39.390 --> 00:02:41.670
it macOS Support Essentials, but

50
00:02:41.670 --> 00:02:45.326
we're tailored towards that certification,
the Apple Certified Support Professional.

51
00:02:45.326 --> 00:02:47.290
You take this course you
learn all the material,

52
00:02:47.290 --> 00:02:49.490
you can go to an Apple training center,
and

53
00:02:49.490 --> 00:02:52.450
from there you can get the certification.
>> So, in depth

54
00:02:52.450 --> 00:02:56.440
now what topics are covered in the course?
>> The course covers a lot of stuff I

55
00:02:56.440 --> 00:03:00.320
mentioned that we install macOS, right,
so we would kind of start off there.

56
00:03:00.320 --> 00:03:02.590
And I know some of you
are probably thinking, boy,

57
00:03:02.590 --> 00:03:04.120
that's really easy just installing it but

58
00:03:04.120 --> 00:03:07.190
there's actually a number of different
ways that macOS can be installed and a lot

59
00:03:07.190 --> 00:03:10.350
of different things that we need to think
about as we're doing that installation.

60
00:03:10.350 --> 00:03:13.740
So we get a chance to see that, we'll
also see how to support user accounts and

61
00:03:13.740 --> 00:03:15.280
multiple user accounts.

62
00:03:15.280 --> 00:03:18.350
How to configure networking,
how to configure network sharing and

63
00:03:18.350 --> 00:03:20.600
exchanging information between our Macs.

64
00:03:20.600 --> 00:03:22.840
We'll see system troubleshooting,

65
00:03:22.840 --> 00:03:25.770
we'll talk about some of the other
services that are kinda hidden away in

66
00:03:25.770 --> 00:03:28.180
the background that we might use
as part of the administration.

67
00:03:28.180 --> 00:03:31.430
We'll take a good look at iCloud,
because that's become so important.

68
00:03:31.430 --> 00:03:34.730
We'll take a good look at Time Machine,
the ways that we can back up our Macs and

69
00:03:34.730 --> 00:03:39.610
restore them very easily and ways that we
can even centrally manage that beyond what

70
00:03:39.610 --> 00:03:42.930
a normal consumer would have we can
actually set up a Time Machine server.

71
00:03:42.930 --> 00:03:46.680
So, we get a chance to see a lot of
the different tools that are available for

72
00:03:46.680 --> 00:03:50.860
our Macs and keeping it up and
operational and running nice and smoothly.

73
00:03:50.860 --> 00:03:54.090
And then we kind of end the series talking
a little bit more about troubleshooting,

74
00:03:54.090 --> 00:03:58.050
troubleshooting hardware that we've
added and other resources on the system.

75
00:03:58.050 --> 00:04:01.100
Lastly, I just wanna mention
that we do highlight security

76
00:04:01.100 --> 00:04:04.635
really all throughout the series there's
all sorts of security features built into

77
00:04:04.635 --> 00:04:07.970
macOS that we need to be aware of and
we'll learn about them right here.

78
00:04:07.970 --> 00:04:12.882
And I keep saying macOS, we're
actually focused on macOS High Sierra,

79
00:04:12.882 --> 00:04:16.839
this is the version that's
focused on macOS 10.13.

80
00:04:16.839 --> 00:04:19.106
If you've watched a previous
version of this show,

81
00:04:19.106 --> 00:04:21.165
we've done it for
each of the versions before,

82
00:04:21.165 --> 00:04:24.768
there's always new features that get snuck
in and so while we don't call out the new

83
00:04:24.768 --> 00:04:27.963
features specifically, they're kinda
sprinkle throughout the series

84
00:04:27.963 --> 00:04:30.531
things that are unique to High Sierra.
>> Thanks Don, now if

85
00:04:30.531 --> 00:04:34.119
Apple Certified Support Professional
sounds like a show you'd be interested in

86
00:04:34.119 --> 00:04:37.775
and you should be, make sure you check out
all the episodes in the course library.

87
00:04:37.775 --> 00:04:41.075
And thank you for watching ITPRO.TV,
it is binge worthy.

88
00:04:41.075 --> 00:04:47.802
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don takes a look at prerequisites for getting macOS High Sierra installed. He also discusses the hardware requirements as well as the platforms that are supported by macOS High Sierra.
episodes.title: Getting Prepared
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:02.055
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.055 --> 00:00:06.604
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.604 --> 00:00:08.233
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.233 --> 00:00:12.386
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> All right,

5
00:00:12.386 --> 00:00:16.100
greetings everyone, and welcome to
another exciting episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.100 --> 00:00:20.244
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode, well,

7
00:00:20.244 --> 00:00:23.432
we are starting our ASCP,
I think I got that right.

8
00:00:23.432 --> 00:00:26.513
The Apple, it's ACSP,
always get those backwards,

9
00:00:26.513 --> 00:00:30.769
the Apple Certified Support Professional
Series, for version 10.13, for

10
00:00:30.769 --> 00:00:32.635
those of you keeping score at home.

11
00:00:32.635 --> 00:00:36.215
Joining me in the studio, our good
friend and mentor in this endeavor,

12
00:00:36.215 --> 00:00:37.840
our good friend Mr. Don Pezet.

13
00:00:37.840 --> 00:00:40.741
Don, welcome back, how's it going today?
>> It is going great,

14
00:00:40.741 --> 00:00:44.640
ready to kick off our
Mac OS High Sierra adventure.

15
00:00:44.640 --> 00:00:47.080
This is the very beginning of our series,
and so

16
00:00:47.080 --> 00:00:50.310
we're gonna start off with the beginning
things that we need to know about.

17
00:00:50.310 --> 00:00:54.030
So what is the knowledge that we need
to have in our minds before we go and

18
00:00:54.030 --> 00:00:56.070
take that dive into High Sierra?

19
00:00:56.070 --> 00:00:59.030
You'd be surprised as to all the little
oddities that creep up as you

20
00:00:59.030 --> 00:01:00.750
work with the new release from Apple.

21
00:01:00.750 --> 00:01:03.660
For the most part,
it's actually really enjoyable,

22
00:01:03.660 --> 00:01:06.190
there's a lot of great new features,
a lot of great power there.

23
00:01:06.190 --> 00:01:09.320
But there are things that are different,
things that have changed,

24
00:01:09.320 --> 00:01:11.770
things that behave differently
than in previous versions of Mac.

25
00:01:11.770 --> 00:01:15.939
So we need to be familiar with those and
understand that before we take the dive.

26
00:01:15.939 --> 00:01:17.839
That way,
we don't impact the end users, and

27
00:01:17.839 --> 00:01:19.610
everybody gets a nice smooth experience.

28
00:01:19.610 --> 00:01:22.059
So that's what we're gonna be
doing right here in this episode.

29
00:01:22.059 --> 00:01:23.266
>> You make a great point, Don,

30
00:01:23.266 --> 00:01:26.357
when you talk about things, typically,
while you have some familiarity,

31
00:01:26.357 --> 00:01:27.580
there's also some changes.

32
00:01:27.580 --> 00:01:30.583
So a good place to start is,
what should we know?

33
00:01:30.583 --> 00:01:34.071
What should we need to know to
be prepared to jump into those

34
00:01:34.071 --> 00:01:35.143
waters?
>> All right, well,

35
00:01:35.143 --> 00:01:36.519
there's a couple things that
we need to be aware of.

36
00:01:36.519 --> 00:01:42.661
Some that are cutting edge new, some that
are just, I'll call them recently new,

37
00:01:42.661 --> 00:01:47.682
that's probably not a good term,
but things as simple as the name.

38
00:01:47.682 --> 00:01:50.725
This one is Mac OS 10.13 High Sierra, and

39
00:01:50.725 --> 00:01:55.963
that terminology's a little different
than what we had in previous versions.

40
00:01:55.963 --> 00:02:01.720
Because it was was OS 10, or
Mac OS X, X the Roman numeral, OS 10.

41
00:02:01.720 --> 00:02:08.603
It was OS 10 all the way up through
El Capitan, which was 10.11.

42
00:02:08.603 --> 00:02:12.338
And then starting with 10.12 Sierra,
it became Mac OS, so

43
00:02:12.338 --> 00:02:15.280
this is High Sierra, we're still Mac OS.

44
00:02:15.280 --> 00:02:19.860
It's still OS 10 technically under the
hood, but they just kind of dropped that

45
00:02:19.860 --> 00:02:23.510
nomenclature, so
now it's Mac iOS 10.13 High Sierra.

46
00:02:23.510 --> 00:02:26.084
So terminology is a little bit different,
that's one thing.

47
00:02:26.084 --> 00:02:29.272
There's also some new features, some
things that are baked in that are a little

48
00:02:29.272 --> 00:02:31.020
bit different than in previous versions.

49
00:02:31.020 --> 00:02:36.880
So for example, for the longest time,
we would always format our disks as Mac OS

50
00:02:36.880 --> 00:02:41.900
extended, or Mac OS extended journaled,
that's the Apple HFS plus file system.

51
00:02:41.900 --> 00:02:45.826
In High Sierra, we have a new file system
called APFS, the Apple File System,

52
00:02:45.826 --> 00:02:48.042
and we'll talk about
it in a later episode.

53
00:02:48.042 --> 00:02:51.662
But that means we might be seeing
a different file system than we're used to

54
00:02:51.662 --> 00:02:53.163
when we jump into High Sierra.

55
00:02:53.163 --> 00:02:57.240
And that's even different from regular
old Sierra, so a big change there.

56
00:02:57.240 --> 00:03:02.765
We have a new version of Safari,
that impacts some people who use Safari.

57
00:03:02.765 --> 00:03:05.870
[LAUGH] I'm not really one of those,
but a lot of people do.

58
00:03:05.870 --> 00:03:09.520
So any time a web browser changes,
that changes the end-user's experience.

59
00:03:09.520 --> 00:03:14.100
There's some video codec support,
Apple has gone all in with 4K support.

60
00:03:14.100 --> 00:03:18.520
So 4K video renders better under
High Sierra than under previous versions.

61
00:03:18.520 --> 00:03:22.070
So if you're looking at it and saying,
I don't really need High Sierra, but

62
00:03:22.070 --> 00:03:25.060
you do video work,
especially with 4K video, you'll want it,

63
00:03:25.060 --> 00:03:27.890
that codec improvement is a big deal.

64
00:03:27.890 --> 00:03:31.310
There's Metal 2, the graphic
subsystem that was introduced in,

65
00:03:31.310 --> 00:03:33.838
I think it was actually
introduced in El Capitan.

66
00:03:33.838 --> 00:03:36.723
That helps with games and
3D rendering that was called Metal,

67
00:03:36.723 --> 00:03:38.200
it's the second version of it.

68
00:03:38.200 --> 00:03:39.100
It's more optimized for

69
00:03:39.100 --> 00:03:42.570
some of the graphics cards that
are available on a Mac Pro.

70
00:03:42.570 --> 00:03:44.136
So if you've got a Mac Pro,

71
00:03:44.136 --> 00:03:46.299
also known as you being rich.
>> [LAUGH]

72
00:03:46.299 --> 00:03:47.012
>> Then that's

73
00:03:47.012 --> 00:03:51.050
another thing you'll be able to take
advantage of inside of High Sierra.

74
00:03:51.050 --> 00:03:55.140
And be able to really, really see
the graphics performance of your system.

75
00:03:56.230 --> 00:03:59.310
Another thing to be aware of is not so
much a change, but

76
00:03:59.310 --> 00:04:02.975
a notice of impending change,
notice of impending doom.

77
00:04:02.975 --> 00:04:07.470
32-bit applications, Apple announced
awhile ago that they were gonna

78
00:04:07.470 --> 00:04:11.670
end support for 32-bit applications
in the Apple App Store.

79
00:04:11.670 --> 00:04:15.213
Well, they've been warning that it's
coming, this is the final warning.

80
00:04:15.213 --> 00:04:18.836
In High Sierra,
whenever you launch a 32-bit version,

81
00:04:18.836 --> 00:04:22.386
you're gonna get a warning
window that pops up that says,

82
00:04:22.386 --> 00:04:26.090
this is the last version of
Mac OS to support 32-bit apps.

83
00:04:26.090 --> 00:04:33.020
When the next version comes out, so
we had 10.12 Sierra, 10.13 High Sierra.

84
00:04:33.020 --> 00:04:37.037
When 10.14 Even Higher Sierra comes out-
>> [LAUGH]

85
00:04:37.037 --> 00:04:38.003
>> Or Peak Sierra,

86
00:04:38.003 --> 00:04:41.384
whatever they'll call it,
whatever the next the one is,

87
00:04:41.384 --> 00:04:44.385
it's not gonna have 32-bit app support.

88
00:04:44.385 --> 00:04:46.245
So you're gonna start
getting warnings here.

89
00:04:46.245 --> 00:04:48.695
And the reason I bring
that up is your end users,

90
00:04:48.695 --> 00:04:50.325
when they see a warning,
what do they think?

91
00:04:50.325 --> 00:04:52.205
Something didn't work,
something went wrong.

92
00:04:52.205 --> 00:04:54.979
So we need to make sure that we
educate people to know, hey,

93
00:04:54.979 --> 00:04:57.038
we have plans to replace that application.

94
00:04:57.038 --> 00:04:59.789
Or, hey, if you don't have plans
to replace that application,

95
00:04:59.789 --> 00:05:02.260
then you're going to have
problems in the next version.

96
00:05:02.260 --> 00:05:04.924
So another thing we need to be
aware of getting ready for Sierra.

97
00:05:04.924 --> 00:05:07.884
>> Well, Don, continuing along the vein of

98
00:05:07.884 --> 00:05:12.537
support, right, what are the minimum
requirements that are for

99
00:05:12.537 --> 00:05:15.119
High Sierra?
>> Well, I guess that's a good point,

100
00:05:15.119 --> 00:05:17.489
because maybe you can't even
run High Sierra, right?

101
00:05:17.489 --> 00:05:21.530
Well, Apple happens to be one of the best
companies at supporting hardware.

102
00:05:21.530 --> 00:05:25.010
They support hardware for way longer
than any other vendor that's out there.

103
00:05:25.010 --> 00:05:29.760
So we know that if you get a laptop or
a desktop or whatever that's two,

104
00:05:29.760 --> 00:05:32.520
three years old,
it's gonna support the latest OS.

105
00:05:32.520 --> 00:05:35.820
But what if it's five years old,
what if it's seven years old?

106
00:05:35.820 --> 00:05:36.832
Well, with other vendors,

107
00:05:36.832 --> 00:05:39.496
they don't have to worry about that
because their hardware fails by then.

108
00:05:39.496 --> 00:05:42.820
So you buy a new one and
now you can support the new OS.

109
00:05:42.820 --> 00:05:45.950
But Apple hardware,
it runs darn near forever, right?

110
00:05:45.950 --> 00:05:49.967
So if you have an older MacBook,
if you have an older Mac Mini,

111
00:05:49.967 --> 00:05:54.397
or Mac Pro, or something like that,
is it going to run High Sierra?

112
00:05:54.397 --> 00:05:56.585
Well, Apple publishes
another website here,

113
00:05:56.585 --> 00:05:59.160
I'm gonna pull up their
website right here.

114
00:05:59.160 --> 00:06:02.060
They publish the Mac OS High Sierra
technical specifications,

115
00:06:02.060 --> 00:06:04.230
and I'll put the link to
this in the show notes.

116
00:06:04.230 --> 00:06:07.740
But basically, they break it down
into general requirements and

117
00:06:07.740 --> 00:06:09.080
hardware requirements.

118
00:06:09.080 --> 00:06:13.880
On the general side, if your current
Mac is running OS 10, 10.8, or later,

119
00:06:13.880 --> 00:06:18.710
then the odds are, you're going
to be able to run High Sierra.

120
00:06:18.710 --> 00:06:22.530
Right, cuz on the hardware side, it just
needs 2 gigs of RAM it needs about 14 and

121
00:06:22.530 --> 00:06:24.970
a half gigs of space if

So if I just type A-P-P-L-I-C and

00:31:42.530 --> 00:31:48.340
But let's do A-P-P-L-I-C, and

00:31:48.340 --> 00:31:51.390

00:31:51.390 --> 00:31:54.912

00:31:54.912 --> 00:32:00.265
So that tab autocomplete is really handy,

00:32:00.265 --> 00:32:04.274

00:32:04.274 --> 00:32:05.740

00:32:13.030 --> 00:32:18.320

00:32:18.320 --> 00:32:21.886

00:32:21.886 --> 00:32:23.240

00:32:38.305 --> 00:32:41.195

00:32:45.435 --> 00:32:48.688

00:33:16.940 --> 00:33:20.180
it doesn't need that, I'm sorry

But the name of the disk is what's really

Then we need to tell it, where the

But basically, when I come in here

00:24:23.630 --> 00:24:25.599

00:24:30.547 --> 00:24:31.263

00:24:33.631 --> 00:24:37.271
So anyhow, it's kind like that,

>> [LAUGH]

00:24:58.420 --> 00:25:00.892
And I'll tell you,

526

It's copying some files,
It's gonna reboot,

528
00:25:04.860 --> 00:25:08.080

529
00:25:08.080 --> 00:25:08.950
>> Although in a perfect world,

531
00:25:11.210 --> 00:25:15.040
But as always, there's these little

What happens if this
doesn't get to completion,

533
00:25:17.202 --> 00:25:18.620
what if it fails out?
>> All right,

534
00:25:18.620 --> 00:25:20.130
failure does happen sometimes, and

535
00:25:20.130 --> 00:25:22.780
let see if I can catch this
fast enough before it reboot.

536
00:25:22.780 --> 00:25:25.487

00:25:25.487 --> 00:25:31.770

an option to view the installation logs.

00:25:31.770 --> 00:25:33.760

00:25:36.784 --> 00:25:39.154

And if the installer fails,
just to give you a chance to read it and

545
00:25:47.845 --> 00:25:49.170

00:25:49.170 --> 00:25:51.745

00:25:51.745 --> 00:25:53.475
and there goes the reboot.
>> There,

548
00:25:53.475 --> 00:25:56.039

>> All right, so my install is working

00:25:56.039 --> 00:26:00.740

550
00:26:00.740 --> 00:26:02.536
But what's gonna happen is,

00:26:04.769 --> 00:26:07.670

Now it's gonna reboot and, or

557

a 15-minute install window,

559
00:26:21.645 --> 00:26:23.680

560
00:26:24.710 --> 00:26:27.953
And once it's installed, then it'll

00:26:27.953 --> 00:26:30.736

562
00:26:30.736 --> 00:26:31.863
>> All right, well, Don,

00:26:31.863 --> 00:26:35.573

564
00:26:35.573 --> 00:26:36.780
for 12 to 15 minutes.

565
00:26:36.780 --> 00:26:38.560
And we'll go ahead and
call this an episode.

566
00:26:38.560 --> 00:26:41.311
Anything else you wanna add to
the show before we call it a day?

567
00:26:41.311 --> 00:26:42.076
>> Main thing here is,

568
00:26:42.076 --> 00:26:43.698
you got a lot of choices for installation.

569
00:26:43.698 --> 00:26:45.959
There's even some more
advanced options for

570
00:26:45.959 --> 00:26:49.460
doing installs that aren't part
of the ACSP certification.

571
00:26:49.460 --> 00:26:52.485
If you ever get bored,
got to Apple's website and look for

572
00:26:52.485 --> 00:26:56.278
information on NetInstall, or
building custom installation images.

573
00:26:56.278 --> 00:26:58.879
You can do installs off of

574
00:26:58.879 --> 00:27:02.044
And you can build custom install images

00:27:02.044 --> 00:27:03.250
installed on there.

00:27:03.250 --> 00:27:05.320
So you can quickly deploy
machines that are ready for

00:27:05.320 --> 00:27:07.650

Definitely something you want to learn

00:27:10.530 --> 00:27:13.463

581

For ITProTV,

episodes.description: In this episode, Don dives into the world of recovering the macOS High Sierra operating system when failures arise. He discusses some of the common symptoms that might manifest themselves, the options available during the recovery process as well as demonstrating that process.
episodes.title: OS Recovery
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.363
Welcome to ITPro TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:04.363 --> 00:00:07.908
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:07.908 --> 00:00:12.505
You're watching ITProTV.
>> All right,

4
00:00:12.505 --> 00:00:16.412
greetings everyone, and welcome back
to another great episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:16.412 --> 00:00:20.225
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and in
today's episode we've got a real treat for

6
00:00:20.225 --> 00:00:23.080
you, because we're back with
more in our ACSP series.

7
00:00:23.080 --> 00:00:25.994
Joining us the studio yet again,
lending his expertise on that subject,

8
00:00:25.994 --> 00:00:27.360
our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

9
00:00:27.360 --> 00:00:28.580
Don, we're so glad to have you back.

10
00:00:28.580 --> 00:00:30.751
How is it going today?
>> It is going great, Daniel, and

11
00:00:30.751 --> 00:00:34.151
in this episode we're gonna be kind of
building on to what we talked about in our

12
00:00:34.151 --> 00:00:35.037
previous episode.

13
00:00:35.037 --> 00:00:38.667
You've been watching them all, and our
last episode we had a chance to see what

14
00:00:38.667 --> 00:00:40.608
was it like to install MAC OS high series.

15
00:00:40.608 --> 00:00:43.423
We went through that installation process
and saw everything we needed to do.

16
00:00:43.423 --> 00:00:46.426
Got to the really exciting
12 minutes remaining screen,

17
00:00:46.426 --> 00:00:49.800
kinda let that one run out, but
basically that was the installer.

18
00:00:49.800 --> 00:00:52.280
It wasn't anything too
terribly crazy there.

19
00:00:52.280 --> 00:00:56.850
But it was all done assuming that
things worked the right way.

20
00:00:56.850 --> 00:00:59.450
That our system was able to
build the install media or

21
00:00:59.450 --> 00:01:01.690
do the upgrade through the App Store or
whatever.

22
00:01:01.690 --> 00:01:03.720
And that's not always the case.

23
00:01:03.720 --> 00:01:06.770
Sometimes your computer
gets totally horsed and

24
00:01:06.770 --> 00:01:10.120
you can't get in there to do things and
you need to be able to recover.

25
00:01:10.120 --> 00:01:12.885
And so what we're gonna take a look
at in this episode are some of

26
00:01:12.885 --> 00:01:15.546
the tools that are available to
help us recover our operating

27
00:01:15.546 --> 00:01:18.153
system, get our system back
online in the event that we have

28
00:01:18.153 --> 00:01:19.400
a failure.
>> Well, Don,

29
00:01:19.400 --> 00:01:22.410
I guess the first place to start
in this episode would be then,

30
00:01:22.410 --> 00:01:26.595
what can cause our system to become
damaged, and why does Apple ignore this?

31
00:01:26.595 --> 00:01:28.260
[LAUGH]
>> All right, [LAUGH] so

32
00:01:28.260 --> 00:01:32.762
fortunately Apple doesn't ignore it.
>> They say it just works though [LAUGH]

33
00:01:32.762 --> 00:01:35.024
>> [LAUGH] It is supposed to just work,

34
00:01:35.024 --> 00:01:39.406
but if it just worked perfectly,
they wouldn't have Apple Care.

35
00:01:39.406 --> 00:01:40.344
[LAUGH]
>> That's right.

36
00:01:40.344 --> 00:01:43.565
[LAUGH]
>> So any hardware device can fail, right?

37
00:01:43.565 --> 00:01:46.230
Things can go wrong, and
then software can fail.

38
00:01:46.230 --> 00:01:49.690
Especially third party software that
hasn't had a lot of scrutiny to it.

39
00:01:49.690 --> 00:01:53.670
These are all areas where we can
introduce failure into our systems.

40
00:01:53.670 --> 00:01:57.270
So hardware though is typically
one of the big causes of this.

41
00:01:57.270 --> 00:02:01.720
If you have RAM that's going bad in
your system, that's a really tricky one,

42
00:02:01.720 --> 00:02:03.650
because RAM does go bad and

43
00:02:03.650 --> 00:02:07.670
when it happens it usually manifests
itself as a problem with something else.

44
00:02:07.670 --> 00:02:10.650
Like you're trying to open a file on
the hard drive and the file is corrupt.

45
00:02:10.650 --> 00:02:13.900
Well, my first thought is
the hard drive's failing, great.

46
00:02:13.900 --> 00:02:17.940
But when you open a file from the hard
drive, it copies the file onto RAM and

47
00:02:17.940 --> 00:02:19.530
then actually opens it from RAM.

48
00:02:19.530 --> 00:02:22.950
So if your RAM is bad,
the file is going to be corrupt.

49
00:02:22.950 --> 00:02:24.810
And so it can misrepresent itself.

50
00:02:24.810 --> 00:02:27.550
You can identify things
coming from the wrong source.

51
00:02:27.550 --> 00:02:32.130
You see the symptom, not necessarily the
cause, and so that makes it really tricky.

52
00:02:32.130 --> 00:02:35.310
But failing hardware is probably
the number one reason why you

53
00:02:35.310 --> 00:02:37.860
might not be able to boot
into your operating system.

54
00:02:37.860 --> 00:02:41.430
If you have a spinning hard drive in
your system, a traditional hard drive,

55
00:02:41.430 --> 00:02:45.260
then those things,
they rarely last more than three years and

56
00:02:45.260 --> 00:02:48.860
beyond that it's just a crap shoot how
long it's gonna take before it fails.

57
00:02:48.860 --> 00:02:51.020
The more you power off and
power on your computer,

58
00:02:51.020 --> 00:02:54.480
the sooner those discs are gonna fail,
they don't last forever.

59
00:02:54.480 --> 00:02:57.880
SSDs last a lot longer,
I mean you might go seven years and

60
00:02:57.880 --> 00:03:00.020
not have a single failure
on one of those things.

61
00:03:00.020 --> 00:03:03.740
They really last a long time,
but not everybody has SSD yet.

62
00:03:03.740 --> 00:03:05.070
So those are some examples.

63
00:03:05.070 --> 00:03:10.170
It could be something a little more crazy,
maybe

64
00:03:10.170 --> 00:03:14.280
you accidentally delete some operating
system files and now you can't boot.

65
00:03:14.280 --> 00:03:17.540
Maybe you get a virus or malware and your
system's infected and now you can't boot.

66
00:03:17.540 --> 00:03:21.810
These are things that might stop you
from being able to use your system, or

67
00:03:21.810 --> 00:03:26.030
even something as innocent as you've
forgotten your password, right?

68
00:03:26.030 --> 00:03:28.070
We'll talk a little bit more
about password recovery later on,

69
00:03:28.070 --> 00:03:31.260
but if you have file vault
encryption turned on.

70
00:03:31.260 --> 00:03:35.200
And you've got a password,
and you forget it,

71
00:03:35.200 --> 00:03:38.820
you can get completely locked out of your
system and you're unable to get in there.

72
00:03:38.820 --> 00:03:40.540
What do you do in those scenarios?

73
00:03:40.540 --> 00:03:42.510
And that's where OS recovery comes in.
>> Well, Don,

74
00:03:42.510 --> 00:03:44.880
let's continue on this line of
thought just really quickly and

75
00:03:44.880 --> 00:03:48.400
can you give us some kind of idea of some
of the symptoms we might encounter so

76
00:03:48.400 --> 00:03:52.150
that we know something is going wrong?
>> Sure, so for your average end user,

77
00:03:52.150 --> 00:03:56.750
they might not even know the difference
between an SSD and HDD, or whatever,

78
00:03:56.750 --> 00:04:00.580
and we don't want them to have to know
that, this is supposed to just work.

79
00:04:00.580 --> 00:04:04.604
So, they're gonna identify symptoms,
symptoms like the computer freezes,

80
00:04:04.604 --> 00:04:08.880
it just gets stuck and
you have to power off, power back on, or

81
00:04:08.880 --> 00:04:11.350
maybe a reboots on its own randomly.

82
00:04:11.350 --> 00:04:15.360
More commonly though, you start seeing
that little spinning pin wheel,

83
00:04:15.360 --> 00:04:16.940
the spinning color wheel, right?

84
00:04:16.940 --> 00:04:20.550
When the system is thinking, when it's
working hard on something your cursor will

85
00:04:20.550 --> 00:04:23.641
turn into this little beach ball type.
>> I call it the rainbow

86
00:04:23.641 --> 00:04:26.013
pin wheel of doom [LAUGH]
>> That is a very creative

87
00:04:26.013 --> 00:04:26.577
name.
>> Well,

88
00:04:26.577 --> 00:04:27.297
I have moments [LAUGH]
>> We're

89
00:04:27.297 --> 00:04:27.797
gonna trademark that one.
>> [LAUGH].

90
00:04:27.797 --> 00:04:30.796
>> But that usually just means the system

91
00:04:30.796 --> 00:04:31.760
is busy.

92
00:04:31.760 --> 00:04:34.910
But it could also mean that
something is not working right and

93
00:04:34.910 --> 00:04:37.520
the system is trying to access that
thing that's not working right.

94
00:04:37.520 --> 00:04:40.920
And it's having to wait, and
if you are seeing that a lot, more and

95
00:04:40.920 --> 00:04:43.890
more frequently, that would be a symptom
your end-users would recognize.

96
00:04:43.890 --> 00:04:46.790
And it could indicate
an issue with your system.

97
00:04:46.790 --> 00:04:49.570
There's other things like
you power on the system and

98
00:04:49.570 --> 00:04:52.650
it tells you it can't find
the operating system, right?

99
00:04:52.650 --> 00:04:56.070
You'll normally see a little globe with a
network picture because it's going to try

100
00:04:56.070 --> 00:04:58.300
and boot recovery off of
the Internet at that point.

101
00:04:58.300 --> 00:05:01.720
You might see a folder with a question
mark on it telling you that

102
00:05:01.720 --> 00:05:03.510
it can't find the operating system.

103
00:05:03.510 --> 00:05:07.680
Those are all symptoms that occur and
let you know that, one way or

104
00:05:07.680 --> 00:05:10.835
another, your system is damaged and
it might be hardware.

105
00:05:10.835 --> 00:05:15.105
But if it's software, there's a couple of
easy ways that we can fix that that go

106
00:05:15.105 --> 00:05:17.575
right along with the Mac OS installer.
>> All right, well, Don,

107
00:05:17.575 --> 00:05:19.395
we've determined that yes,

108
00:05:19.395 --> 00:05:23.315
while most of the time your Apple system
will just work sometimes it doesn't.

109
00:05:23.315 --> 00:05:27.385
We've seen some of the symptoms that
might indicate that there is a problem.

110
00:05:27.385 --> 00:05:29.895
Now let's jump on
the train of how can we fix

111
00:05:29.895 --> 00:05:32.725
it?
>> All right, well there's several tools

112
00:05:32.725 --> 00:05:35.530
available to us, and throughout this
series we're gonna see all of them.

113
00:05:35.530 --> 00:05:37.938
But this is a quick kind of overview.

114
00:05:37.938 --> 00:05:41.556
My first go-to tool,
if I've got a system that's acting weird,

115
00:05:41.556 --> 00:05:45.535
if I have a Time Machine back up,
I will restore the Time Machine back up.

116
00:05:45.535 --> 00:05:46.505
That's the thing to do, right?

117
00:05:46.505 --> 00:05:49.970
Cuz you can replace every file
with copies that are known good.

118
00:05:49.970 --> 00:05:54.490
If I know that my system was working fine
on Monday and here I am, on Thursday, and

119
00:05:54.490 --> 00:05:55.510
it's not working.

120
00:05:55.510 --> 00:05:59.030
I could restore Monday's backup and
I should be back up and going.

121
00:05:59.030 --> 00:06:01.240
If I'm not,
I likely do have a hardware issue and

122
00:06:01.240 --> 00:06:03.480
I've got a trip to the Apple
store ahead of me, right?

123
00:06:03.480 --> 00:06:06.800
But if I can restore that Time Machine
backup, I'll be back in business,

124
00:06:06.800 --> 00:06:09.910
that's one of the great
tools that we've got.

125
00:06:09.910 --> 00:06:13.090
If I think it's a disk failure
I can use the Disk Utility.

126
00:06:13.090 --> 00:06:16.350
Disk Utility has first aid that you
can run, that scan across the disk and

127

00:24:39.520 --> 00:24:43.180
And it's tied to your Apple ID, so
once you buy it, you can install it on

474
00:24:44.740 --> 00:24:48.930
they say up to five or six Mac's, whatever
it is, it's part of the family sharing.

475
00:24:48.930 --> 00:24:50.750
So you can cover many machines with it.

476
00:24:50.750 --> 00:24:53.402
And once you install that app,

477
00:24:53.402 --> 00:24:58.094
it gives you the ability to
set up the Profile Manager,

478
00:24:58.094 --> 00:25:02.830
which here,
that little screenshot is kinda blurry.

479
00:25:02.830 --> 00:25:06.110
I've got it installed it
here on my actual laptop.

480
00:25:07.140 --> 00:25:10.970
And one of the things that you can do
with the Profile Manager is you can

481
00:25:10.970 --> 00:25:14.790
create a profile which is a list
of settings or preferences.

482
00:25:14.790 --> 00:25:17.365
So I can figure out what
are all the settings and

483
00:25:17.365 --> 00:25:19.752
preferences that I want on these new Macs.

484
00:25:19.752 --> 00:25:23.480
And I can come to and define each and
everyone of them, and

485
00:25:23.480 --> 00:25:28.543
once their defined, this can generate
what's called a mobile config file.

486
00:25:28.543 --> 00:25:32.645
Now mobile config file is just a simple
little file, you can put it on a USB key.

487
00:25:32.645 --> 00:25:37.380
You can take that USB key to each machine,
and you just double-click on that file.

488
00:25:37.380 --> 00:25:38.661
Or you can even have
the file on the network and

489
00:25:38.661 --> 00:25:40.330
you just browse over the network and
double-click on it.

490
00:25:40.330 --> 00:25:43.870
And when you double-click on it,
it will install and

491
00:25:43.870 --> 00:25:47.090
set all of those preferences at once.

492
00:25:47.090 --> 00:25:51.948
So if you have a standard wallpaper you
want, a screensaver or lockout time,

493
00:25:51.948 --> 00:25:55.610
you want to enable FileVault,
all these you wanna do you,

494
00:25:55.610 --> 00:25:58.880
you can build them all into that profile.

495
00:25:58.880 --> 00:26:01.890
And then save that as a file and
deploy it somewhere else.

496
00:26:01.890 --> 00:26:04.860
The Profile Manager lets you do that, and

497
00:26:04.860 --> 00:26:10.020
while we don't cover it here in this show,
we actually have some server content.

498
00:26:10.020 --> 00:26:13.480
If you're an ITProTV subscriber,
you have access to our whole library, and

499
00:26:13.480 --> 00:26:16.420
we have the server content
in a special show.

500
00:26:16.420 --> 00:26:21.660
Apple used to have a separate ACSP
certification that was just for Server.

501
00:26:21.660 --> 00:26:22.950
And they ended it for some reason.

502
00:26:22.950 --> 00:26:24.420
I don't know why exactly.

503
00:26:24.420 --> 00:26:27.350
But the Server product is still
the best way to go about pushing

504
00:26:27.350 --> 00:26:28.420
out these settings.

505
00:26:28.420 --> 00:26:32.470
So definitely worth a look if you're
dealing with large quantities of Macs.

506
00:26:32.470 --> 00:26:34.060
>> Initial configuration part two.

507
00:26:34.060 --> 00:26:35.470
Make sure you see part one.

508
00:26:35.470 --> 00:26:37.600
Very important, great information.

509
00:26:37.600 --> 00:26:39.050
Well done as usual, Don.

510
00:26:39.050 --> 00:26:44.210
But before we move away into another
subject which I know there are more,

511
00:26:44.210 --> 00:26:47.943
anything else you would like to say?
>> One thing I forgot to mention about

512
00:26:47.943 --> 00:26:52.388
the Profile Manager, it's a great way to
get an initial set of preferences set

513
00:26:52.388 --> 00:26:56.653
up on a machine, but it can also be
configured to maintain those settings.

514
00:26:56.653 --> 00:27:00.305
Maybe you want an enforced desktop on
all your machines, like a wallpaper,

515
00:27:00.305 --> 00:27:03.627
what's to stop a student from coming
in and changing the wallpaper?

516
00:27:03.627 --> 00:27:05.881
That's a user preference, you don't
have to be an administrator for that.

517
00:27:05.881 --> 00:27:09.172
Well, they can do it and the Profile
Manager will put it right back.

518
00:27:09.172 --> 00:27:11.544
So it's a great way to
enforce those settings,

519
00:27:11.544 --> 00:27:13.925
not just to put them in
place in the first place.

520
00:27:13.925 --> 00:27:17.355
So definitely something you wanna look at
if you're working on this in a business,

521
00:27:17.355 --> 00:27:20.062
school, enterprise type environment,
really, really good.

522
00:27:20.062 --> 00:27:21.496
>> Fantastic, well, once again,

523
00:27:21.496 --> 00:27:24.162
initial configuration parts one and
two, see them both, and

524
00:27:24.162 --> 00:27:27.750
see everything inside of the Apple
Certified Support Professional series.

525
00:27:27.750 --> 00:27:29.920
Don's done a wonderful job
putting that together for you.

526
00:27:29.920 --> 00:27:32.660
You'll be glad you did, and
you'll be in the course library where

527
00:27:32.660 --> 00:27:37.460
there's thousands of other videos,
all designed to help you go further.

528
00:27:37.460 --> 00:27:39.921
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

529
00:27:39.921 --> 00:27:41.580
ITProTV is binge worthy.

530
00:27:41.580 --> 00:27:42.540
Thanks for watching.

531
00:27:42.540 --> 00:27:44.400
I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

532
00:27:44.400 --> 00:27:46.838
>> And we will see you again, soon.

533
00:27:46.838 --> 00:27:52.730
[MUSIC]

534
00:27:52.730 --> 00:27:56.148
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explores user accounts in macOS 10.13. Here you will learn about the types of user accounts that you may need to configure including Administrators, Standard, Managed with Parental Controls, and Sharing Only. He also explores special accounts like the Guest and Root accounts.
episodes.title: Managing User Accounts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.100
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet, live-

2
00:00:03.100 --> 00:00:06.095
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.095 --> 00:00:08.277
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.277 --> 00:00:11.928
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:11.928 --> 00:00:13.011
>> Hello and thank you for

6
00:00:13.011 --> 00:00:16.055
watching ITPRO.TV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.055 --> 00:00:17.355
I'm your host, Zach Memos,

8
00:00:17.355 --> 00:00:20.605
as we continue on with
Apple Certified Support Professional.

9
00:00:20.605 --> 00:00:23.562
Managing User Accounts is
the title of this episode,

10
00:00:23.562 --> 00:00:25.937
as we move merrily forward with Don Pezet.

11
00:00:25.937 --> 00:00:27.086
Don, great to have you here again.

12
00:00:27.086 --> 00:00:27.930
Thanks very much.

13
00:00:27.930 --> 00:00:30.645
>> And I am ready to be one
of Robin Hood's merry men.

14
00:00:30.645 --> 00:00:31.485
>> Yes.
>> And-

15
00:00:31.485 --> 00:00:32.931
>> We're men, we're men in tights.

16
00:00:32.931 --> 00:00:33.475
No, we're not doing that.

17
00:00:33.475 --> 00:00:34.097
[CROSSTALK] I'm sorry.
>> Yeah, yeah.

18
00:00:34.097 --> 00:00:36.625
We have the ITProTV dress code.

19
00:00:36.625 --> 00:00:39.320
We'll be jumping into User Accounts.

20
00:00:39.320 --> 00:00:42.360
Now, if you've seen all our episodes you
know that we actually did set up a user

21
00:00:42.360 --> 00:00:45.710
account during the initial
configuration of our Mac.

22
00:00:45.710 --> 00:00:48.243
But that doesn't have to be
the only user account we use.

23
00:00:48.243 --> 00:00:50.030
In fact,
we can create custom user accounts and

24
00:00:50.030 --> 00:00:51.820
do all sorts of crazy things with them.

25
00:00:51.820 --> 00:00:54.180
We're gonna take a look at that
right here in this episode.

26
00:00:54.180 --> 00:00:57.000
>> So what tool do we use to
manage user accounts, Don?

27
00:00:57.000 --> 00:00:59.230
>> Well,
there is the initial Configuration Wizard.

28
00:00:59.230 --> 00:01:01.150
But that just creates one account.

29
00:01:01.150 --> 00:01:03.200
And it doesn't give you
a whole lot of options.

30
00:01:03.200 --> 00:01:03.740
First name.

31
00:01:03.740 --> 00:01:05.060
Last name.
Password.

32
00:01:05.060 --> 00:01:08.640
And it automatically makes
that account an administrator.

33
00:01:08.640 --> 00:01:11.178
So that's not really the tool we're
going to use when it comes to

34
00:01:11.178 --> 00:01:12.670
working with user accounts.

35
00:01:12.670 --> 00:01:16.310
Instead, we actually have a system
preference that we can use that let's us

36
00:01:16.310 --> 00:01:17.510
create users in groups.

37
00:01:17.510 --> 00:01:18.840
Let me bring that up here.

38
00:01:18.840 --> 00:01:24.690
If we go in to Apple menu on top,
we can jump into our System Preferences.

39
00:01:24.690 --> 00:01:26.770
And we can try again to get
into our System Preferences.

40
00:01:26.770 --> 00:01:27.680
There we go.

41
00:01:27.680 --> 00:01:30.350
And in the System Preferences,
you can hang around a bit

42
00:01:30.350 --> 00:01:35.100
an you can see here there's two little
silhouettes, for users and groups.

43
00:01:35.100 --> 00:01:38.060
And that's the primary tool that we're
gonna use when it comes to working

44
00:01:38.060 --> 00:01:38.600
with users.

45
00:01:38.600 --> 00:01:43.270
Now, if you just did a fresh install,
it's going to look something like this.

46
00:01:43.270 --> 00:01:46.890
There might be some little variations
like the icon that it picked for

47
00:01:46.890 --> 00:01:52.020
my account, it just randomly picked
that from the default set of images.

48
00:01:52.020 --> 00:01:55.130
I ended up with a violin or
viola or something.

49
00:01:55.130 --> 00:01:56.295
I don't know what that is.

50
00:01:56.295 --> 00:01:59.130
>> [LAUGH]
>> You might have an owl or a sunflower.

51
00:01:59.130 --> 00:02:00.690
>> A small furry creature.

52
00:02:00.690 --> 00:02:03.710
>> There are number of
crazy icons in there.

53
00:02:03.710 --> 00:02:08.270
You also may or may not see this
guest user account turned on or off.

54
00:02:08.270 --> 00:02:10.790
I'll talk more about that
one a little bit later.

55
00:02:10.790 --> 00:02:14.890
But from here, I can see my account,
and I can come in, and

56
00:02:14.890 --> 00:02:19.320
I can change my password, I can change
the icon, I can make modifications.

57
00:02:19.320 --> 00:02:23.760
Now, by default, I actually can't
make too many modifications.

58
00:02:23.760 --> 00:02:25.840
I can only modify my account.

59
00:02:25.840 --> 00:02:27.930
I can't modify any other accounts.

60
00:02:27.930 --> 00:02:30.130
You'll notice a little lock
down here at the bottom.

61
00:02:30.130 --> 00:02:35.390
That if you're an administrator, you can
unlock this screen by clicking on that and

62
00:02:35.390 --> 00:02:38.730
typing in your password,
and when you do that,

63
00:02:38.730 --> 00:02:43.010
now you'll have the full features to
be able to go in here and modify this.

64
00:02:43.010 --> 00:02:45.710
A regular user can only
modify their settings.

65
00:02:45.710 --> 00:02:47.060
And so, that's what you see by default.

66
00:02:47.060 --> 00:02:50.960
You can modify your own settings,
but an administrator can unlock, and

67
00:02:50.960 --> 00:02:52.700
now they have full access to everything.

68
00:02:52.700 --> 00:02:56.150
So most of the screen didn't really
change, what changed was the list over on

69
00:02:56.150 --> 00:02:59.870
the left side, the grayed out
accounts are now in a bolder black.

70
00:02:59.870 --> 00:03:02.650
Which means I can go in and
modify and change them.

71
00:03:02.650 --> 00:03:05.530
But this is the primary tool that
we're gonna be using to go in and

72
00:03:05.530 --> 00:03:09.860
modify our user accounts, their
attributes, their settings, and so forth.

73
00:03:09.860 --> 00:03:12.230
It's all right kind of tied in here.

74
00:03:12.230 --> 00:03:15.950
So if I don't like that icon,
I can edit that.

75
00:03:15.950 --> 00:03:20.520
And I can pick from a number of defaults
or pick my own photo or whatever, right?

76
00:03:20.520 --> 00:03:23.750
So we can-
>> Picture of the cat.

77
00:03:23.750 --> 00:03:24.258
>> Do you see a cat?
>> No.

78
00:03:24.258 --> 00:03:25.635
[LAUGH]

79
00:03:25.635 --> 00:03:27.350
>> I was going to pick a cat.

80
00:03:27.350 --> 00:03:29.120
We will do a zebra.

81
00:03:29.120 --> 00:03:29.770
You know what?

82
00:03:29.770 --> 00:03:31.640
We should go all American.

83
00:03:31.640 --> 00:03:32.578
>> There you go.

84
00:03:32.578 --> 00:03:37.170
Say I'm an eagle, so I'll pick the eagle
there and, an eagle it's great.

85
00:03:37.170 --> 00:03:39.450
I can change my password,
under login items,

86
00:03:39.450 --> 00:03:42.930
I can change what programs
launch when I first log in.

87
00:03:42.930 --> 00:03:47.300
Maybe every time I log in, I know I'm
gonna run Safari and browse the web, so

88
00:03:47.300 --> 00:03:52.220
I can add that to my list and say, hey,
when I log in go ahead and run Safari.

89
00:03:52.220 --> 00:03:55.850
You just go ahead and find it,
it'll be in here somewhere, right?

90
00:03:55.850 --> 00:03:58.720
Whoops, that's Siri, I don't want her
to bother me every time I log in.

91
00:03:58.720 --> 00:03:59.302
>> Not all the time.

92
00:03:59.302 --> 00:04:03.220
>> [LAUGH] So, I'll punch in Safari,
and now every time I log in,

93
00:04:03.220 --> 00:04:04.690
Safari is going to launch.

94
00:04:04.690 --> 00:04:06.360
That's custom to my account.

95
00:04:06.360 --> 00:04:09.080
So simple changes like these
are all done from right here.

96
00:04:09.080 --> 00:04:11.370
Not a whole lot that we have to tweak or
customize.

97
00:04:11.370 --> 00:04:14.310
But, we get it set up,
we customize it the way we want, and

98
00:04:14.310 --> 00:04:15.370
that's the tool we're gonna use.

99
00:04:15.370 --> 00:04:18.870
>> So, Don,
are all user accounts treated the same?

100
00:04:18.870 --> 00:04:21.520
All right, user accounts
are not all treated the same.

101
00:04:21.520 --> 00:04:23.890
And I kind of mentioned already
that the account that I've got,

102
00:04:23.890 --> 00:04:29.270
that was done by the Initial Configuration
Wizard has me flagged as an Admin, right?

103
00:04:29.270 --> 00:04:31.550
An Admin is a special type of account,

104
00:04:31.550 --> 00:04:33.965
there's actually five
different types of accounts.

105
00:04:33.965 --> 00:04:35.880
And Admin is one of them, right?

106
00:04:35.880 --> 00:04:42.120
There's also regular users, there's
guest users, like you see right there.

107
00:04:42.120 --> 00:04:46.620
There's regular users with parental
controls and then there's groups.

108
00:04:46.620 --> 00:04:48.270
Right, five different types of users.

109
00:04:48.270 --> 00:04:50.860
And each one kind of does something
a little bit different, right?

110
00:04:50.860 --> 00:04:51.860
So an Administrator.

111
00:04:51.860 --> 00:04:55.140
An Administrator can do
anything they want, right?

112
00:04:55.140 --> 00:04:59.250
They have full access to the machine
to modify settings and make changes.

113
00:04:59.250 --> 00:05:01.100
Let's say I wanna share
my computer with Zach.

114
00:05:01.100 --> 00:05:03.480
So I wanna give Zach a user account,
right?

115
00:05:03.480 --> 00:05:05.620
I don't want him messing
with system settings, right?

116
00:05:05.620 --> 00:05:08.420
He can use the computer, but
I don't want him messing with

117
00:05:08.420 --> 00:05:12.860
like the file vault encryption or things
like that, I wanna keep that stuff safe.

118
00:05:12.860 --> 00:05:16.930
So I can add an account for him,
I'll hit the little plus sign down here.

119
00:05:16.930 --> 00:05:20.060
And when I add an account for
Zach, I can pick.

120
00:05:20.060 --> 00:05:22.020
Do I want him to be an administrator?

121
00:05:22.020 --> 00:05:24.110
A standard user?

122
00:05:24.110 --> 00:05:27.590
A standard user that's managed
with parental controls?

123
00:05:27.590 --> 00:05:30.140
A sharing-only user?

124
00:05:30.140 --> 00:05:31.170
Or a group?

125
00:05:31.170 --> 00:05:33.410
Okay, so what are each of these?

126
00:05:33.410 --> 00:05:35.200
Well, a standard user.

127
00:05:35.200 --> 00:05:37.650
That means they can log in on the system.

128
00:05:37.650 --> 00:05:42.330
They had their own settings,
they can install software just for them.

129
00:05:42.330 --> 00:05:45.240
And they can change the wallpaper
that just affects them.

130
00:05:45.240 --> 00:05:48.480
But they can't do things
like changing the hardware,

131
00:05:48.480 --> 00:05:53.860
or doing a system update,
turning on file vault encryption.

132
00:05:53.860 --> 00:05:56.700
That stuff is protected, you have
to be an administrator to do that.

133
00:05:56.700 --> 00:05:58.600
This would be a regular user.

134
00:05:58.600 --> 00:06:01.705
So I can punch in an account here for

135
00:06:01.705 --> 00:06:07.310
Zach and
once I've got that account created,

136
00:06:07.310 --> 00:06:11.390
I can give an account to him and like say,
hey, here's your username and password.

137
00:06:11.390 --> 00:06:14.560
He can walk up, he can log in,
and have that access.

138
00:06:14.560 --> 00:06:19.170
But whenever you see a lock like this,
if he clicks to unlock it,

139
00:06:19.170 --> 00:06:22.430
you would have to put in an administrative
password which he doesn't have.

140
00:06:22.430 --> 00:06:24.480
So that's a protected account.

141
00:06:24.480 --> 00:06:26.940
But the settings inside
are pretty much the same, right?

142
00:06:26.940 --> 00:06:30.010
Well, I've got where I can reset
the password, we see his account,

143
00:06:30.010 --> 00:06:32.180
I can change his icon, if I want.

144
00:06:32.180 --> 00:06:35.550
I can't do the start up items, right?

145
00:06:35.550 --> 00:06:39.110
He can when he logs in,
he can modify his own startup items.

146
00:06:39.110 --> 00:06:40.990
But I can't modify his start up items.

147
00:06:40.990 --> 00:06:42.220
Now, why is that?

148
00:06:42.220 --> 00:06:43.950
I'm a malicious user.

149
00:06:43.950 --> 00:06:46.560
I can make all sorts of crazy
things run when he logs in.

150
00:06:46.560 --> 00:06:49.430
So they don't give us that option
right here by default, but

151
00:06:49.430 --> 00:06:51.590
the rest of it's pretty much the same.

152
00:06:51.590 --> 00:06:52.770
Now, I made him a standard user.

153
00:06:52.770 --> 00:06:55.935
I mentioned there was a standard user
that's managed with parental controls,

154
00:06:55.935 --> 00:06:56.610
right?

155
00:06:56.610 --> 00:07:00.070
If I add another user, so
let's say another one of our hosts.

156
00:07:00.070 --> 00:07:04.140
Maybe I want to allow
Ronnie to use my computer.

157
00:07:04.140 --> 00:07:06.480
So I'm gonna create an account for
Ronnie Wong.

158
00:07:06.480 --> 00:07:10.620
And when it sets up, by default,
it's doing that standard user.

159
00:07:10.620 --> 00:07:14.330
Well, I want him to be managing
parental controls, right?

160
00:07:14.330 --> 00:07:17.133
Parental controls are a set of
restrictions we can use to control what

161
00:07:17.133 --> 00:07:18.060
they access.

162
00:07:18.060 --> 00:07:20.640
And when I choose that
management of parental controls,

163
00:07:20.640 --> 00:07:22.870
the screen changes a little bit, right?

164
00:07:22.870 --> 00:07:25.620
Now, it's asking me, how old is Ronnie?

165
00:07:25.620 --> 00:07:29.420
And that's because Apple has some
default settings that apply that

166
00:07:29.420 --> 00:07:31.560
are customized by age.

167
00:07:31.560 --> 00:07:35.535

00:19:47.880 --> 00:19:50.170

00:20:52.260 --> 00:20:55.260

00:20:55.260 --> 00:20:57.600

00:20:57.600 --> 00:20:59.379

00:20:59.379 --> 00:21:01.930
Or if I just put it somewhere and

00:21:01.930 --> 00:21:06.021
But if somebody steals my Mac and

00:21:06.021 --> 00:21:07.990

00:21:07.990 --> 00:21:08.959

00:21:08.959 --> 00:21:11.479

00:21:11.479 --> 00:21:13.780

00:21:13.780 --> 00:21:15.590

00:21:15.590 --> 00:21:18.550

00:21:18.550 --> 00:21:21.310

00:21:26.760 --> 00:21:29.700

00:21:29.700 --> 00:21:31.970
That's why it turns on that guest account.

On an iPad or

00:21:35.240 --> 00:21:38.100

00:21:38.100 --> 00:21:40.550

00:21:40.550 --> 00:21:43.370

00:21:43.370 --> 00:21:46.170

00:21:46.170 --> 00:21:47.670
I didn't make the guest account.

00:21:47.670 --> 00:21:49.140
It's there by default.

00:21:49.140 --> 00:21:53.290

00:22:01.880 --> 00:22:04.740

00:22:04.740 --> 00:22:07.770
So if I've just lost it and

00:22:07.770 --> 00:22:11.160
at home, well, Find My Mac will find that.

00:22:11.160 --> 00:22:14.630

00:22:14.630 --> 00:22:17.540

00:22:17.540 --> 00:22:19.860
So that's why the guest

00:22:23.465 --> 00:22:26.432
macOS, it is a super easy

00:22:37.689 --> 00:22:40.298

489
00:22:40.298 --> 00:22:46.820
Unix is incredibly stable and powerful,

00:22:46.820 --> 00:22:49.682
It's a difficult operating system to use,
and so

00:22:49.682 --> 00:22:53.470
most users would just not

00:22:53.470 --> 00:22:54.910
But it's there, it's under the hood.

00:22:54.910 --> 00:22:58.410
Apple has done an amazing job of

494
00:22:58.410 --> 00:23:06.140
Well, in the Unix world, your system has
to have a default administrative account,

00:23:06.140 --> 00:23:11.340
and the name of that account is root,
R-O-O-T, the root user.

496
00:23:11.340 --> 00:23:16.360
Well, because this is based on Unix,
there is a root user account.

497
00:23:16.360 --> 00:23:19.290
We just don't see it,
okay, but it is there.

498
00:23:19.290 --> 00:23:21.810
When you go to perform an action that
you have to be an administrator to do,

499
00:23:21.810 --> 00:23:23.420
and it prompts you for

500
00:23:23.420 --> 00:23:28.715
your password, what you're actually
doing is saying don't run this as me.

501
00:23:28.715 --> 00:23:30.245
Run it as root.

502
00:23:30.245 --> 00:23:31.923
You're running it as a different user,
right?

Let me just show you an example so

I'm going to bring up the terminal.

And the terminal, whoops, which if you

And in the terminal,

if you ever wonder how do you really

00:23:54.777 --> 00:23:58.159
If you run the Uname command,
that's the Unix name command, so

00:23:58.159 --> 00:24:01.051
show me the name of the operating

And when I run that, it tells me
not that I'm running macOS 10.13 It

00:24:05.727 --> 00:24:10.098
tells me that I'm running
the Darwin kernel version 17.4, and

00:24:10.098 --> 00:24:15.250
that's Apple's code name for their
version of BSD Unix, they call it Darwin.

515
00:24:16.370 --> 00:24:16.990
>> Yeah.
>> And

516
00:24:16.990 --> 00:24:20.290
because it was an evolution
past the old Mac OS.

00:24:21.440 --> 00:24:23.995
So any how that's the operating
system that I'm running.

00:24:23.995 --> 00:24:26.742
And if I type who am I,
I can see that I'm dpezet,

00:24:26.742 --> 00:24:29.870
that's the account that I'm logged in as.

00:24:29.870 --> 00:24:35.950
But if I use the sudo command,
that's the super user do command, right.

00:24:35.950 --> 00:24:40.290
So I want to run something as
a super user, and I run who am I.

522
00:24:40.290 --> 00:24:42.720
When I run that,
it prompts me for my password.

523
00:24:42.720 --> 00:24:46.460
I'm doing something that needs to be an
administration, I'll punch in my password.

524
00:24:46.460 --> 00:24:48.076
And then it runs, and who am I?

525
00:24:48.076 --> 00:24:49.168
I'm root.

526
00:24:49.168 --> 00:24:50.524
R-O-O-T.

527
00:24:50.524 --> 00:24:51.340
>> Mm-hm.

528
00:24:51.340 --> 00:24:54.350
>> I'm running as that
root administrative user.

00:24:54.350 --> 00:24:56.450
So, that account exists.

00:24:56.450 --> 00:24:57.790
It's there.

I can't log in as that root user account.

00:25:08.020 --> 00:25:10.580

00:20:00.190 --> 00:20:03.790

00:20:08.360 --> 00:20:11.840

00:20:11.840 --> 00:20:15.660

00:20:15.660 --> 00:20:20.472

00:20:23.013 --> 00:20:24.185
>> Mm-hm.

00:20:24.185 --> 00:20:28.209

00:20:28.209 --> 00:20:31.989

00:20:31.989 --> 00:20:35.603

00:20:35.603 --> 00:20:37.440

00:21:20.560 --> 00:21:23.100

00:21:24.320 --> 00:21:27.175

00:21:52.811 --> 00:21:55.517

00:21:55.517 --> 00:21:57.608
But easy enough to just
change their password and

00:21:57.608 --> 00:21:59.191

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explores working with multiple user accounts in macOS 10.13. He demonstrates the Fast User Switching feature and Parental Controls. These allow you to quickly switch users without needing to close running programs and restrict features of the OS respectively.

When you buy a new Mac it walks

And for a lot of us we just stick

20

00:01:01.770 --> 00:01:05.000
>> So why would we want
multiple user account, Don?.

27
00:01:05.000 --> 00:01:07.660
>> So there's a couple of

28
00:01:07.660 --> 00:01:12.290
Maybe we have more than one identity,

29
00:01:12.290 --> 00:01:13.980

30

sharing our computer with somebody, right?

31
00:01:18.180 --> 00:01:22.230
That maybe it's a family,
so you've got a parents and

32
00:01:22.230 --> 00:01:25.390
children and they all share one computer.

33
00:01:25.390 --> 00:01:28.130
So we might want separate accounts for
everybody.

34
00:01:28.130 --> 00:01:30.360
That would facilitate separating out data.

35
00:01:30.360 --> 00:01:33.430
And having separate data means,
we have separate preferences as well.

36
00:01:33.430 --> 00:01:38.430
So the dad in the family might
have a Magnum P.I. background,

37
00:01:38.430 --> 00:01:41.800
and the daughter in the family might have
a Care Bear background, and everybody has

38
00:01:41.800 --> 00:01:45.400
their own backgrounds, and that's fine,
it's all separate and it's isolated and

39
00:01:45.400 --> 00:01:49.730
that's just for personal preferences,
but it could be security as well, right.

40
00:01:49.730 --> 00:01:54.584
It might be that I have a sales person
who has financial data that's being

41
00:01:54.584 --> 00:01:58.802

00:01:58.802 --> 00:02:03.198

43
00:02:03.198 --> 00:02:07.647
I need to make sure that shipping person
doesn't have access to the financial data

44
00:02:07.647 --> 00:02:08.740
of the user.

45
00:02:08.740 --> 00:02:10.640
So we use separate accounts.

46
00:02:10.640 --> 00:02:15.910
If you just share one account everybody
has access to each other's information.

47
00:02:15.910 --> 00:02:18.280
One user could delete another user's data.

48
00:02:18.280 --> 00:02:22.500
Users can read each other information,
there's no privacy created by that.

49
00:02:22.500 --> 00:02:26.330
Multiple user accounts would facilitate
that, so those are a few scenarios, but

50
00:02:26.330 --> 00:02:27.760
basically what it boils down to is,

00:02:27.760 --> 00:02:30.890
if you share the computer

52

00:02:34.770 --> 00:02:36.960

54
00:02:36.960 --> 00:02:38.560
Depending on how your Mac is set up,

55

56
00:02:42.700 --> 00:02:45.350
Where when you press power on your Mac,

57

58
00:02:48.840 --> 00:02:51.470
But when we have multiple user accounts,
you don't want that.

59
00:02:51.470 --> 00:02:54.060
You don't want it to automatically log in.

60
00:02:54.060 --> 00:02:58.190

27

29

00:02:04.260 --> 00:02:08.450

00:02:08.450 --> 00:02:09.730

00:02:34.030 --> 00:02:37.240
