00:26:39.909 --> 00:26:43.736
So they can't get into recovery.

560
00:26:43.736 --> 00:26:44.418
Drat, right?

561
00:26:44.418 --> 00:26:46.003
They've been foiled.
>> [LAUGH]

562
00:26:46.003 --> 00:26:48.334
>> Well, they could crack it open,

563
00:26:48.334 --> 00:26:50.841
they could take the hard drive out.

564
00:26:50.841 --> 00:26:54.948
And they could stick the hard drive on as
a second hard drive to some computer that

565
00:26:54.948 --> 00:26:56.184
they control, right?

566
00:26:56.184 --> 00:26:59.932
A computer that they can log into and
have access to.

567
00:26:59.932 --> 00:27:03.547
And when my hard drive is just
a second hard drive in their system,

568
00:27:03.547 --> 00:27:07.044
they can browse into it and
read all the data out of it they want.

569
00:27:07.044 --> 00:27:10.360
They now control the drive and
they're able to read that data.

570
00:27:10.360 --> 00:27:12.279
So I'm not completely safe, right?

571
00:27:12.279 --> 00:27:14.423
So there's one more security
feature I wanna mention.

572
00:27:14.423 --> 00:27:18.409
We're gonna talk about it more in another
episode, but it's called FileVault, right?

573
00:27:18.409 --> 00:27:21.815
You might have noticed that when I
was in my system preferences, and

574
00:27:21.815 --> 00:27:23.382
I was in security and privacy.

575
00:27:23.382 --> 00:27:27.027
And in here there's a tab
called FileVault, okay?

576
00:27:27.027 --> 00:27:31.004
This is where we can
turn on disk encryption,

577
00:27:31.004 --> 00:27:35.722
where it will encrypt
everything on your hard drive.

578
00:27:35.722 --> 00:27:39.829
Now if somebody cracks open your system,
takes out the hard drive, and

579
00:27:39.829 --> 00:27:43.668
adds it as a second drive to
another machine, it doesn't matter.

580
00:27:43.668 --> 00:27:47.240
Because everything on there is
encrypted and you are safe.

581
00:27:48.660 --> 00:27:52.094
So the short answer to Zach's
question is no we're not safe yet.

582
00:27:52.094 --> 00:27:54.908
But the slightly longer answer is that,

583
00:27:54.908 --> 00:27:59.210
if we have a good user password,
and a firmware password, and

584
00:27:59.210 --> 00:28:04.160
we're doing FileVault disk encryption,
yes, we're safe.

585
00:28:04.160 --> 00:28:09.680
If somebody steals my device,
not only can they not get at my data,

586
00:28:09.680 --> 00:28:12.560
they can't even reset
the system to resell it.

587
00:28:12.560 --> 00:28:14.910
It's effectively a dead weight for them.

588
00:28:14.910 --> 00:28:17.818
Maybe they could take the power
supply out and sell that for parts.

589
00:28:17.818 --> 00:28:21.440
Maybe they could take the monitor off and
sell that for parts.

590
00:28:21.440 --> 00:28:24.440
But the system itself is no
longer functional for them.

591
00:28:24.440 --> 00:28:26.090
They won't be able to use it.

592
00:28:26.090 --> 00:28:27.365
So that really deters theft.

593
00:28:27.365 --> 00:28:28.574
It makes it where-
>> I would think so.

594
00:28:28.574 --> 00:28:30.874
>> Yeah, if it's a properly secured

595
00:28:30.874 --> 00:28:34.615
system, there is no point in
stealing a Mac these days.

596
00:28:34.615 --> 00:28:35.855
Not everybody knows that.

597
00:28:35.855 --> 00:28:38.883
So it's best to secure the system,
make sure you turn on encryption.

598
00:28:38.883 --> 00:28:43.658
And then that way, you know your data is
safe, even if your device gets stolen.

599
00:28:43.658 --> 00:28:45.899
>> Fantastic, another great episode,

600
00:28:45.899 --> 00:28:47.374
user account security.

601
00:28:47.374 --> 00:28:49.976
And I know there is a few more
words you'd like to share with us.

602
00:28:49.976 --> 00:28:52.477
>> Yeah, I wanted to get to a question

603
00:28:52.477 --> 00:28:56.801
that came up in our chatroom
about the Keychain and iCloud.

604
00:28:56.801 --> 00:29:00.679
Yeah, the question was to
give everybody context here.

605
00:29:00.679 --> 00:29:06.570
But I talked about how I could use iCloud
to reset the user account's password.

606
00:29:06.570 --> 00:29:08.538
But what about the Keychain, right?

607
00:29:08.538 --> 00:29:11.441
The Keychain has its own password.

608
00:29:11.441 --> 00:29:15.796
iCloud won't reset the Keychain's
password, so you'd still lose it,

609
00:29:15.796 --> 00:29:20.022
except there is actually one feature
in iCloud that I didn't mention.

610
00:29:20.022 --> 00:29:22.557
And let me see if I even have
it turned on, I might not.

611
00:29:22.557 --> 00:29:28.085
If I go back into my system
preferences and iCloud it turned on.

612
00:29:28.085 --> 00:29:35.122
In my list of stuff here, when I synced
iCloud, I did an iCloud Keychain.

613
00:29:35.122 --> 00:29:40.800
This is where your entire Keychain is
stored encrypted, on the iCloud servers.

614
00:29:40.800 --> 00:29:44.120
Now there's two really cool reasons for
doing this.

615
00:29:44.120 --> 00:29:50.790
Reason one is if I have an iPhone and
an iPad and a MacBook and an iMac, right?

616
00:29:50.790 --> 00:29:51.703
I'm a good Apple customer.

617
00:29:51.703 --> 00:29:53.449
I bought all the stuff.

618
00:29:53.449 --> 00:29:57.351
I can have a synchronized Keychain
across all those devices.

619
00:29:57.351 --> 00:29:59.635
So if I go to a website on my desktop and
I save the password,

620
00:29:59.635 --> 00:30:01.842
when I go to my iPhone
the password is saved there, too.

621
00:30:01.842 --> 00:30:02.447
That's nice, right?

622
00:30:02.447 --> 00:30:03.689
That's feature one.

623
00:30:03.689 --> 00:30:09.698
Feature two though, if I have to reset my
password I'm gonna lose my local Keychain,

624
00:30:09.698 --> 00:30:12.129
the local Keychain gets deleted.

625
00:30:12.129 --> 00:30:15.522
But it's just gonna synchronize
it down again from iCloud and

626
00:30:15.522 --> 00:30:17.540
I get the intact Keychain.

627
00:30:17.540 --> 00:30:23.256
So technically ICloud does not
reset the Keychain's password.

628
00:30:23.256 --> 00:30:25.149
But that's okay, because I don't need it.

629
00:30:25.149 --> 00:30:27.067
It can erase itself, what do I care?

630
00:30:27.067 --> 00:30:30.644
Because I'm gonna repopulate it
from iCloud as soon as it's rebuilt

631
00:30:30.644 --> 00:30:31.513
empty, right?

632
00:30:31.513 --> 00:30:32.825
So it fixes itself.

633
00:30:32.825 --> 00:30:36.110
So as long as we have that
Keychain in place in iCloud,

634
00:30:36.110 --> 00:30:38.163
then we'll preserve that data.

635
00:30:38.163 --> 00:30:40.374
And this is the way Apple
wants to people to do it now.

636
00:30:40.374 --> 00:30:42.563
They want everybody to use iCloud for

637
00:30:42.563 --> 00:30:45.990
their accounts because of
protections like these.

638
00:30:45.990 --> 00:30:48.747
But there's still tons of schools,
universities,

639
00:30:48.747 --> 00:30:52.373
businesses that don't want to give
each employee an iCloud account.

640
00:30:52.373 --> 00:30:53.667
And so they don't use these features.

641
00:30:53.667 --> 00:30:56.368
So that's why we need to know
both ways of handling that data.

642
00:30:56.368 --> 00:30:58.152
>> Fantastic information as always, Don.

643
00:30:58.152 --> 00:31:01.081
Apple certified support
professional is a fabulous series.

644
00:31:01.081 --> 00:31:02.833
Make sure you see every episode.

645
00:31:02.833 --> 00:31:05.536
Don has done a great job putting this
information all together for you.

646
00:31:05.536 --> 00:31:07.128
And you're in the course library, so

647
00:31:07.128 --> 00:31:10.626
there's thousands of other videos that
will help you go further, check them out.

648
00:31:10.626 --> 00:31:12.877
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

649
00:31:12.877 --> 00:31:14.705
You know a good IT pro is always learning.

650
00:31:14.705 --> 00:31:16.919
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

651
00:31:16.919 --> 00:31:18.971
>> And we will see you soon.

652
00:31:18.971 --> 00:31:24.931
[MUSIC]

653
00:31:24.931 --> 00:31:28.385
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduced us to the ways macOS handles disks and their associated data. He details the various file systems supported by macOS High Sierra, demonstrates how to prepare a drive for use, and walks us through some troubleshooting procedures should the need arise.
episodes.title: File Storage
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:03.499
Welcome to ITProTV I'm
your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.499 --> 00:00:05.710
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.710 --> 00:00:06.805
>> [MUSIC]

4
00:00:06.805 --> 00:00:12.500
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Hello and

5
00:00:12.500 --> 00:00:16.020
thank you for watching IT Pro TV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.020 --> 00:00:17.065
I'm your host Zach Memos.

7
00:00:17.065 --> 00:00:20.683
As we continue on with
Apple Certified Support Professional and

8
00:00:20.683 --> 00:00:23.500
this is file storage,
the title of this episode.

9
00:00:23.500 --> 00:00:27.261
We're going to talk about file storage,
right? >> I guess we kind of are obligated

10
00:00:27.261 --> 00:00:31.125
now, it's the name of the show.
>> We need to.

11
00:00:31.125 --> 00:00:31.643
>> [LAUGH] And

12
00:00:31.643 --> 00:00:35.850
in this episode, we're gonna look at
a lot of the different places that we can

13
00:00:35.850 --> 00:00:38.910
put our files on a Mac and
the ways that we can store them.

14
00:00:38.910 --> 00:00:43.826
There's a surprising amount of options
available to us when we store information,

15
00:00:43.826 --> 00:00:48.600
there are defaults and the defaults
are good enough for most people.

16
00:00:48.600 --> 00:00:50.552
But there are times where
we need alternatives and

17
00:00:50.552 --> 00:00:54.810
options and we need to understand what
that storage is like in our system.

18
00:00:54.810 --> 00:00:57.810
Now, storage is a constantly
evolving thing.

19
00:00:57.810 --> 00:01:00.030
So, if you're watching this show,

20
00:01:00.030 --> 00:01:04.970
I've got a Mac that is a,
it's actually less than a year old but

21
00:01:04.970 --> 00:01:07.770
it's a late 2014 model because they
haven't updated the Mac minis.

22
00:01:08.960 --> 00:01:13.880
The current generation of MacBooks
have a slightly different type of

23
00:01:13.880 --> 00:01:18.470
hard drive that's in them, the older Macs
had a completely different subsystem of

24
00:01:18.470 --> 00:01:21.710
storage in them, so
if you're checking all this on your Mac,

25
00:01:21.710 --> 00:01:24.040
you may actually see something
different than what I do.

26
00:01:24.040 --> 00:01:26.960
And that's why it's important that
we understand all the different

27
00:01:26.960 --> 00:01:29.830
things that might turn up
because you just never know.

28
00:01:29.830 --> 00:01:31.780
When you go from system to system.

29
00:01:31.780 --> 00:01:36.350
Some of them have very fast, high density
disks that are present in some of

30
00:01:36.350 --> 00:01:39.850
the newer systems,
some will have more than one drive,

31
00:01:39.850 --> 00:01:42.890
which a lot of the new systems don't allow
because there's just not enough room.

32
00:01:42.890 --> 00:01:44.670
They've made them too small.

33
00:01:44.670 --> 00:01:47.000
So there's a lot variety,
a lot of variation,

34
00:01:47.000 --> 00:01:52.270
we need to understand what that variety
is and what each is really intended for.

35
00:01:52.270 --> 00:01:54.680
So that's what we're gonna be looking
at right here in File Storage.

36
00:01:54.680 --> 00:01:56.210
>> And what types of storage are supported

37
00:01:56.210 --> 00:01:58.200
in Mac OS?
>> We can break

38
00:01:58.200 --> 00:02:02.180
down storage into two categories,
internal and external, right?

39
00:02:02.180 --> 00:02:05.370
Our internal storage, this is stuff
that's gonna be built into our Mac.

40
00:02:05.370 --> 00:02:08.590
So when you go to Apple's website or
go to Best Buy or

41
00:02:08.590 --> 00:02:13.360
the Apple store or wherever and you buy
your Mac, it's got some storage inside it.

42
00:02:13.360 --> 00:02:15.930
It's a given, it's gonna have at least a
little bit of storage of in there cuz it's

43
00:02:15.930 --> 00:02:18.140
gotta hold the operating system somewhere,
right?

44
00:02:18.140 --> 00:02:19.860
That's internal storage.

45
00:02:19.860 --> 00:02:25.440
And we typically don't change our internal
storage, that the storage that it

46
00:02:25.440 --> 00:02:28.790
has when we buy the device is the storage
that it has when we get rid of the device.

47
00:02:28.790 --> 00:02:30.000
That it, maintains the same.

48
00:02:30.000 --> 00:02:33.890
Now there's plenty of companies out there
like OWC that sell upgrade kits and

49
00:02:33.890 --> 00:02:37.460
all that but Apple doesn't
officially do upgrade kits for

50
00:02:37.460 --> 00:02:40.980
any of their devices across the board,
anymore.

51
00:02:40.980 --> 00:02:44.550
So, that storage,
that internal storage is built in, right?

52
00:02:44.550 --> 00:02:47.810
So, you'll know what that storage
is when you buy the device.

53
00:02:47.810 --> 00:02:49.620
And it's unchanged
throughout the life of it.

54
00:02:49.620 --> 00:02:51.270
These are things like hard drives.

55
00:02:51.270 --> 00:02:54.830
And there's actually three different
types of hard drives in Macs these days.

56
00:02:54.830 --> 00:02:56.520
There's traditionally spinning disks,

57
00:02:56.520 --> 00:02:59.490
which we just call HDDs or
Hard Disk Drives.

58
00:02:59.490 --> 00:03:03.570
There's solid state digital disks or SSDs.

59
00:03:03.570 --> 00:03:07.320
Those are the fast ones that cost a lot
more money but boy, are they fast.

60
00:03:07.320 --> 00:03:12.360
And then there's the fusion drives that
are in between that have spinning and

61
00:03:12.360 --> 00:03:14.970
SSD kind of combined into one.

62
00:03:14.970 --> 00:03:16.940
So those are of different varieties.

63
00:03:16.940 --> 00:03:19.380
But those are all internal.

64
00:03:19.380 --> 00:03:23.590
And we will typically just use the
standard Apple file systems on those and

65
00:03:23.590 --> 00:03:25.390
we'll put our files there and
we're in business.

66
00:03:26.410 --> 00:03:30.690
On the external side though,
it becomes the wild west.

67
00:03:30.690 --> 00:03:32.915
If you have a Mac made in
the last three or four years,

68
00:03:32.915 --> 00:03:38.520
you'll likely have USB 3.0 ports,
you'll likely have thunderbolt ports,

69
00:03:38.520 --> 00:03:41.480
you might even have fire
wire ports on your Mac.

70
00:03:41.480 --> 00:03:47.370
And that means you can hook up storage of
all sorts of varieties to those ports and

71
00:03:47.370 --> 00:03:50.190
they might be spinning discs or SSDs.

72
00:03:50.190 --> 00:03:54.000
They might be cheap thumb drives,
they might be an Apple super drive, right,

73
00:03:54.000 --> 00:03:55.180
an optical disc.

74
00:03:55.180 --> 00:03:58.720
It could be any number of crazy
things that you can go out there and

75
00:03:58.720 --> 00:04:00.330
buy on the external side.

76
00:04:00.330 --> 00:04:02.110
And these, these come and go, right?

77
00:04:02.110 --> 00:04:05.550
They're called transient storage,
it's not always there.

78
00:04:05.550 --> 00:04:07.680
It might be there one day and
gone the next.

79
00:04:07.680 --> 00:04:11.350
And we add more or
remove them as we see fit.

80
00:04:11.350 --> 00:04:14.810
Here, things are way different
than internal storage, right?

81
00:04:14.810 --> 00:04:18.758
But that kind of gives you an idea of some
of the different types of devices that

82
00:04:18.758 --> 00:04:19.290
are out there.

83
00:04:19.290 --> 00:04:20.870
There's a lot of things and

84
00:04:20.870 --> 00:04:24.170
some of it is Apple branded like
the super drive that I mentioned.

85
00:04:24.170 --> 00:04:25.350
But a lot of it as after market, right?

86
00:04:25.350 --> 00:04:29.330
That you go and you get a Western Digital
iDrive or whatever they're called and

87
00:04:29.330 --> 00:04:32.020
you stick it on and
now you got extra storage.

88
00:04:32.020 --> 00:04:32.960
Those are perfectly fine.

89
00:04:32.960 --> 00:04:35.060
Apple allows those connections.

90
00:04:35.060 --> 00:04:36.410
You don't violate your warranty.

91
00:04:36.410 --> 00:04:36.920
It's external.

92
00:04:36.920 --> 00:04:38.830
You're just plugging into a port, right?

93
00:04:38.830 --> 00:04:41.560
But that's where we're going to see
the most change with those two types

94
00:04:41.560 --> 00:04:43.740
of storage.
>> How can I find out what storage is

95
00:04:43.740 --> 00:04:47.500
present in my Mac?
>> All right, so, good question here.

96
00:04:47.500 --> 00:04:49.780
Like with my Mac, I have a Mac Mini.

97
00:04:49.780 --> 00:04:51.790
It's tucked under the podium down here.

98
00:04:51.790 --> 00:04:53.420
And it's got some internal storage, right?

99
00:04:53.420 --> 00:04:54.840
Now, I bought it.

100
00:04:54.840 --> 00:04:56.270
So I know how much storage it has.

101
00:04:56.270 --> 00:04:56.900
But if I didn't.

102
00:04:56.900 --> 00:05:00.260
If this is the first time I've used
this system, how much storage do I have?

103
00:05:00.260 --> 00:05:02.270
And what type of disks do I have?

104
00:05:02.270 --> 00:05:05.280
Well, there's a few
different ways to see that.

105
00:05:05.280 --> 00:05:09.800
Our external storage is actually gonna
show up right here on my desktop, right?

106
00:05:09.800 --> 00:05:13.490
So I have a USB key plugged in,
which is called DonUSB, so

107
00:05:13.490 --> 00:05:14.480
it's showing up right there.

108
00:05:14.480 --> 00:05:17.920
And then I have my Time Machine
backup drive plugged in.

109
00:05:17.920 --> 00:05:19.470
They're both USB devices.

110
00:05:19.470 --> 00:05:20.930
One's a 16 gig USB key.

111
00:05:20.930 --> 00:05:23.850
The other's a 1 terrabyte USB 3.0 drive,
right?

112
00:05:23.850 --> 00:05:26.120
So, I've got those plugged in.

113
00:05:26.120 --> 00:05:29.470
I can see them but
my internal storage doesn't show up.

114
00:05:29.470 --> 00:05:31.340
And other things like a superdrive,

115
00:05:31.340 --> 00:05:33.960
a superdrive won't show up
until you put a disk in it.

116
00:05:33.960 --> 00:05:36.400
So I might have
the superdrive attached but

117
00:05:36.400 --> 00:05:39.400
it's empty right now and it won't show up.

118
00:05:39.400 --> 00:05:42.860
If we want to get a better handle on our
storage, you can see some things by going

119
00:05:42.860 --> 00:05:47.040
up to your apple menu and
going to about this mac.

120
00:05:47.040 --> 00:05:48.890
On the About This Mac screen,

121
00:05:48.890 --> 00:05:51.620
it's gonna show you some basic
information about your system, right?

122
00:05:51.620 --> 00:05:55.880
And it's telling you things like your
RAM and your start up disk, right?

123
00:05:55.880 --> 00:05:57.570
So I get some basic information here.

124
00:05:57.570 --> 00:06:01.680
But notice,
it's not really tell me about my storage.

125
00:06:01.680 --> 00:06:04.270
Well, I've got a separate tab for
Storage up here and

126
00:06:04.270 --> 00:06:07.480
if I go to that Storage tab,
I can see what I've got.

127
00:06:07.480 --> 00:06:10.590
I've got a Macintosh HD,
that's my built in hard drive.

128
00:06:10.590 --> 00:06:12.810
It's a solid state seta drive.

129
00:06:12.810 --> 00:06:16.790
I have an SSD, not a fusion drive or
a regular hard drive.

130
00:06:16.790 --> 00:06:20.600
I have an SSD and it's 250 gigs in size.

131
00:06:20.600 --> 00:06:23.450
I've used a little bit of it but
that's the size of it.

132
00:06:23.450 --> 00:06:25.100
When you buy it, like when I bought this,

133
00:06:25.100 --> 00:06:30.330
I could have chosen to do a 500 gig but

00:17:54.640 --> 00:17:55.270
When I go and

366
00:17:55.270 --> 00:17:58.600
click on time machine, I don't realize
that I'm actually picking three things.

367
00:17:58.600 --> 00:18:03.550
I'm saying go to disc two,
which is a USB drive.

368
00:18:03.550 --> 00:18:07.470
On disk two, go to slice two,
which is the time machine partition.

369
00:18:07.470 --> 00:18:13.690
And then on the slice two, there's
a formatted file system, that in my case,

370
00:18:15.840 --> 00:18:19.580
I think it was HSF plus or
OSX extended journal and

371
00:18:19.580 --> 00:18:22.880
so it's finding that funnel system and
it's mapping that to this folder.

372
00:18:22.880 --> 00:18:26.430
So, all of those decisions are made
when I just clicked on this one

373
00:18:26.430 --> 00:18:28.370
little link all kind of automatic.

374
00:18:28.370 --> 00:18:29.310
Which is really nice.

375
00:18:29.310 --> 00:18:31.840
It makes life a lot easier on us.

376
00:18:31.840 --> 00:18:36.500
Now each disk has to be able to
keep track of the partitions and

377
00:18:36.500 --> 00:18:37.300
the things that are on it.

378
00:18:37.300 --> 00:18:40.540
And there are different ways for
them to do that.

379
00:18:40.540 --> 00:18:43.720
When I run disk util list,
I pull up my disk.

380
00:18:43.720 --> 00:18:46.180
It sort of shows us some of this, right?

381
00:18:46.180 --> 00:18:49.260
On my first disk,
I have got this disk zero here.

382
00:18:50.530 --> 00:18:52.580
And you know, let me highlight this.

383
00:18:52.580 --> 00:18:55.350
My numbering was off earlier when I said,

384
00:18:55.350 --> 00:18:57.930
when I thought one of my USB
keys was going to be disk one.

385
00:18:57.930 --> 00:18:59.810
I forgot a little something
that's different in

386
00:18:59.810 --> 00:19:01.930
high sierra that changes this.

387
00:19:01.930 --> 00:19:05.130
In high Sierra,
we have what are called synthesized disks.

388
00:19:05.130 --> 00:19:06.530
See how it says synthesized right there.

389
00:19:07.780 --> 00:19:09.540
Synthesized in your head
that should mean fake.

390
00:19:09.540 --> 00:19:11.790
That's a fake disk, right?

391
00:19:11.790 --> 00:19:13.700
It's not a real disk.

392
00:19:13.700 --> 00:19:17.200
I have a real disk and
it made it into a fake one, right?

393
00:19:17.200 --> 00:19:18.110
Why did it do that?

394
00:19:18.110 --> 00:19:21.890
Well when you buy your MAC there's
three drives you can pick from.

395
00:19:21.890 --> 00:19:26.790
You can do a regular spinning
hard drive or you can do SSD.

396
00:19:26.790 --> 00:19:29.330
Or you can do fusion.

397
00:19:29.330 --> 00:19:31.030
And a fusion disk is both.

398
00:19:31.030 --> 00:19:33.810
There is a regular hard drive and SSD.

399
00:19:33.810 --> 00:19:36.990
And it uses the SSD for
frequently accessed things.

400
00:19:36.990 --> 00:19:38.870
And everything else is
put on the regular disk.

401
00:19:38.870 --> 00:19:41.770
But the end user just
sees it as one drive.

402
00:19:41.770 --> 00:19:44.870
It's two physical drives,
they see it as one drive.

403
00:19:44.870 --> 00:19:45.550
Okay?

404
00:19:45.550 --> 00:19:50.300
The way they do that is by
making a fake disk to represent

405
00:19:50.300 --> 00:19:53.830
that one drive and
to hide the two behind it.

406
00:19:53.830 --> 00:19:55.590
Now, in my case, I've only got one drive.

407
00:19:55.590 --> 00:19:58.350
I've only got one physical internal disk.

408
00:19:58.350 --> 00:20:00.820
It's this SSD right here.

409
00:20:00.820 --> 00:20:01.630
I don't have a fusion drive.

410
00:20:02.680 --> 00:20:08.000
But Apple started representing all
of the systems as a fusion drive

411
00:20:08.000 --> 00:20:10.180
regardless of whether you
actually had fusion or not.

412
00:20:10.180 --> 00:20:12.840
Right?
So mine is being treated as if I have

413
00:20:12.840 --> 00:20:16.720
a fusion disk but
my fusion disk is entirely SSD.

414
00:20:16.720 --> 00:20:17.810
Okay?

415
00:20:17.810 --> 00:20:21.400
On one hand that makes life
a little easier because

416
00:20:21.400 --> 00:20:23.730
everybody is represented the same way.

417
00:20:23.730 --> 00:20:24.930
If I have SSD.

418
00:20:24.930 --> 00:20:29.850
If I have HDD or if I have fusion,
it's all represented the same way,

419
00:20:29.850 --> 00:20:32.630
as a synthesized disc/dev/disc one.

420
00:20:34.100 --> 00:20:36.250
On the other hand it makes
it where we can expand.

421
00:20:36.250 --> 00:20:40.200
Because it's synthesized I can add
more storage to it and would grow.

422
00:20:40.200 --> 00:20:42.430
Now on my Mac Mini, that doesn't help.

423
00:20:42.430 --> 00:20:45.650
My Mac Mini only has one
SATA connector inside of it.

424
00:20:45.650 --> 00:20:48.210
On a MacBook or a MacBook Pro,
that doesn't help.

425
00:20:48.210 --> 00:20:50.510
It only has one connector.

426
00:20:50.510 --> 00:20:52.870
On an iMac, one connector.

427
00:20:52.870 --> 00:20:54.280
Why bother?

428
00:20:54.280 --> 00:20:55.260
The MacPro.

429
00:20:55.260 --> 00:20:58.480
The MacPro still has where you can
have more than one drive in there.

430
00:20:58.480 --> 00:21:00.760
I could add another
drive after the fact and

431
00:21:00.760 --> 00:21:03.240
just expand the drive that I already got.

432
00:21:03.240 --> 00:21:04.640
Thats a pretty cool feature.

433
00:21:04.640 --> 00:21:08.160
So its planning ahead and apple just said
look were going to do it the same across

434
00:21:08.160 --> 00:21:11.930
the board until everybody sees the same
view and it wasnt always like this.

435
00:21:11.930 --> 00:21:13.380
Its something that changed a little bit.

436
00:21:13.380 --> 00:21:14.180
So when I look at this.

437
00:21:14.180 --> 00:21:16.610
When I look at my synthesize disk,
/dev/disk1,

438
00:21:16.610 --> 00:21:19.740
I dont actually see
an EFI partition here.

439
00:21:20.820 --> 00:21:24.640
Right, because the operating system
hasn't booted when the system boots

440
00:21:25.700 --> 00:21:28.490
to map the synthesized drive.

441
00:21:28.490 --> 00:21:33.200
So instead I see my real disk right here,
this is my real disk.

442
00:21:33.200 --> 00:21:36.750
And it's got the EFI boot partition so
that we can boot, and

443
00:21:36.750 --> 00:21:42.660
then it's got a APFS container disc,
all right?

444
00:21:42.660 --> 00:21:44.720
That's the new Apple file system.

445
00:21:44.720 --> 00:21:46.930
We're going to talk about
that in another episode.

446
00:21:46.930 --> 00:21:49.970
But it's got the APFS container.

447
00:21:49.970 --> 00:21:54.600
And that container is 249.8 gigs,
my disk is 250 gigs.

448
00:21:54.600 --> 00:21:58.850
So it's almost the whole disc and
inside of it,

449
00:21:58.850 --> 00:22:03.590
it's creating a fake disk the synthesize
disk that has these partitions.

450
00:22:03.590 --> 00:22:08.370
It's got my Macintosh HD, Reboot,
Recovery and a Virtual Memory.

451
00:22:08.370 --> 00:22:10.330
It's got them laid out inside of it.

452
00:22:10.330 --> 00:22:15.800
So I can see that right here and notice
how it's got this APFS Container Scheme.

453
00:22:16.850 --> 00:22:21.840
That is basically like a table of contents
that says, here's what's stored on

454
00:22:21.840 --> 00:22:25.410
this disk, here's the partitions that
I have, here's how this is divided up.

455
00:22:25.410 --> 00:22:27.240
And there's different ways to do that.

456
00:22:27.240 --> 00:22:31.940
Notice on my Time Machine disk,
it says GUID_partition scheme.

457
00:22:31.940 --> 00:22:35.060
And on my USB key,
it says FDISK_partition scheme.

458
00:22:35.060 --> 00:22:35.830
Right?

459
00:22:35.830 --> 00:22:40.720
These are all different ways of tracking
what partitions are on the disk.

460
00:22:40.720 --> 00:22:44.550
Now I want to talk more about how
those partition schemes work but

461
00:22:44.550 --> 00:22:47.070
they're different for each file system.

462
00:22:47.070 --> 00:22:50.670
And we haven't talked
about filed systems yet.

463
00:22:50.670 --> 00:22:55.660
In the rest of the series we probably
need to go on to a part two 'cause

464
00:22:55.660 --> 00:22:57.910
I need to cover it here.
>> Yeah, let's do it.

465
00:22:57.910 --> 00:23:00.990
>> I need to talk about GPT which

466
00:23:00.990 --> 00:23:05.970
are partition tables, when you talk about
the old FAT or File Allocation Tables and

467
00:23:05.970 --> 00:23:09.425
we need to talk about the APFS and
how it does its container scheme.

468
00:23:09.425 --> 00:23:12.840
'Cause they all pertain to how the system
is keeping track of the stuff.

469
00:23:12.840 --> 00:23:16.240
And once you understand how
those systems work together,

470
00:23:16.240 --> 00:23:19.950
then it's a little easier to see how
these discs are being identified.

471
00:23:19.950 --> 00:23:22.640
Most of this stuff is
invisible to the end user.

472
00:23:23.740 --> 00:23:27.190
But if you're an admin, you have to
deal with this from time to time.

473
00:23:27.190 --> 00:23:29.240
If you're trying to make
a bootable USB key and

474
00:23:29.240 --> 00:23:33.520
it's failing, it might be because there's
a EFI petition stuck on there already.

475
00:23:33.520 --> 00:23:35.930
And the system is hiding, so
you've got to be able to drop down and

476
00:23:35.930 --> 00:23:39.720
use tools like these to clean that up and
get it ready.

477
00:23:39.720 --> 00:23:41.300
These are things that we bump into.

478
00:23:41.300 --> 00:23:44.800
So having a good understanding is
really important, so let's do this.

479
00:23:44.800 --> 00:23:48.500
I've talked about the disks and
the hardware in this episode.

480
00:23:48.500 --> 00:23:52.170
Let's split to a part two and in part two,
I'll switch to kinda software mode.

481
00:23:52.170 --> 00:23:54.850
And we'll talk about the file
systems we can put on our storage,

482
00:23:54.850 --> 00:23:56.230
now we can format them.

483
00:23:56.230 --> 00:24:00.240
And we can see that partitioning process
and then that'd give me a chance to show

484
00:24:00.240 --> 00:24:04.550
off the partition tables and how they
work and how the system is able to kinda

485
00:24:04.550 --> 00:24:08.590
coordinate those and show them as
just simple aliases to the end user.

486
00:24:08.590 --> 00:24:09.150
Thanks Don.

487

Apple Certified Support
Professional File Storage Part 1.

488
00:24:12.030 --> 00:24:14.400
There will be Part 2, so
you want to make sure you see that.

489
00:24:14.400 --> 00:24:18.480
Don, anything else you'd like to say?
>> A lot of the stuff we've done in this

490
00:24:18.480 --> 00:24:20.810
series so far has been really safe.

491
00:24:20.810 --> 00:24:23.040
Like if you mess it up,
there's a way to fix it.

492
00:24:23.040 --> 00:24:24.950
Be careful with file systems.

493
00:24:24.950 --> 00:24:27.460
There are mistakes you could make
here where you could mess it up and

494
00:24:27.460 --> 00:24:29.170

495
00:24:29.170 --> 00:24:32.450
So whenever I'm adjusting
file systems on my computer.

496
00:24:32.450 --> 00:24:34.360
I always unplug my Time Machine disk,

497
00:24:34.360 --> 00:24:36.970
'cause I wanna make sure that I don't
mess with my Time Machine disk.

498
00:24:36.970 --> 00:24:38.120
Because now if I mess something up,

499
00:24:38.120 --> 00:24:39.830
I can just restore from Time Machine.
>> Right.

500
00:24:39.830 --> 00:24:42.100
>> So make sure you have a good backup

501
00:24:42.100 --> 00:24:44.448
before you make any changes
to the file system.

502
00:24:44.448 --> 00:24:46.970
And I I know at this point we
haven't actually changed anything.

503
00:24:46.970 --> 00:24:48.740
In part 2, we're gonna start changing

504
00:24:48.740 --> 00:24:49.280
things.
>> All right.

505
00:24:49.280 --> 00:24:52.840
So, you can be a good Apple Certified
support professional.

And there is a lot of

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.704
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,

2
00:00:02.704 --> 00:00:06.280

3

4
00:00:08.244 --> 00:00:13.043
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.
>> Hi, there, thank you for

5
00:00:13.043 --> 00:00:16.340
choosing ITPRO.TV, enpowering
the world through engaging learning.

6
00:00:16.340 --> 00:00:18.965
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
with this episode of

7
00:00:18.965 --> 00:00:22.850
Apple Certified Support Professional,
this is File Storage, Part 2.

8
00:00:22.850 --> 00:00:25.529
We promised you, make sure you pay
attention, and check this out,

9
00:00:25.529 --> 00:00:26.850
Don Pezet's here to help us out.

10
00:00:26.850 --> 00:00:29.371
Don, thanks so much.
>> Hey, glad to be here, and glad to

11
00:00:29.371 --> 00:00:31.765
continue talking about file systems.
>> Yes.

12
00:00:31.765 --> 00:00:32.610
>> And storage.

13
00:00:32.610 --> 00:00:35.400
In the last episode, we had a chance
to talk about the hardware side,

14
00:00:35.400 --> 00:00:37.140
the physical disks in our system.

15
00:00:37.140 --> 00:00:40.928
In this episode, we're going to take
a look at the software side and

16
00:00:40.928 --> 00:00:43.530
how we apply a little bit
of logic to our disks.

17
00:00:43.530 --> 00:00:47.810
And format them and arrange them to make
them available for use in our system.

18
00:00:47.810 --> 00:00:51.500
So we've got a lot to tackle,
so let's do it.

19
00:00:51.500 --> 00:00:54.090
>> Well, what is the primary file systems

20
00:00:54.090 --> 00:00:55.840
used in Mac OS?
>> All right, so

21
00:00:55.840 --> 00:00:58.460
this is turning into a trickier
question than what it

22
00:00:58.460 --> 00:00:59.013
used to be.
>> I know,

23
00:00:59.013 --> 00:01:00.042
that's why I was hesitating.
>> [LAUGH]

24
00:01:00.042 --> 00:01:00.626
>> I was like, well,

25
00:01:00.626 --> 00:01:04.521
how should I parse this question?
>> So, for over ten years now, for

26
00:01:04.521 --> 00:01:12.150
over a decade, every Apple system,
MacBooks, iMacs, Mac Mini, whatever.

27
00:01:12.150 --> 00:01:15.620
They've all formatted their disks
with a standard file system, and

28
00:01:15.620 --> 00:01:19.016
that's the OS 10 Extended File System.

29
00:01:19.016 --> 00:01:22.190
You'll hear people call it different
things, some people say OSX File System,

30
00:01:22.190 --> 00:01:26.497
or Extended File System, but
it's actually called HFS+.

31
00:01:26.497 --> 00:01:30.930
And HFS+, it's been around a long time,
it's actually been around over 20 years.

32
00:01:30.930 --> 00:01:33.965
But Apple didn't use it consistently
everywhere until a little over

33
00:01:33.965 --> 00:01:34.598
a decade ago.

34
00:01:34.598 --> 00:01:37.051
So if you've got a Mac right now,

35
00:01:37.051 --> 00:01:41.620
and you've been running any
previous version of Mac OS on it.

36
00:01:41.620 --> 00:01:44.820
Then you likely have disks
that are formatted with

37
00:01:44.820 --> 00:01:46.950
OS 10 Extended Journaled File System,
right?

38
00:01:46.950 --> 00:01:48.010
So that one has been there for

39
00:01:48.010 --> 00:01:51.080
quite a while,
it's considered the standard file system.

40
00:01:51.080 --> 00:01:52.963
It provides the linking functions,

41
00:01:52.963 --> 00:01:56.010
the permissions that we're
going to learn about later on.

42
00:01:56.010 --> 00:02:00.830
The time machine functionality,
all of that is powered by HFS+.

43
00:02:00.830 --> 00:02:04.810
So typically we format a disk,
that's what we're going to see,

44
00:02:04.810 --> 00:02:09.070
and if I bring up my disk utility here,
fire this up.

45
00:02:09.070 --> 00:02:10.860
And I take a look at my Time Machine disk,
right?

46
00:02:10.860 --> 00:02:15.570
I mentioned Time Machine,
Time Machine, it relies on HFS+,

47
00:02:15.570 --> 00:02:17.060
it won't work on other file systems.

48
00:02:17.060 --> 00:02:19.680
Because it needs to track
the versions of the files.

49
00:02:19.680 --> 00:02:24.760
And so here's my Western Digital Elements
disc, this USB disk I have attached.

50
00:02:24.760 --> 00:02:28.150
And if I look at the time
machine partition on it,

51
00:02:28.150 --> 00:02:33.090
I can see that it is
Mac OS Extended Journaled, right?

52
00:02:33.090 --> 00:02:37.810
In previous versions, it had a few
different ways this name would show up,

53
00:02:37.810 --> 00:02:40.250
but now it shows up as Mac OS Extended.

54
00:02:40.250 --> 00:02:45.000
And then mine just happens to be
Journaled, which is one of the different

55
00:02:45.000 --> 00:02:48.588
forms of Mac OS Extended.
>> Well, what modes can

56
00:02:48.588 --> 00:02:51.906
the Extended File System operate in?
>> So Journaled is one of them.

57
00:02:51.906 --> 00:02:52.591
>> That's a good question, isn't it?

58
00:02:52.591 --> 00:02:53.126
>> Yeah, [LAUGH].

59
00:02:53.126 --> 00:02:53.821
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

60
00:02:53.821 --> 00:02:57.630
>> So, Journaled is one of them.

61
00:02:57.630 --> 00:03:01.240
Some people, and
the reason I say it's a great question is

62
00:03:01.240 --> 00:03:03.670
some people just assume
that's the only mode, right?

63
00:03:03.670 --> 00:03:06.280
That, hey, it's Mac OS extended, but

64
00:03:06.280 --> 00:03:10.433
what we're really seeing here is
that Mac OS extended, that's HFS+.

65
00:03:10.433 --> 00:03:15.185
Journaled is just one mode of it, and
there's actually a handful of modes.

66
00:03:15.185 --> 00:03:18.816
There's Journaled, there's Case-Sensitive,
there's Encrypted,

67
00:03:18.816 --> 00:03:21.220
there are three different
modes right there.

68
00:03:21.220 --> 00:03:23.880
We could even do all three if we wanted.

69
00:03:23.880 --> 00:03:25.950
Let's take my USB key here, for example.

70
00:03:25.950 --> 00:03:29.950
So I'm going to take this
Kingston DataTraveler that I've got, and

71
00:03:29.950 --> 00:03:33.450
it's not a very big disk, but
maybe I want to erase it.

72
00:03:33.450 --> 00:03:36.676
And when I erase it,
I can choose to format that, right?

73
00:03:36.676 --> 00:03:39.320
So I'm going to call this Don USB, and

74
00:03:39.320 --> 00:03:42.150
I can pick what I want
that file system to be.

75
00:03:42.150 --> 00:03:47.140
And when I look, it's letting me pick,
I can do Mac OS Extended Journaled,

76
00:03:47.140 --> 00:03:50.910
or a Mac OS Extended
Case-Sensitive Journaled.

77
00:03:50.910 --> 00:03:54.690
Now I mentioned Encrypted,
that one's not on the list, where's that?

78
00:03:54.690 --> 00:03:57.060

00:01:28.831 --> 00:01:29.828

00:01:29.828 --> 00:01:34.043

00:01:34.043 --> 00:01:35.613
>> All right, so the main way,

37
00:01:35.613 --> 00:01:39.875
the primary way these permissions are used
is to isolate data between users.

38
00:01:39.875 --> 00:01:43.962
So if I have documents and
Zach has documents, they're separate.

39
00:01:43.962 --> 00:01:45.250
I can't get to his documents.

40
00:01:45.250 --> 00:01:46.458
He can't get to my documents.

41
00:01:46.458 --> 00:01:48.049
They're stored on the same hard drive.

42
00:01:48.049 --> 00:01:52.623
They're stored in the same file system,
but we're separated, right?

43
00:01:52.623 --> 00:01:55.683
But they're also used to do other things
like protect operating system files so

44
00:01:55.683 --> 00:01:56.971
that we can't tamper with them.

45
00:01:56.971 --> 00:02:00.594
Protect applications,
to isolate our sandbox applications so

46
00:02:00.594 --> 00:02:03.216
that they can't access other applications.

47
00:02:03.216 --> 00:02:07.337
That minimize malware, viruses,
trojans, things like that.

48
00:02:07.337 --> 00:02:11.940
But at the end of the day for a user,
they're typically just used to protect

49
00:02:11.940 --> 00:02:15.392
files, folders, and
other shared network services.

50
00:02:15.392 --> 00:02:18.249
Things like shared printers and
devices like that.

51
00:02:18.249 --> 00:02:22.335
So it's all about isolation,
and I shouldn't say isolation.

52
00:02:22.335 --> 00:02:26.395
I should say it's about ensuring that only

53
00:02:26.395 --> 00:02:30.350
the people I want to
can get at a resource.

54
00:02:30.350 --> 00:02:33.976
That resource might be isolated to just me
or it might be shared across five people.

55
00:02:33.976 --> 00:02:36.751
But those are the only five
people I want to get to it.

56
00:02:36.751 --> 00:02:39.874
And that's what I can do if file
permissions are configured properly.

57
00:02:39.874 --> 00:02:41.952
>> Perfect, well how are they assigned?

58
00:02:41.952 --> 00:02:43.787
>> Well,
a lot of them are automatic, right?

59
00:02:43.787 --> 00:02:47.935
So the operating system has a ton of
default permissions that are in place.

60
00:02:47.935 --> 00:02:52.120
So when you went to the old Mac OS,
it's copying files to the hard drive.

61
00:02:52.120 --> 00:02:54.038
And it's dropping them
into various folders.

62
00:02:54.038 --> 00:02:58.171
And when it does that, there's permissions
that are put in place by default.

63
00:02:58.171 --> 00:03:01.921
And they're dictating who's
allowed to access what.

64
00:03:01.921 --> 00:03:07.328
Now, the who part is a little
bit kind of counterintuitive.

65
00:03:07.328 --> 00:03:10.799
And that's because we have to
remember that when we run Mac OS,

00:03:10.799 --> 00:03:13.364

graphical user interface.

67
00:03:13.364 --> 00:03:16.796
But under the hood, it's BSD Unix.

68
00:03:16.796 --> 00:03:23.178
And so any of the security features in MAC
OS usually start from the BSD Unix side.

69
00:03:23.178 --> 00:03:24.548
Permissions are not an exception.

70
00:03:24.548 --> 00:03:28.388
So the permissions are being set in
the background in a very difficult,

71
00:03:28.388 --> 00:03:29.415
unintuitive way.

72
00:03:29.415 --> 00:03:33.507
And we'll see a little bit later how
there is an easier way, the Mac way,

73
00:03:33.507 --> 00:03:34.531

00:03:34.531 --> 00:03:38.294
But the who side, who is it that
we're giving permissions to,

75
00:03:38.294 --> 00:03:42.990
that was actually defined as part of
the Unix standards back in the 1970s.

76
00:03:42.990 --> 00:03:43.966
A long, long time ago.

world it's abbreviated to U.

84
00:04:01.581 --> 00:04:04.588
The user is typically me.

00:04:04.588 --> 00:04:07.003
I create a document,
I'm the user for that document.

86
00:04:07.003 --> 00:04:08.651
I create a folder,
I'm the user for that folder.

87
00:04:08.651 --> 00:04:13.673
So the user is whoever owns the content
that is potentially being shared or

88
00:04:13.673 --> 00:04:15.860
we're giving permissions to.

00:04:15.860 --> 00:04:19.865
After that, we have the group
which is often abbreviated G.

90
00:04:19.865 --> 00:04:24.895
The group, that would be more than one
person that I want to give access to.

91
00:04:24.895 --> 00:04:29.684
So if I want all of the ITProTV employees
to be able to browse to a particular

92
00:04:29.684 --> 00:04:33.179

a group called ITProTV.

93
00:04:33.179 --> 00:04:36.316
Put all of those employees in that group
and just give permission to that group.

94
00:04:36.316 --> 00:04:36.932

00:04:36.932 --> 00:04:40.892

00:04:40.892 --> 00:04:42.190
I can take users out.

00:04:42.190 --> 00:04:45.589
So if I hire a new employee,

98
00:04:45.589 --> 00:04:46.913
now they get that access.

00:04:46.913 --> 00:04:49.816
Before, I would have to go on assigned
permissions to them individually,

100
00:04:49.816 --> 00:04:50.653
it takes a long time.

00:04:50.653 --> 00:04:52.453

00:04:52.453 --> 00:04:55.923

00:04:55.923 --> 00:04:57.952

105
00:05:01.961 --> 00:05:03.613
So that's what a group does.

00:05:03.613 --> 00:05:08.745

00:05:08.745 --> 00:05:12.773
Other is technically anybody else.

00:05:12.773 --> 00:05:16.906
Anybody who's not the user that owns it or

00:05:16.906 --> 00:05:23.338

110
00:05:23.338 --> 00:05:26.496
User accounts that aren't a part of

00:05:26.496 --> 00:05:28.667

00:05:28.667 --> 00:05:31.406

00:05:31.406 --> 00:05:34.223

261
00:12:51.150 --> 00:12:54.570
And it doesn't say it, but it's implied
that if you're allowed to write to

262
00:12:54.570 --> 00:12:56.470
the file that you can
also delete the file.

263
00:12:56.470 --> 00:13:00.825
So if I decide, [LAUGH], this novel is
garbage, let me go ahead and delete it-

264
00:13:00.825 --> 00:13:01.400
>> [LAUGH].

265
00:13:01.400 --> 00:13:04.545
>> Or I can rename it Twilight 4 and
then it'll sell like crazy.

266
00:13:04.545 --> 00:13:06.340
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you can make that choice.

267
00:13:06.340 --> 00:13:08.310
But I can delete it and then it goes away.

268
00:13:08.310 --> 00:13:10.014
So that's part of read and write.

269
00:13:10.014 --> 00:13:12.840
Read and write means you want
somebody to be able to do

270
00:13:12.840 --> 00:13:14.720
pretty much whatever they
want to this document.

271
00:13:15.900 --> 00:13:18.460
Read only is far more limited.

272
00:13:18.460 --> 00:13:22.450
Read only is saying, I want somebody to
be able to see the document, open it and

273
00:13:22.450 --> 00:13:26.580
read it, but if they try and
change it, it won't let them save.

274
00:13:26.580 --> 00:13:29.190
If they try and delete it,
it won't let them delete it.

275
00:13:29.190 --> 00:13:31.230
They can't do that.

276
00:13:31.230 --> 00:13:34.580
So those are the two most common,
but there are a few others, and

277
00:13:34.580 --> 00:13:38.200
it depends on who you're
looking at what you'll see.

278
00:13:38.200 --> 00:13:42.480
So for example if I click on Read and
Write from my user account,

279
00:13:42.480 --> 00:13:46.960
I can pick between Read & Write and
Read only, that's it.

280
00:13:46.960 --> 00:13:51.443
If I take staff I see the same
thing Read & Write and Read only.

281
00:13:51.443 --> 00:13:54.882
If I take everyone though,
I see something else.

282
00:13:54.882 --> 00:13:59.530
Read & Write, Read only and No Access.

283
00:13:59.530 --> 00:14:03.350
No Access says no, you don't get anything.

284
00:14:03.350 --> 00:14:05.850
You can't read it, you can't write to it.

285
00:14:05.850 --> 00:14:07.390
You get no access.

286
00:14:07.390 --> 00:14:13.620
So if it's me, or if's someone in the
staff group, they'll be able to read it.

287
00:14:13.620 --> 00:14:16.080
Everybody else, it's no access.

288
00:14:16.080 --> 00:14:20.790
Now those three right there, those are the
three main types of permissions that we're

289
00:14:20.790 --> 00:14:23.080
gonna see when we're working
with files like this.

290
00:14:24.370 --> 00:14:27.180
They're a little bit different
when you look at a folder.

291
00:14:27.180 --> 00:14:29.310
Let me show you on a folder.

292
00:14:29.310 --> 00:14:33.580
So if I take my ebook folder that I made,
and I pull up its information,

293
00:14:34.850 --> 00:14:39.090
and I come down and look,
I've got Read & Write and Read only.

294
00:14:39.090 --> 00:14:41.906
But if I expand it,
see how there's another option?

295
00:14:41.906 --> 00:14:45.470
>> Write only (Drop Box), and

296
00:14:45.470 --> 00:14:49.460
if I come down here I see it on all
three of them, Write only (Drop Box).

297
00:14:49.460 --> 00:14:50.350
What the heck is that?

298
00:14:50.350 --> 00:14:55.700
Well, Read only means I can
just read the document.

299
00:14:55.700 --> 00:14:58.560
Write only means I can write to it but
I can't read it.

300
00:14:58.560 --> 00:15:00.750
Now that sounds really weird, doesn't it?

301
00:15:00.750 --> 00:15:01.790
>> That does sound wierd, yes.

302
00:15:01.790 --> 00:15:05.085
>> It'd be like playing
darts with your eyes closed.

303
00:15:05.085 --> 00:15:06.080
>> [LAUGH].
>> You can-

304
00:15:06.080 --> 00:15:07.300
>> I tried that once.

305
00:15:07.300 --> 00:15:08.370
The dog didn't like it.

306
00:15:08.370 --> 00:15:11.655
>> Yeah, and
how do you know the score's accurate?

307
00:15:11.655 --> 00:15:14.360
>> [LAUGH].
>> The dog won, he cheated.

308
00:15:14.360 --> 00:15:18.820
But what write only is, is it's
a neat little system, because, well,

309
00:15:18.820 --> 00:15:20.930
I'll give you an example.

310
00:15:20.930 --> 00:15:27.170
So when I was in college, I was the worst
about getting term papers done on time.

311
00:15:27.170 --> 00:15:28.370
And the professors,

312
00:15:28.370 --> 00:15:32.970
they were used to dealing with
lazy college students like myself.

313
00:15:32.970 --> 00:15:37.830
And so what they would do is they'd say,
your term paper is due on Friday, or

314
00:15:37.830 --> 00:15:39.630
Thursday, or whatever day it is.

315
00:15:39.630 --> 00:15:44.120
And it needs to be in
my office by midnight.

316
00:15:44.120 --> 00:15:45.370
They would give you until midnight.

317
00:15:45.370 --> 00:15:48.753
Now I don't know if they actually came
in at midnight to check or whatever.

318
00:15:48.753 --> 00:15:52.776
But you could go to their
office at 11:59 PM.

319
00:15:52.776 --> 00:15:56.633
You could take your term paper and
slide it under the door.

320
00:15:56.633 --> 00:15:59.697
And then when he or she came in
the morning, they'd open the door,

321
00:15:59.697 --> 00:16:01.362
there'd be all these term papers.

322
00:16:01.362 --> 00:16:03.221
They didn't really care
when you dropped it off,

323
00:16:03.221 --> 00:16:06.242
as long as it was there that morning, they
would then pick them up and grade them.

324
00:16:06.242 --> 00:16:08.503
And if it wasn't there,
then you didn't submit it.

325
00:16:08.503 --> 00:16:10.171
And that was the end of it, right?

326
00:16:10.171 --> 00:16:14.903
What I was doing was writing to
something that I couldn't read.

327
00:16:14.903 --> 00:16:19.541
Once I slid my term paper under the door,
could I get it back?

328
00:16:19.541 --> 00:16:21.351
No, door was locked, right?

329
00:16:21.351 --> 00:16:23.213
Could I change or edit mine?

330
00:16:23.213 --> 00:16:25.357
Nope, I slid it under the door,
and it's gone.

331
00:16:25.357 --> 00:16:25.942
>> Mm-hm.

332
00:16:25.942 --> 00:16:28.435
>> Could I look at
the other student's papers?

333
00:16:28.435 --> 00:16:29.026
>> Unh-unh.

334
00:16:29.026 --> 00:16:31.631
>> No, I didn't have read access.

335
00:16:31.631 --> 00:16:34.971
I couldn't read anything,
I could just write.

336
00:16:34.971 --> 00:16:38.332
And that's exactly what Dropbox
is like here in Mac OS.

337
00:16:38.332 --> 00:16:43.494
If I were to set this ebook folder, and
set it so that staff had Write only,

338
00:16:43.494 --> 00:16:48.659
or everyone had Write only, now anybody
could browse to my ebook folder,

339
00:16:48.659 --> 00:16:51.433
and they could give me an ebook to read.

340
00:16:51.433 --> 00:16:53.772
But they wouldn't be
able to pull my ebooks.

341
00:16:53.772 --> 00:16:57.862
And they wouldn't be able to even remove
their own once they've uploaded them.

342
00:16:57.862 --> 00:16:59.601
They're in there, and
that's the end of it.

343
00:16:59.601 --> 00:17:03.683
So Dropbox, or Write only permission,
is a pretty neat thing.

344
00:17:03.683 --> 00:17:08.705
But it's definitely designed for
a particular use case.

345
00:17:08.705 --> 00:17:11.813
I give the example of a teacher cuz
that is an example that I know.

346
00:17:11.813 --> 00:17:14.552
You might already be thinking
of a way you can use it,

347
00:17:14.552 --> 00:17:17.241
you might have a server
that drops off server logs.

348
00:17:17.241 --> 00:17:19.245
And you don't want anybody to
mess with those server logs.

349
00:17:19.245 --> 00:17:23.646
So it's Write only, it writes the logs,
they then get stored.

350
00:17:23.646 --> 00:17:25.958
And you have access to it, and that's it.

351
00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:27.805
But whatever it is that you do,

352
00:17:27.805 --> 00:17:31.296
that's what that Write only
permission is designed for.

353
00:17:31.296 --> 00:17:34.560
There's one more permission I wanna
highlight that doesn't show up here,

354
00:17:34.560 --> 00:17:35.431
that we don't see.

355
00:17:35.431 --> 00:17:38.128
And that's the execute permission.

356
00:17:38.128 --> 00:17:38.888
>> Mm-hm.

357
00:17:38.888 --> 00:17:43.801
>> And I could be wrong on this, but I'm
pretty sure you never see it in the GUI.

358
00:17:43.801 --> 00:17:44.642
Let me just double-check.

359
00:17:44.642 --> 00:17:46.632
I'm gonna go into Applications here.

360
00:17:46.632 --> 00:17:49.496
And I'll take an application,
I've got the Apple Configurator.

361
00:17:49.496 --> 00:17:50.032
>> Mm-hm.

362
00:17:50.032 --> 00:17:56.223
>> And if we take a look at it,
yeah we've got read.

363
00:17:56.223 --> 00:18:01.293
You might not know this, I can't remember
if, [LAUGH] we covered it already or

364
00:18:01.293 --> 00:18:04.650
not, but
Applications are technically a folder.

365
00:18:04.650 --> 00:18:06.402
It doesn't look like it here, but it is.

366
00:18:06.402 --> 00:18:11.623
If you two-finger click on an application,
you could choose Show Package Contents.

367
00:18:11.623 --> 00:18:12.255
>> Mm-hm.

368
00:18:12.255 --> 00:18:15.871
>> And you can browse in, and
you can find the real program.

369
00:18:15.871 --> 00:18:20.573
The real program itself is buried
in there, and it'll look like this.

370
00:18:20.573 --> 00:18:23.194
So that's the real Apple Configurator
program right there.

371
00:18:23.194 --> 00:18:23.743
>> That's right.

372
00:18:23.743 --> 00:18:26.295
>> And if I pull up its GUI,
let's see if it shows up.

373
00:18:26.295 --> 00:18:27.642
It doesn't show up, okay.

374
00:18:27.642 --> 00:18:29.604
So I don't see execute.

375
00:18:29.604 --> 00:18:31.962
But there is another
permission called execute.

376
00:18:31.962 --> 00:18:36.011
And that means if this is a program,
then you're allowed to run it.

377
00:18:36.011 --> 00:18:38.192
You're allowed to run the program.

378
00:18:38.192 --> 00:18:41.603
A text file you don't need execute on,
it's not a program, right?

379
00:18:41.603 --> 00:18:46.398
But an application, a script, any kind
of binary that actually runs a process,

380
00:18:46.398 --> 00:18:49.091
would need to have that
execute permission.

381
00:18:49.091 --> 00:18:53.175
And also folders need
the execute permission.

382
00:18:53.175 --> 00:18:55.870
When you double-click
a folder to browse into it,

383
00:18:55.870 --> 00:18:58.201
that's considered executing the folder.

384
00:18:58.201 --> 00:18:59.373
It's not real program, right?

385
00:18:59.373 --> 00:19:00.639
Is not something running
in the background.

386
00:19:00.639 --> 00:19:01.983
>> Mm-hm.
>> But you're navigating into it.

387
00:19:01.983 --> 00:19:05.781
So that's a fifth permission
that we don't see in the GUI.

388
00:19:05.781 --> 00:19:07.769
And we've never really
needed to set it either,

389
00:19:07.769 --> 00:19:09.623
the operating system
takes care of that one.

390
00:19:09.623 --> 00:19:13.329
But I wanted to highlight it here
because later on we're gonna talk

391
00:19:13.329 --> 00:19:18.110
about these permissions from the command
line, and you will see execute from there.

392
00:19:18.110 --> 00:19:21.296
But Zach's original question was,
can I see all this stuff from the GUI?

393
00:19:21.296 --> 00:19:21.848
>> Right.

394
00:19:21.848 --> 00:19:26.151
>> Well we can for the most part,
but there's a few that are hidden.

395
00:19:26.151 --> 00:19:30.833
And then as far as setting them,
Read & Write, Read only, and Write only,

396
00:19:30.833 --> 00:19:34.286
Dropbox, those are the three
that we really work with.

397
00:19:34.286 --> 00:19:38.187
And then we had no access which
was kind of another option.

398
00:19:38.187 --> 00:19:40.274
And then lastly execute,
which we don't see.

399
00:19:40.274 --> 00:19:42.663
So those are the permissions that
we're gonna be choosing from.

400
00:19:42.663 --> 00:19:46.592
>> So Don,
are we limited to just three entries?

401
00:19:46.592 --> 00:19:47.247
>> Sort of.

402
00:19:47.247 --> 00:19:50.481
So every example that I've shown you so
far, every folder or file,

403
00:19:50.481 --> 00:19:52.369
or whatever's that, three entries.

404
00:19:52.369 --> 00:19:55.242
You had the user, the group,
and the other, right?

405
00:19:55.242 --> 00:19:59.239
>> Mm-hm.
>> Let's go back to my ebooks folder here,

406
00:19:59.239 --> 00:20:00.112
whoops.

407
00:20:00.112 --> 00:20:01.130
Go away, stop.

408
00:20:01.130 --> 00:20:03.251
>> [LAUGH] Okay,
I want to read your novel.

409
00:20:03.251 --> 00:20:05.809
[LAUGH]
>> I'm gonna get back to the novel, right?

410
00:20:05.809 --> 00:20:10.909
Sure, so right now the way that this
is set is that I have Read & Write,

411
00:20:10.909 --> 00:20:14.638
staff has Read only,
everyone else has No Access.

412
00:20:14.638 --> 00:20:16.305
>> Mm-hm.
>> Let's say that I want Zach.

413
00:20:16.305 --> 00:20:18.763
Zach's gonna help me write my novel,
right?

414
00:20:18.763 --> 00:20:21.033
So it's good to have a co-writer.

415
00:20:21.033 --> 00:20:21.804
>> That's right.
[LAUGH]

416
00:20:21.804 --> 00:20:25.130
>> So I want him to help.

417
00:20:25.130 --> 00:20:26.586
Zach is in the staff group.

418
00:20:26.586 --> 00:20:32.390
So anybody who has a user account on your
computer is a part of the staff group.

419
00:20:32.390 --> 00:20:35.712
So if I create five user accounts, they're
all in that staff group by default.

420
00:20:35.712 --> 00:20:39.551
I didn't make the staff group,
it was made by Apple.

421
00:20:39.551 --> 00:20:42.370
So every user on your computer
is in the staff group.

422
00:20:42.370 --> 00:20:45.782
Zach has a user account,
he's in staff, so he gets Read only.

423
00:20:45.782 --> 00:20:47.364
I want him to be able to write.

424
00:20:47.364 --> 00:20:50.092
But I don't want every
user to able to write.

425
00:20:50.092 --> 00:20:51.401
So how do I solve that problem?

426
00:20:51.401 --> 00:20:52.412
>> How do you?

427
00:20:52.412 --> 00:20:55.935
>> I can't if I just have three entries.

428
00:20:55.935 --> 00:20:58.106
>> But Apple thought about that, and so

429
00:20:58.106 --> 00:21:02.393
they've extended out the functionality
that was included in BSD Unix.

430
00:21:02.393 --> 00:21:04.878
In the BSD Unix world,
right now I'd be telling you,

431
00:21:04.878 --> 00:21:07.542
yeah you just have three entries and
that's it, right?

432
00:21:07.542 --> 00:21:09.083
Cuz that's how it works.

433
00:21:09.083 --> 00:21:11.192
But in the Apple world,
they've added on to it.

434
00:21:11.192 --> 00:21:13.910
And now we have what are called
Access Control Lists.

435
00:21:13.910 --> 00:21:17.983
In ACL, let's just go beyond,
just these three entries.

436
00:21:17.983 --> 00:21:22.939
I can hit the little plus sign down
here at the bottom of the window, and

437
00:21:22.939 --> 00:21:24.713
I can add another entry.

438
00:21:24.713 --> 00:21:27.794
And when I do that,
it's gonna ask who I wanna add.

439
00:21:27.794 --> 00:21:31.781
And I can see these different accounts
that I got on my system here, Zach.

440
00:21:31.781 --> 00:21:34.413
And so I'm gonna pick him,
and I'll select.

441
00:21:34.413 --> 00:21:38.518
And once I do that,
I now have four entries.

442
00:21:38.518 --> 00:21:39.852
[LAUGH] Zach.

443
00:21:39.852 --> 00:21:40.890
Still haven't logged in as Zach.

444
00:21:40.890 --> 00:21:42.216
>> [LAUGH]
>> So it's still gonna show up as

445
00:21:42.216 --> 00:21:43.014
fetching for right now.

446
00:21:43.014 --> 00:21:49.002
But he shows up right here in my list,
and I can choose Read & Write.

447
00:21:49.002 --> 00:21:53.710
And now he has rejoined, he's in staff,
so he gets Read only as well.

448
00:21:53.710 --> 00:21:54.892
>> Mm-hm.
>> But they combine, and

449
00:21:54.892 --> 00:21:56.280
he gets the best of that.

450
00:21:56.280 --> 00:21:59.280
So he gets Read & Write.

451
00:21:59.280 --> 00:22:01.664
And now he can help me with this novel.

452
00:22:01.664 --> 00:22:05.343
And technically I've gone beyond what
normal Unix permissions can do, and

453
00:22:05.343 --> 00:22:06.501
I can keep adding more.

454
00:22:06.501 --> 00:22:10.122
I can add more users, more groups,
adding each one in here,

455
00:22:10.122 --> 00:22:12.903
and customizing it exactly
the way we want it.

456
00:22:12.903 --> 00:22:17.413
So this is an example where Apple used
BSD as their core to get that stable

457
00:22:17.413 --> 00:22:19.306
powerful operating system.

458
00:22:19.306 --> 00:22:21.418
>> Mm-hm.
>> But then they extended it to make it

459
00:22:21.418 --> 00:22:24.222
a lot more user-friendly,
and a lot more flexible.

460
00:22:24.222 --> 00:22:26.482
>> Is there any limit to that?

461
00:22:26.482 --> 00:22:27.925
>> No, you know what,
there is a theoretical limit.

462
00:22:27.925 --> 00:22:28.618
>> Yeah.

463
00:22:28.618 --> 00:22:30.764
>> The way these ACL's are stored,

464
00:22:30.764 --> 00:22:34.755
they're actually stored as part
of your file system tables.

465
00:22:34.755 --> 00:22:35.300
>> Mm-hm.
>> And

466
00:22:35.300 --> 00:22:39.705
the file system tables do have a maximum
size, but it's pretty, pretty, big.

467
00:22:39.705 --> 00:22:45.414
>> So you can add hundreds of entries
to this list and not hit the maximum.

468
00:22:45.414 --> 00:22:47.892
Unfortunately I can't tell you
what the actual maximum is,

469
00:22:47.892 --> 00:22:49.697
because it's based on
the size of the data.

470
00:22:49.697 --> 00:22:53.811
>> Right.
>> So depending on what account ID numbers

471
00:22:53.811 --> 00:22:58.072
are being used,
you might get more or less.

472
00:22:58.072 --> 00:22:59.338
Your mileage may vary.

473
00:22:59.338 --> 00:23:02.193
>> Mm.
But either way it is in the thousands.

474
00:23:02.193 --> 00:23:04.104
>> My.
>> And if you've got a list that's that

475
00:23:04.104 --> 00:23:05.784
big, you've got bigger problems.

476
00:23:05.784 --> 00:23:08.573
You should be leveraging
groups in that case.

477
00:23:08.573 --> 00:23:12.145
Most folders,
even in massive complex environments,

478
00:23:12.145 --> 00:23:15.724
you should be able to get down
to about maybe ten groups.

479
00:23:15.724 --> 00:23:19.841
That would be considered a lot for
me if I had ten groups on a single folder.

480
00:23:19.841 --> 00:23:22.401
But you certainly can go pretty high.

481
00:23:22.401 --> 00:23:25.361
So no limit that we really
need to worry about.

482
00:23:25.361 --> 00:23:26.883
>> Fantastic information.

483
00:23:26.883 --> 00:23:29.164
File permissions, this is part one.

484
00:23:29.164 --> 00:23:31.670
There's two more parts
coming before we move on.

485
00:23:31.670 --> 00:23:34.369
Don, anything else you'd like to add?

486
00:23:34.369 --> 00:23:38.724
>> The only thing worth mentioning, we
talked a little bit about Users & Groups.

487
00:23:38.724 --> 00:23:40.307
>> Yeah.
>> And we covered that in another episode,

488
00:23:40.307 --> 00:23:41.775
so you'll definitely wanna check that out.

489
00:23:41.775 --> 00:23:44.463
But groups make permissions easier.

490
00:23:44.463 --> 00:23:47.721
So I can create a group, and

episodes.description: In this episode, Don goes more in-depth into file permissions by showing how to manipulate them from the terminal. He demonstrates the use of chmod and chown and how to change the access control lists. Also demonstrated is how the metadata is retained for files in macOS High Sierra.

We can do a lot of really

>> All right, so step one,

can browse in your application folder, and

36
00:01:44.030 --> 00:01:46.420
there'll be a folder in
there called utilities.

37
00:01:46.420 --> 00:01:49.360
And the terminal is in there,
but I always use Spotlight.

38
00:01:49.360 --> 00:01:53.300
So once you're in your terminal,
the terminal is gonna launch and

00:01:56.160 --> 00:01:58.620

When I run that,

46

Now, this is turned off by default,

48
00:02:26.200 --> 00:02:29.780
It's a preference I like to set in

00:02:29.780 --> 00:02:34.820
menu you can see up here

50
00:02:34.820 --> 00:02:36.490
status bar, these kind of things.

00:02:36.490 --> 00:02:40.120
And that path bar is
what's actually showing me

00:02:40.120 --> 00:02:41.920
the folder that I'm in right down here.

53
00:02:41.920 --> 00:02:44.000
So I'm able to spot that and get at it.

54
00:02:44.000 --> 00:02:47.920
From the command line, I don't see that
unless I type pwd because it's got

55
00:02:47.920 --> 00:02:52.180
an alias of till [INAUDIBLE] that
tells you in your home drive.

56
00:02:52.180 --> 00:02:57.360
Now, when I'm in here I can start to look
at the contents of my folder by typing LS.

57
00:02:57.360 --> 00:03:02.143
LS is the list command and it's gonna list

58
00:03:02.143 --> 00:03:05.470
[INAUDIBLE] desktop,

00:03:05.470 --> 00:03:08.620
I'll even see some that might

So things start to get different

there's some things that are different.

65

On the permissions side, though,
if I wanna see the permissions on these

folders, what I need to do is type LS-L,

that's gonna give us the long

This is the short format,

69
00:03:43.140 --> 00:03:47.090
When I do a -l now I see a lot more.

70
00:03:47.090 --> 00:03:49.130
>> Wow.
>> I see the folder names,

71
00:03:49.130 --> 00:03:55.060
I see folder sizes, and I see the other

so I can start to spot what

75
00:04:05.875 --> 00:04:06.855
>> Okay.

76
00:04:06.855 --> 00:04:08.285
>> Remember from episode one,

77
00:04:08.285 --> 00:04:12.945
or part one, where I talked about user,
group and other.

78
00:04:12.945 --> 00:04:16.105
User was the person that owned the folder,

79
00:04:16.105 --> 00:04:18.855
group was a group of people

80
00:04:18.855 --> 00:04:21.275
And I keep saying folder because these
are folders, but this would work for

81
00:04:21.275 --> 00:04:22.290
files as well.

82
00:04:22.290 --> 00:04:24.380
And then other was everybody else.

83
00:04:24.380 --> 00:04:27.600
Well I've only got two columns here,
not three.

84
00:04:27.600 --> 00:04:31.800
And that's because other, well,
it's always other, right?

85
00:04:31.800 --> 00:04:34.780
There's no changing that one,
it's just hey, this is everybody else.

86
00:04:34.780 --> 00:04:37.700
So they don't need to represent that here.

87
00:04:37.700 --> 00:04:41.070
I've got the user,
all of these are dpezet, and

88
00:04:41.070 --> 00:04:43.490
then the group, all of these are staff.

89
00:04:43.490 --> 00:04:45.820
Bur remember how I
changed the desktop one.

90
00:04:45.820 --> 00:04:49.920
So, if I were to go into my
desktop folder, and then into,

00:04:49.920 --> 00:04:53.050
I think that folder was called
eBooks right, or what was it called?

92
00:04:53.050 --> 00:04:55.600
You know what I renamed it
after that show to files.

93
00:04:55.600 --> 00:04:57.160
So, if I come in here and look,

00:04:57.160 --> 00:05:00.500
there's that Don's novel that

00:05:00.500 --> 00:05:03.610
So, if I do a long listing on that and

00:05:03.610 --> 00:05:09.024
I see Don's Novel, I've got the user
is dpezet and the group is staff.

97
00:05:09.024 --> 00:05:12.069
That's right, I didn't change that,
I added to it.

98
00:05:12.069 --> 00:05:15.270
All right, so if I'd changed it, I would
see it right here represented that way.

99
00:05:15.270 --> 00:05:20.450
But on the left side is where I'm
seeing the actual permissions.

100
00:05:20.450 --> 00:05:22.040
And the permissions,

101
00:05:22.040 --> 00:05:24.990
might not make a whole lot of sense
when I first glance at it, right?

102
00:05:24.990 --> 00:05:28.510
Because what we're used to Apple's GUI,
which you could be seeing for

103
00:05:28.510 --> 00:05:30.790
the first time and it would make sense.

104
00:05:30.790 --> 00:05:33.970
Here it's not going to make
sense the first time you see it.

105
00:05:33.970 --> 00:05:36.530
So let me explain what these settings are,
right?

106
00:05:36.530 --> 00:05:41.840
What we're actually seeing
are ten letters or hyphens, okay.

107
00:05:42.840 --> 00:05:46.460
If there is a letter,
it means some kind of permission is set,

108
00:05:46.460 --> 00:05:49.980
if there is a hyphen,
it means no permissions are set, right?

109
00:05:49.980 --> 00:05:52.170
And the letter dictates a few things.

110
00:05:52.170 --> 00:05:56.979
The very first letter where I've got a d,
d means directory.

111
00:05:56.979 --> 00:05:59.160
This is a folder.

112
00:05:59.160 --> 00:06:01.940
If it's a dash, then it's a file.

113
00:06:01.940 --> 00:06:07.700
So Don's Novel here shows up with a dash
at the beginning because it's a file.

114
00:06:07.700 --> 00:06:11.350
And then the eBooks folder shows up with
a d because it's a directory, right?

115
00:06:11.350 --> 00:06:14.300
So that's the first one,
not really permissions, right?

116
00:06:14.300 --> 00:06:16.620
Just kind of the identity of that item.

117
00:06:16.620 --> 00:06:21.800
But the next nine characters
are all permissions, okay?

118
00:06:21.800 --> 00:06:24.410
It's actually three blocks of three.

119
00:06:24.410 --> 00:06:31.110
Inside of each one you have R,W,
and X, read, write and execute.

120
00:06:32.180 --> 00:06:36.231
In the first block of three
is the user's permission.

121
00:06:36.231 --> 00:06:41.360
The second block of three
is the group's permission.

122
00:06:41.360 --> 00:06:46.740
And the third block of three
is the other permission, UGO.

123
00:06:46.740 --> 00:06:50.490
So looking at my eBooks directory
I can see where the user,

124
00:06:50.490 --> 00:06:54.540
me, I have read, write, and execute.

125
00:06:54.540 --> 00:06:58.566
I can read what's in the folder, I can
write to create new items in the folder,

126
00:06:58.566 --> 00:06:59.550
and I can execute.

127
00:06:59.550 --> 00:07:02.370
Which means I can double click on
the folder and browse into it.

128
00:07:02.370 --> 00:07:04.010
Read, write and execute.

129
00:07:04.010 --> 00:07:06.740
Staff has read and execute.

130
00:07:06.740 --> 00:07:10.560
They can read what's in the folder,
they can double-click to open the folder.

131
00:07:10.560 --> 00:07:13.490
But they can't change
anything inside of it.

132
00:07:13.490 --> 00:07:15.740
And then other is the same.

133
00:07:15.740 --> 00:07:18.050
They can read and they can execute.

134
00:07:18.050 --> 00:07:19.440
User group other.

135
00:07:19.440 --> 00:07:23.100
But if you look at my novel,
I have read and write.

136
00:07:23.100 --> 00:07:25.900
I don't have execute,
cuz this is not a program.

137
00:07:25.900 --> 00:07:28.630
It's not a program that runs,
it's just a text document.

138
00:07:28.630 --> 00:07:33.210
I'm gonna use text editor some other
program to open I'll need execute on that.

139
00:07:33.210 --> 00:07:36.320
But I don't need execute for
this document so I have read and write.

140
00:07:36.320 --> 00:07:38.675
Staff has read, they've got read only.

141
00:07:38.675 --> 00:07:40.335
They can open it and look at it.

142
00:07:40.335 --> 00:07:41.835
That's these three,

143
00:07:41.835 --> 00:07:46.495
oops, these three values if I can,
come on, I know how to highlight right?

144
00:07:46.495 --> 00:07:48.014
All right,
apparently I don't know how to highlight.

145
00:07:48.014 --> 00:07:50.123
>> [LAUGH]
>> But it's these three right here,

146
00:07:50.123 --> 00:07:56.375
there we go, r--, they've got read, they
don't have write, they don't have execute.

147
00:07:56.375 --> 00:07:58.662
And then other Others
are absolutely nothing.

148
00:07:58.662 --> 00:08:00.041
Dash, dash, dash.
>> Dash, dash, dash.

149
00:08:00.041 --> 00:08:00.686
>> All right?

150
00:08:00.686 --> 00:08:01.418
They can't read.

151
00:08:01.418 --> 00:08:02.500
They can't write.

152
00:08:02.500 --> 00:08:03.240
They can't execute.

153
00:08:03.240 --> 00:08:06.500
They can not see a great
American novel by Don Pezet.

154
00:08:06.500 --> 00:08:08.250
They don't know what they are missing.

155
00:08:08.250 --> 00:08:11.015
But that's the permissions that are set.

156
00:08:11.015 --> 00:08:14.710
So from the command line,
things look totally different.

157
00:08:14.710 --> 00:08:15.288
Right?

158
00:08:15.288 --> 00:08:19.420
It was oso much easier from
the GUI to be able to come in and

159
00:08:19.420 --> 00:08:22.260
take that novel, do a command i.

160
00:08:22.260 --> 00:08:27.420
Scroll down and look, and
there is me, staff, everyone.

161
00:08:27.420 --> 00:08:29.595
And you can see where
everyone has no access.

162
00:08:29.595 --> 00:08:32.050
>> Mm-hm.
>> That's far easier, right?

163
00:08:32.050 --> 00:08:36.530
But, from the command line,
we do see that same information.

164
00:08:36.530 --> 00:08:40.670
So Apple has hidden this from us,
hidden the Unix way of doing things, and

165
00:08:40.670 --> 00:08:42.530
made it a heck of a lot easier.

166
00:08:42.530 --> 00:08:45.020
>> Well,
can we change permissions as well?

167
00:08:45.020 --> 00:08:46.820
>> You can, yeah,
you can change the permissions.

00:35:06.534 --> 00:35:08.200
How does that work, right?

624
00:35:09.390 --> 00:35:12.100
How does another operating system
even know to deal with this, right?

625
00:35:12.100 --> 00:35:15.990
What's happening here is, Apple has
what's called the Apple double format.

626
00:35:15.990 --> 00:35:18.310
And most people wouldn't care about
this but it does show up on the exams.

627
00:35:18.310 --> 00:35:19.690
Make sure you know it.

628
00:35:19.690 --> 00:35:20.960
The Apple double format.

629
00:35:20.960 --> 00:35:25.100
Where they say, look, if we're writing
a file with metadata to a file system that

630
00:35:25.100 --> 00:35:29.690
is not an Apple file system,
it creates a second file,

631
00:35:29.690 --> 00:35:32.680
a hidden file,
a file that I'm not seeing right now.

632
00:35:32.680 --> 00:35:38.350
If I do ls -l,
I just see iOS Application Security.

633
00:35:38.350 --> 00:35:43.730
I'm going to add an A, and that's gonna
show me all the files, even hidden ones,

634
00:35:43.730 --> 00:35:47.830
and when I do that,
notice how there's a second file.

635
00:35:47.830 --> 00:35:51.650
I've got iOS Application Security and

636
00:35:51.650 --> 00:35:57.090
I've got ._iOS Application Security.pdf.

637
00:35:57.090 --> 00:35:59.850
Looks like I've got two
copies of the file, right?

638
00:35:59.850 --> 00:36:01.760
But look at the sizes on them.

639
00:36:01.760 --> 00:36:04.960
Let me here to get them human readable.

640
00:36:04.960 --> 00:36:07.080
And let's look at the sizes on these.

641
00:36:07.080 --> 00:36:10.879
The iOS Application Security
pdf is 15 megabyte in size.

642
00:36:10.879 --> 00:36:13.640
It's a decent size for a PDF.

643
00:36:13.640 --> 00:36:18.737
The other one that starts with ._
is only four kilobytes in size,

644
00:36:18.737 --> 00:36:21.310
it just has the metadata in it.

645
00:36:21.310 --> 00:36:23.930
So Apple takes the metadata,
this file system doesn't support it,

646
00:36:23.930 --> 00:36:25.810
puts it as an extra file there.

647
00:36:25.810 --> 00:36:30.260
So when another operating system, like
if Windows or Linux were to read this,

648
00:36:30.260 --> 00:36:33.380
as long as they took the time to write
support for, they could read this file and

649
00:36:33.380 --> 00:36:36.690
say yeah here's the metadata,
this is an orange file, right.

650
00:36:36.690 --> 00:36:38.620
But none of them have done that so far.

651
00:36:38.620 --> 00:36:42.650
So Zach's question was,
how do other operating systems treat this?

652
00:36:42.650 --> 00:36:44.920
The short answer would have
been most of them ignore it.

653
00:36:44.920 --> 00:36:49.890
They just ignore it, but they could at
any time add support for it very easily,

654
00:36:49.890 --> 00:36:52.920
it's just a text file, if you ever poke
around in it it's not really, actually,

655
00:36:52.920 --> 00:36:53.960
I think it's XML.

656
00:36:55.800 --> 00:37:00.390
Let's see if we can look in here and
find out, no, it is a binary.

657
00:37:01.470 --> 00:37:05.010
It's a binary, but you can actually
see some of that data right here,

658
00:37:05.010 --> 00:37:08.840
like that item user tag
that we saw a moment ago.

659
00:37:08.840 --> 00:37:13.530
And other information, but
it's basically just stored in there.

660
00:37:13.530 --> 00:37:18.340
Apple publishes the format of that file,
and so you can support it.

661
00:37:18.340 --> 00:37:20.260
It just hasn't really been done yet.

662
00:37:20.260 --> 00:37:23.381
>> Or you can use that as nice wallpaper.

663
00:37:23.381 --> 00:37:26.120
>> Yeah, it's somewhat soothing in a way.

664
00:37:26.120 --> 00:37:29.040
It's like lakes in between mountains.

665
00:37:29.040 --> 00:37:29.545
>> I do like that.

666
00:37:29.545 --> 00:37:32.195
>> Yeah.
>> File permissions part two as promised,

667
00:37:32.195 --> 00:37:36.100
and now file permissions part
three will be seen as well.

668
00:37:36.100 --> 00:37:37.740
Make sure you watch all three episodes.

669
00:37:37.740 --> 00:37:40.000
Before we move on,
Don anything else you would like to say?

670
00:37:40.000 --> 00:37:43.200
>> All right, so
part one was file permissions in the GUI.

671
00:37:43.200 --> 00:37:46.360
Part two, this was file
permissions from the terminal.

672
00:37:46.360 --> 00:37:47.570
Part three?

673
00:37:47.570 --> 00:37:49.380
Weird odds and ends, right?

674
00:37:49.380 --> 00:37:52.380
There is weird little exceptions to a lot
of the permissions that we talked to, and

675
00:37:52.380 --> 00:37:54.142
just little quirks things that
we needed to be aware of.

676
00:37:54.142 --> 00:37:56.470
We're gonna take a look
at that in part three and

677
00:37:56.470 --> 00:37:58.750
now we wrap up our permissions odyssey.

678
00:37:58.750 --> 00:38:01.210
But hopefully, you've enjoyed yourself and
definitely stay stay tuned for part three.

679
00:38:01.210 --> 00:38:02.150
>> Absolutely do that.

680
00:38:02.150 --> 00:38:04.562
Apple certifies work professionals,
a wonderful series.

681
00:38:04.562 --> 00:38:08.470
Don has done a lot of great work
putting this all together for you and

682
00:38:08.470 --> 00:38:10.660
it will help you and
you'll be in the course library too.

683
00:38:10.660 --> 00:38:12.560
There's thousands of
other videos there and

684
00:38:12.560 --> 00:38:14.030
they're designed to help you go further.

685
00:38:14.030 --> 00:38:14.700
Check those out, too.

686
00:38:14.700 --> 00:38:17.120
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

687
00:38:17.120 --> 00:38:18.860
ITProTV is binge worthy.

688
00:38:18.860 --> 00:38:20.440
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

689
00:38:20.440 --> 00:38:21.290

690
00:38:21.290 --> 00:38:22.780

episodes.description: In this episode, Don takes a look at some of the default file permissions for the home folder and the shared folder. He also discusses repairing permissions and some of the issues that can arise when using permissions with removable drives too.
episodes.title: File Permissions Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:01.768
>> Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.768 --> 00:00:06.336
I'm your host, Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.336 --> 00:00:08.221
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.221 --> 00:00:10.591
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.591 --> 00:00:11.537
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:11.537 --> 00:00:14.515
