watching IT Pro TV.

7
00:00:14.515 --> 00:00:16.925
Helping you learn everywhere you go.

8
00:00:16.925 --> 00:00:17.875
I'm your host, Zach Memos,

9
00:00:17.875 --> 00:00:20.585
as we continue on with
Apple Certified Support Professional.

10
00:00:20.585 --> 00:00:22.835
This is File Permissions part three.

11
00:00:22.835 --> 00:00:26.545
We promised you there would be
a part three, and we are there.

12
00:00:26.545 --> 00:00:28.215
And Don Pezet's gonna help us out again.

13
00:00:28.215 --> 00:00:30.000
Thank you, Don.
>> Hey, thank you for

14
00:00:30.000 --> 00:00:30.730
having me back, Zach.

15
00:00:30.730 --> 00:00:35.850
So to quickly recap, in part one we got
to see permissions through the GUI,

16
00:00:35.850 --> 00:00:37.660
and we've built up our rebel alliance.

17
00:00:37.660 --> 00:00:42.640
In part two, we saw permissions from the
command line, and unfortunately the empire

18
00:00:42.640 --> 00:00:44.581
was winning at the end of that one.
>> [LAUGH]

19
00:00:44.581 --> 00:00:45.855
>> So here in part three,

20
00:00:45.855 --> 00:00:48.950
we're gonna see special,
unexpected permissions.

21
00:00:48.950 --> 00:00:53.230
And this is our chance to let the Jedis
win and save the day and all that.

22
00:00:53.230 --> 00:00:55.660
So that's all right here in this episode.
>> Well,

23
00:00:55.660 --> 00:00:58.645
which default permissions do
we need to watch out for, Don?

24
00:00:58.645 --> 00:01:01.025
All right, so-
>> Those storm troopers.

25
00:01:01.025 --> 00:01:03.950
>> The default storm troopers.

26
00:01:03.950 --> 00:01:05.585
So there are permissions set

27
00:01:05.585 --> 00:01:06.925
all throughout the file system.
>> Yeah.

28
00:01:06.925 --> 00:01:08.995
>> And some of them you might expect,

29
00:01:08.995 --> 00:01:11.455
some of them fall within
this kinda default setting.

30
00:01:11.455 --> 00:01:13.435
But there is a lot of variation.

31
00:01:13.435 --> 00:01:18.310
And so, I wanna highlight some of
the weird ones that are there by default.

32
00:01:18.310 --> 00:01:20.650
Which technically makes them not weird,
the default permissions, but

33
00:01:20.650 --> 00:01:22.400
they're just not what you would expect.

34
00:01:22.400 --> 00:01:27.560
And one of the best places to highlight
this is with the user's home directory.

35
00:01:27.560 --> 00:01:31.500
The directories that we would think would
be the most sacrosanct, or isolated, or

36
00:01:31.500 --> 00:01:34.240
whatever, they're not.

37
00:01:34.240 --> 00:01:36.010
And let me show you what I mean.

38
00:01:36.010 --> 00:01:38.260
I'm gonna drop to terminal
cuz it's a little faster for

39
00:01:38.260 --> 00:01:42.530
me to show this in the terminal,
even though normally we'd wanna use GUI.

40
00:01:42.530 --> 00:01:47.090
But if you go into the /Users folder,
and you take a look at the permissions.

41
00:01:47.090 --> 00:01:49.750
Now, I know that I have a folder and

42
00:01:49.750 --> 00:01:50.990
you have a folder Zach.
>> Yeah.

43
00:01:50.990 --> 00:01:53.900
>> So we would think that I wouldn't

44
00:01:53.900 --> 00:01:56.870
have access to Zach's folder and
Zach wouldn't have access to my folder.

45
00:01:56.870 --> 00:01:58.360
That's what you would think.

46
00:01:58.360 --> 00:02:01.870
But if you look at the default
permissions, with Zach,

47
00:02:03.100 --> 00:02:07.570
everyone has read and
execute on his folder.

48
00:02:07.570 --> 00:02:12.000
And me, everyone has read and
execute on my folder.

49
00:02:12.000 --> 00:02:13.480
What is that all about?

50
00:02:13.480 --> 00:02:19.230
Why would we want everyone to be
able to get into our folder, right?

51
00:02:19.230 --> 00:02:22.530
And this is why it's important to
understand default permissions.

52
00:02:22.530 --> 00:02:23.610
I did not change either of these.

53
00:02:23.610 --> 00:02:25.570
These are the default permissions set

54
00:02:25.570 --> 00:02:27.030
by Apple.
>> Okay.

55
00:02:27.030 --> 00:02:30.470
>> The reason it's like that is inside of

56
00:02:30.470 --> 00:02:34.600
your folder, so now,
I'm in /users/dpezet$.

57
00:02:34.600 --> 00:02:39.290
If I look at the folders in there,
all right, well, I've got applications,

58
00:02:39.290 --> 00:02:41.020
desktop, documents, down loads.

59
00:02:41.020 --> 00:02:44.270
Those are all normal folders
that Apple created for me, and

60
00:02:44.270 --> 00:02:47.851
if you look at the permissions,
now it's what I expect, right?

61
00:02:47.851 --> 00:02:53.980
Only I can get into my documents folder,
and I have read, write, and execute.

62
00:02:53.980 --> 00:02:56.930
Everybody else has nothing, right?

63
00:02:56.930 --> 00:02:58.706
That's what I expect.

64
00:02:58.706 --> 00:03:01.710
Same thing with picture.
Same thing with library.

65
00:03:01.710 --> 00:03:07.530
So if that's protected, why give
everyone access to this home folder?

66
00:03:07.530 --> 00:03:13.030
And it's all because of this
folder right here, Public.

67
00:03:13.030 --> 00:03:16.810
In every home folder there's a folder
called Public, and it's designed so

68
00:03:16.810 --> 00:03:20.680
that if I had a document I wanted
everybody to see, I want everybody to be

69
00:03:20.680 --> 00:03:23.500
able to read my novel, that was
what I used in the first two parts.

70
00:03:23.500 --> 00:03:28.010
If I want everybody to read my novel,
I could just drop it in my Public folder.

71
00:03:28.010 --> 00:03:31.920
And anybody who has a user account on my
computer can browse into it and get at it.

72
00:03:31.920 --> 00:03:34.960
Or if I'm using shared folders,
they could browse over the network and

73
00:03:34.960 --> 00:03:37.750
go right into my Public folder and
see that document.

74
00:03:37.750 --> 00:03:41.350
That lets me, the user,
control that access.

75
00:03:41.350 --> 00:03:44.480
So when I want that document to be public,

76
00:03:44.480 --> 00:03:48.650
instead of putting it into my Documents
folder, I just put it in my Public folder.

77
00:03:48.650 --> 00:03:51.910
Any end user can do that, it doesn't
take a rocket scientist to see him.

78
00:03:51.910 --> 00:03:54.460
Folder is called Public.
>> Yeah.

79
00:03:54.460 --> 00:03:56.180
>> So why am I making a big deal

80
00:03:56.180 --> 00:03:57.160
out of that right now?

81
00:03:57.160 --> 00:04:00.540
Well, if you know what you're doing, and

82
00:04:00.540 --> 00:04:04.700
you put your documents in the right place,
this works great.

83
00:04:04.700 --> 00:04:08.740
But if you don't know what you're doing,
let's say that I'm a user and hey,

84
00:04:08.740 --> 00:04:12.370
I've added my Home folder
to the sidebar here, right?

85
00:04:12.370 --> 00:04:18.010
So I start taking documents like my novel,
and only I should have access to my novel,

86
00:04:18.010 --> 00:04:19.480
it's my novel.
>> [LAUGH]

87
00:04:19.480 --> 00:04:21.310
>> But I drop it here,

88
00:04:21.310 --> 00:04:22.810
where is my novel these days?

89
00:04:22.810 --> 00:04:23.850
There we go.

90
00:04:23.850 --> 00:04:26.930
So I'm gonna take my novel, and
I'm just gonna drop it in my home folder.

91
00:04:26.930 --> 00:04:28.200
Hey, it's my home folder.

92
00:04:28.200 --> 00:04:30.040
I can put it there if I want to, right?

93
00:04:30.040 --> 00:04:30.630
You can.

94
00:04:30.630 --> 00:04:33.530
But the default permissions
to that folder,

95
00:04:33.530 --> 00:04:37.270
remember, everyone has read access.

96
00:04:37.270 --> 00:04:42.240
So by dropping something in here,
everybody is going to have access to it.

97
00:04:42.240 --> 00:04:47.800
If I put it in the documents folder,
now only I have access to it, right?

98
00:04:47.800 --> 00:04:49.900
So users can make mistakes.

99
00:04:49.900 --> 00:04:51.640
And not just users.

100
00:04:51.640 --> 00:04:54.170
I have third party software installed,
right?

101
00:04:54.170 --> 00:04:55.480
AJA mini-config, right?

102
00:04:55.480 --> 00:04:58.430
That's from a company,
oddly enough, called AJA.

103
00:04:58.430 --> 00:05:01.880
And when they created that folder with
their application that was installed,

104
00:05:01.880 --> 00:05:08.535
if you look at the permissions, well,
it's set where everyone has access to it.

105
00:05:08.535 --> 00:05:09.730
Say if they were resiliosync,

106
00:05:09.730 --> 00:05:13.330
a little synchronization program I use,
everyone has access to it.

107
00:05:13.330 --> 00:05:14.570
That's not good.

108
00:05:14.570 --> 00:05:16.710
Those developers,
whoever wrote that software,

109
00:05:16.710 --> 00:05:19.460
didn't realize the mistake they
were making when they did that.

110
00:05:19.460 --> 00:05:21.910
They just said, we'll put it in
the home folder, it'll be fine.

111
00:05:21.910 --> 00:05:23.540
That's not what they should have done.

112
00:05:23.540 --> 00:05:26.910
Their data should be either
going into the Library folder or

113
00:05:26.910 --> 00:05:27.890
into the Documents folder.

114
00:05:27.890 --> 00:05:30.470
It should be going into one of those.

115
00:05:30.470 --> 00:05:34.010
I have VMware Fusion installed,
and it makes virtual machines.

116
00:05:34.010 --> 00:05:40.340
And it's putting those
into my Documents folder.

117
00:05:40.340 --> 00:05:43.190
So inside of Documents, there's
a folder called Virtual Machines, and

118
00:05:43.190 --> 00:05:45.560
that's where my virtual
machines are being stored.

119
00:05:45.560 --> 00:05:47.310
And that's what you want.

120
00:05:47.310 --> 00:05:50.070
Because now the permissions are set right.

121
00:05:50.070 --> 00:05:54.380
Not every developer seems to understand
this, and you end up with documents and

122
00:05:54.380 --> 00:05:56.000
things that are in the wrong spot.

123
00:05:56.000 --> 00:05:58.290
So we need to know those permissions.

124
00:05:58.290 --> 00:06:02.970
Understand that your Home folder is
not as private as you might think.

125
00:06:02.970 --> 00:06:07.430
The default permissions on that
folder are unusual, right?

126
00:06:07.430 --> 00:06:09.380
Everything needs to go
into the subfolders.

127
00:06:09.380 --> 00:06:12.280
The subfolders are protected properly.

128
00:06:12.280 --> 00:06:16.780
Now, if you don't use the Public folder,
which really I don't, I could go and

129
00:06:16.780 --> 00:06:19.590
change the default permissions here,
and say you know what,

130
00:06:19.590 --> 00:06:21.880
I'm gonna make it where only
I can get into that folder.

131
00:06:21.880 --> 00:06:22.920
That makes sense.

132
00:06:22.920 --> 00:06:24.900
I don't use Public anyway,
let me shut that off.

133
00:06:24.900 --> 00:06:26.520
You can do that, right?

134
00:06:26.520 --> 00:06:29.200
But it's not done that way by default.

135
00:06:29.200 --> 00:06:30.980
So just be aware, and

136
00:06:30.980 --> 00:06:34.550
notice how a lot of these folders have
a little plus sign beside them or

137
00:06:34.550 --> 00:06:38.900
an at symbol, which is what lets us know
there's extra information attached to it.

138
00:06:38.900 --> 00:06:42.679
So if I take a look, if I do an ls.

139
00:06:45.316 --> 00:06:47.640
Ls -le, there we go.

140
00:06:47.640 --> 00:06:51.020
If I do an ls-le and I start to take a
look at some of these, look at Documents,

141
00:06:51.020 --> 00:06:52.017
for example, right?

142
00:06:52.017 --> 00:06:57.240
Not only is it set so
that only I have read, write, and execute.

143
00:06:57.240 --> 00:07:00.190
They group everyone as deny delete.

144
00:07:00.190 --> 00:07:04.350
It's like a fail safe that if they
find some other way to get in there,

145
00:07:04.350 --> 00:07:06.540
they still won't be able to delete things,
right?

146
00:07:06.540 --> 00:07:08.460
So it's kind of protecting
that information.

147
00:07:08.460 --> 00:07:11.050
So there's permissions like
these that are hidden away,

148
00:07:11.050 --> 00:07:15.750
and if we don't know about them, we can
end up with behavior that's unexpected.

149
00:07:15.750 --> 00:07:18.940
And your average end-user,
they'll never see this.

150
00:07:18.940 --> 00:07:22.380
They won't even know this is happening
because it doesn't necessarily get

151
00:07:22.380 --> 00:07:24.545
represented very well in the GUI.

152
00:07:24.545 --> 00:07:26.480
In the GUI,
they would have to pull up every folder.

153
00:07:26.480 --> 00:07:28.680
They will have to say, well,
let me look at documents.

154
00:07:28.680 --> 00:07:31.900
Okay, and I'm gonna come in here and,
look at that.

155
00:07:31.900 --> 00:07:34.393
I have read and write,
everybody else no access.

156
00:07:34.393 --> 00:07:39.320
Okay, well, let me go take a look at
AJA mini config, and come in here,

157
00:07:39.320 --> 00:07:42.320
and wait a minute,
that doesn't look right.

158
00:07:42.320 --> 00:07:43.888
How many end users are gonna do that?

159
00:07:45.057 --> 00:07:46.140
Zero, right?

160
00:07:46.140 --> 00:07:48.580
So as a support professional,
we need to do that.

161
00:07:48.580 --> 00:07:51.269
We need to be the ones stepping in and
saying these

162
00:07:51.269 --> 00:07:55.481

if you boot a MAC up while holding the
letter T on the keyboard, it will boot in

398
00:18:50.630 --> 00:18:55.550
the target mode where your system
becomes one giant removable hard drive.

399
00:18:55.550 --> 00:18:59.090
And you can run a Thunderbolt or
a FireWire cable from your Mac to another

400
00:18:59.090 --> 00:19:02.310
Mac, and the other Mac will
just see you as a hard drive.

401
00:19:02.310 --> 00:19:04.830
And you can use their disk
utility to go through and

402
00:19:04.830 --> 00:19:06.610
repair the permissions and it'll fix it.

403
00:19:06.610 --> 00:19:09.837
So several different ways to go
about that to get it repaired.

404
00:19:09.837 --> 00:19:12.320
But it does happen.

405
00:19:12.320 --> 00:19:14.770
Disk utility is certainly
the easiest way to fix it.

406
00:19:14.770 --> 00:19:17.560
Are our permissions handled the same
way on an external storage then?

407
00:19:18.590 --> 00:19:19.130
>> Yes and no.

408
00:19:19.130 --> 00:19:21.130
So for the most part, yes.

409
00:19:21.130 --> 00:19:25.490
If I have an external drive,
right, so here I actually, whoops,

410
00:19:25.490 --> 00:19:30.815
buried in my 8000 windows, somewhere
in here I've got this USB storage.

411
00:19:30.815 --> 00:19:32.490
Okay, so here's some USB storage.

412
00:19:32.490 --> 00:19:35.490
I've got a copy of my novel and
some other things that are on here.

413
00:19:35.490 --> 00:19:40.580
And when I take a look at my novel, and
I look at the permissions on it, I've got,

414
00:19:40.580 --> 00:19:45.180
I'm the owner, dpezet, admin is
the group right now for whatever reason.

415
00:19:45.180 --> 00:19:48.850
Everyone is given no access.

416
00:19:48.850 --> 00:19:50.170
Zach, you have read and write.

417
00:19:50.170 --> 00:19:51.760
NovelEditors have read and write.

418
00:19:51.760 --> 00:19:54.160
And that's all stored
on a removable drive.

419
00:19:54.160 --> 00:19:56.310
Right, there's that external
drive sitting right there.

420
00:19:56.310 --> 00:19:58.450
And so I'm able to set those permissions.

421
00:19:58.450 --> 00:20:01.360
Well, that's assuming it has
an Apple file system, right?

422
00:20:01.360 --> 00:20:05.115
So mine is formatted,
mine should be MacOS extended journal.

423
00:20:05.115 --> 00:20:06.565
You might have an APFS.

424
00:20:06.565 --> 00:20:10.893
If it's exFAT, right, exFAT is really
compatible, works with a number of OSs,

425
00:20:10.893 --> 00:20:13.085
exFAT does not support permissions.

426
00:20:13.085 --> 00:20:14.775
So you'd have no permissions on that disk.

427
00:20:14.775 --> 00:20:17.354
Everybody would have
full access to that disk.

428
00:20:17.354 --> 00:20:19.711
That's why it's so
important to encrypt our disks.

429
00:20:19.711 --> 00:20:23.903
But in this case, it's an Apple file
system so I have real permissions,

430
00:20:23.903 --> 00:20:24.599
all right?

431
00:20:24.599 --> 00:20:27.630
But there's one little problem.

432
00:20:27.630 --> 00:20:29.560
This is a removable drive.

433
00:20:29.560 --> 00:20:34.310
So if I eject it and I give to Zach and
Zach plugs it into his computer,

434
00:20:34.310 --> 00:20:36.510
it's gonna look at these permissions and
what is it gonna find?

435
00:20:36.510 --> 00:20:39.750
Well, it's gonna find this list down here.

436
00:20:39.750 --> 00:20:45.550
This list is groups and
users that are on my computer.

437
00:20:45.550 --> 00:20:47.270
Are they on his computer?

438
00:20:47.270 --> 00:20:50.420
Well, Zach probably is,
right, but NovelEditors?

439
00:20:50.420 --> 00:20:52.560
That group doesn't exist on his computer.

440
00:20:52.560 --> 00:20:54.610
The user, dpezet, that's me.

441
00:20:54.610 --> 00:20:57.950
I don't exist on his computer, unless
you've made an account I don't know about.

442
00:20:57.950 --> 00:21:01.070
So these don't exist
on the other computer.

443
00:21:01.070 --> 00:21:05.530
So when you plug into another system,
do these permissions work?

444
00:21:06.610 --> 00:21:07.610
Not necessarily.

445
00:21:08.620 --> 00:21:10.830
You can have a lot of problems with that.

446
00:21:10.830 --> 00:21:13.180
So when you've got removable media,

447
00:21:13.180 --> 00:21:17.770
sometimes those permissions
are getting ignored, all right?

448
00:21:17.770 --> 00:21:20.027
And I don't see it,
let me unlock this real quick.

449
00:21:20.027 --> 00:21:25.453
A lot of times what will happen is when
you plug in a removable drive, and it was

450
00:21:25.453 --> 00:21:31.237
set up in another computer, well, this one
was set up in my computer, so I see it.

451
00:21:31.237 --> 00:21:36.576
If it was set up in another computer,
there'll actually be, at the bottom

452
00:21:36.576 --> 00:21:42.860
of the screen, a little check mark that
says, ignore ownership on this drive.

453
00:21:42.860 --> 00:21:47.530
If it's a removable drive, and
the system knows it, then it says, hey,

454
00:21:47.530 --> 00:21:49.750
the owner doesn't really
mean anything to me.

455
00:21:49.750 --> 00:21:50.862
Let's just ignore it.

456
00:21:50.862 --> 00:21:53.210
And so that gets treated differently.

457
00:21:53.210 --> 00:21:57.330
Let me take this disk, and
I'm just gonna format it.

458
00:21:57.330 --> 00:21:58.900
I'll format it exFAT.

459
00:21:58.900 --> 00:22:02.885
If I format it exFAT, the system will
know that it can't trust the disk, so

460
00:22:02.885 --> 00:22:05.830
I'm just gonna format that real quick.

461
00:22:05.830 --> 00:22:08.380
And once I do that, there we go.

462
00:22:08.380 --> 00:22:08.970
So that's done.

463
00:22:10.150 --> 00:22:14.310
I'll pull up the permissions
on that disk and, shoot,

464
00:22:14.310 --> 00:22:17.177
it's gonna tell me I have custom access.

465
00:22:17.177 --> 00:22:19.754
[SOUND] Just told me I have custom access.

466
00:22:19.754 --> 00:22:23.157
But if this disk were formatted in some
other computer and I bring it over here,

467
00:22:23.157 --> 00:22:26.560
I would just see that checkpoint
that says ignore ownership.

468
00:22:26.560 --> 00:22:28.686
What that's really trying
to tell you is hey,

469
00:22:28.686 --> 00:22:31.880
sending permissions on a removable drive,
that's great and

470
00:22:31.880 --> 00:22:34.390
all, but they don't mean anything.
>> Wow.

471
00:22:34.390 --> 00:22:35.360
>> They're pointless.

472
00:22:35.360 --> 00:22:40.180
It's pointless to have permissions on a
removable disk because the moment you plug

473
00:22:40.180 --> 00:22:43.370
it into another computer,
they all get ignored anyway, right?

474
00:22:43.370 --> 00:22:45.780
So how do we fix that?

475
00:22:45.780 --> 00:22:50.580
On removable media it is
super mega ultra double

476
00:22:50.580 --> 00:22:55.600
secret provision important to make
sure that you encrypt the disc.

477
00:22:55.600 --> 00:23:00.536
If it's encrypted, now nobody has
access to the disc at all unless they

478
00:23:00.536 --> 00:23:03.020
can unlock the disc.
>> If they have the key.

479
00:23:03.020 --> 00:23:04.004
>> If they have the key to

480
00:23:04.004 --> 00:23:05.030
unlock it, right.

481
00:23:05.030 --> 00:23:07.020
That's how you protect removable media.

482
00:23:07.020 --> 00:23:09.980
File permissions,
that doesn't work, right?

483
00:23:09.980 --> 00:23:11.910
Maybe if this was a server, right?

484
00:23:11.910 --> 00:23:16.500
So maybe I had a Mac Mini with a bunch of
USB drives stuck in a closet somewhere,

485
00:23:16.500 --> 00:23:20.020
I might set permissions, cuz people are
coming in over the network to access it.

486
00:23:20.020 --> 00:23:24.280
But if other people have physical access
to the disk, the permissions are useless.

487
00:23:24.280 --> 00:23:28.560
So on removable media,
we don't normally worry too much about it.

488
00:23:28.560 --> 00:23:32.460
And then we just make sure to secure it
a different way, like doing encryption.

489
00:23:32.460 --> 00:23:33.700
It's easy enough to do.

490
00:23:33.700 --> 00:23:35.860
That's the way you protect it.
>> Fantastic,

491
00:23:35.860 --> 00:23:37.390
well, file permissions part three.

492
00:23:37.390 --> 00:23:39.010
Make sure you see parts one and two.

493
00:23:39.010 --> 00:23:40.177
And before you move on, Don,

494
00:23:40.177 --> 00:23:43.428
I know you wanna say something else.

the troubleshooting world that we'll talk

File permissions can oftentimes be

498

Most people don't

If you stick with the GUI,

Check those out, too.

Hey, ITProTV is binge-worthy.

WEBVTT

1

2

4

>> You're watching ITPro.TV
>> All right, greetings, everyone.

5

And welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITPro.TV.

6

Joining us in the studio once again,

12
00:00:29.970 --> 00:00:31.550

13
00:00:31.550 --> 00:00:32.430
Don, welcome back, man.

14
00:00:32.430 --> 00:00:33.320
How's it going?
>> Well,

15
00:00:33.320 --> 00:00:36.260
I am ready to support some Macs on my
way to becoming an Apple certified

00:00:36.260 --> 00:00:37.810

In this episode,

00:00:41.202 --> 00:00:43.330

We're not gonna bore you to death with

00:00:43.330 --> 00:00:45.400
copying and pasting files, and all that.

20
00:00:45.400 --> 00:00:46.177
We'll bore you another
day with that stuff.

21
00:00:46.177 --> 00:00:46.803
>> [LAUGH]

22
00:00:46.803 --> 00:00:47.564
>> We're gonna focus

23
00:00:47.564 --> 00:00:50.190
on some of the advanced features
that files have inside of macOS.

24
00:00:50.190 --> 00:00:53.490
There's actually a lot of little bells and
whistles, and some interesting features

25
00:00:53.490 --> 00:00:56.970
that are brought about,
thanks to the macOS extended file system.

26
00:00:56.970 --> 00:00:59.022
So we're gonna give you a chance
to see those right here.

27
00:00:59.022 --> 00:01:02.870
I have to remember to mention APFS as
well, which provides these same features.

28
00:01:02.870 --> 00:01:05.730
So we're gonna get a chance to
see all those things right here

29
00:01:05.730 --> 00:01:06.670
in this episode.
>> All right.

30
00:01:06.670 --> 00:01:09.270
Well, Don, I know one of the first things
they like to call out when it comes to

31
00:01:09.270 --> 00:01:14.230
these advanced file system features is
aliasing, a very, very handy thing.

32
00:01:14.230 --> 00:01:18.490
If you're unfamiliar with aliasing inside
of a file system, a very, very good thing.

33
00:01:18.490 --> 00:01:21.080
And we have this ability inside
of our Mac as well, correct?

34
00:01:21.080 --> 00:01:21.670
>> Absolutely,

35
00:01:21.670 --> 00:01:24.590
except Mac aliases are a little more
powerful than what a lot of other

36
00:01:24.590 --> 00:01:28.940
platforms have So other platforms like
Windows, you have shortcuts, right?

37
00:01:28.940 --> 00:01:33.999
A shortcut is just an icon that points
to a file stored somewhere else, right?

38
00:01:33.999 --> 00:01:36.020
So you've got a file stored one place.

39
00:01:36.020 --> 00:01:39.580
But you don't wanna navigate,
there's too many folders deep or whatever.

40
00:01:39.580 --> 00:01:43.040
You have some program
you run all the time.

41
00:01:43.040 --> 00:01:44.900
Well, you wanna move it somewhere else,
right?

42
00:01:45.980 --> 00:01:48.670
You don't necessarily wanna move it
though, because that could cause problems.

43
00:01:48.670 --> 00:01:53.220
Let's say, for example,
that I am constantly

44
00:01:53.220 --> 00:01:58.660
having to go into,
I have a little program called Media Info.

45
00:01:58.660 --> 00:01:59.760
And Media Info,

46
00:01:59.760 --> 00:02:03.540
if I browse into my applications,
it should be sitting in here.

47
00:02:03.540 --> 00:02:06.230
You ever get a video file and

48
00:02:06.230 --> 00:02:09.876
you don't know what codec it is?
>> Yeah.

49
00:02:09.876 --> 00:02:10.789
>> Or whatever.

50
00:02:10.789 --> 00:02:14.980
This little program, which seems-
>> It's hiding from you.

51
00:02:14.980 --> 00:02:15.971
>> It's so important that,

52
00:02:15.971 --> 00:02:16.920
have I not installed it?

53
00:02:16.920 --> 00:02:18.518
All right, we'll pick a different one.

54
00:02:18.518 --> 00:02:20.230
We'll do Serial.
>> [LAUGH]

55
00:02:20.230 --> 00:02:21.330
>> For the record, Media Info,

56
00:02:21.330 --> 00:02:23.745
you can just drop a video file in and
it tells you what codec it's using-

57
00:02:23.745 --> 00:02:24.374
>> That's cool.

58
00:02:24.374 --> 00:02:25.690
>> What bit rate and all that other stuff.

59
00:02:25.690 --> 00:02:27.920
But I'll take Serial here.

60
00:02:27.920 --> 00:02:29.340
I work on routers and switches.

61
00:02:29.340 --> 00:02:32.380
Sometimes I need to plug into their
console port using a serial cable.

62
00:02:32.380 --> 00:02:33.640
This program lets me do it.

63
00:02:33.640 --> 00:02:36.850
So let's say that I use this
program all the time, right?

64
00:02:36.850 --> 00:02:38.930
Well, I might say, man,
I use this so much.

65
00:02:38.930 --> 00:02:41.120
Let me just stick it on my desktop, right?

66
00:02:41.120 --> 00:02:44.630
I'm gonna drag that and
drop it here on my desktop.

67
00:02:44.630 --> 00:02:49.500
Well, if I do that, if I'm the
administrator I can, it'll let me move it.

68
00:02:49.500 --> 00:02:50.530
It'll prompt me for credentials.

69
00:02:50.530 --> 00:02:52.760
Then I can move it out, right,
and it'll be on my desktop.

70
00:02:52.760 --> 00:02:55.324
And then I can run it,
it'll let me run it from the desktop.

71
00:02:55.324 --> 00:02:59.130
But what about any other
user on my system?

72
00:02:59.130 --> 00:03:00.340
That application's now gone for

73
00:03:00.340 --> 00:03:05.050
them, because it's in the desktop
folder of my user profile, right?

74
00:03:05.050 --> 00:03:06.380
That's not good.

75
00:03:06.380 --> 00:03:09.030
So instead of moving it,

76
00:03:09.030 --> 00:03:14.339
what we should do is create an alias or
a shortcut.

77
00:03:14.339 --> 00:03:16.950
And you can do this with a file,
you can do it with a folder.

78
00:03:16.950 --> 00:03:18.740
You can do it with an application.

79
00:03:18.740 --> 00:03:22.110
You can really do it with anything
that's represented as an icon here.

80
00:03:22.110 --> 00:03:26.358
And you can take that item and
you can make an alias for it.

81
00:03:26.358 --> 00:03:30.007
If you Ctrl+click on something,
or I've got a magic touchpad, so

82
00:03:30.007 --> 00:03:31.230
I two-finger click.

83
00:03:32.250 --> 00:03:34.090
When you do that, you get your menu.

84
00:03:34.090 --> 00:03:38.620
And in the menu,
you'll see an option here to Make Alias.

85
00:03:38.620 --> 00:03:41.960
And I can make an alias
of that Serial program.

86
00:03:41.960 --> 00:03:46.646
And then I can take the alias, oops.
>> And you can open it up [LAUGH].

87
00:03:46.646 --> 00:03:47.980
>> Preview by accident, yeah.

88
00:03:47.980 --> 00:03:50.890
And then I can just drag it and
drop it onto my desktop.

89
00:03:50.890 --> 00:03:52.290
And there it is, right?

90
00:03:52.290 --> 00:03:57.244
Now the important part here is that the
original version of Serial, that program,

91
00:03:57.244 --> 00:03:59.099
is still sitting right there.

92
00:03:59.099 --> 00:04:02.030
So all of the other users see it in
the Application folder like normal.

93
00:04:02.030 --> 00:04:04.060
But now I've got this nice,

94
00:04:04.060 --> 00:04:08.710
neat little alias right here
that's pointing to it, okay?

95
00:04:08.710 --> 00:04:11.290
And I know it's an alias cuz
it's got this little arrow.

96
00:04:11.290 --> 00:04:13.750
See that little tiny arrow in the icon?

97
00:04:13.750 --> 00:04:16.080
That's the only way I really
know this is an alias.

98
00:04:16.080 --> 00:04:18.130
Because otherwise,
if I double click on that,

99
00:04:18.130 --> 00:04:22.560
it's gonna run just the same as
if I ran the actual program.

100
00:04:22.560 --> 00:04:24.540
So if I, quit out of that.

101
00:04:25.610 --> 00:04:27.860
If I run the program from here or

102
00:04:27.860 --> 00:04:32.070
if I run it from the desktop,
it runs the same way, okay?

103
00:04:32.070 --> 00:04:33.350
Now so far,

104
00:04:33.350 --> 00:04:37.570
that's not really much different
than a shortcut in other platforms.

105
00:04:37.570 --> 00:04:39.780
So what's so special about this?

106
00:04:39.780 --> 00:04:44.860
Well, in the macOS extended file system,
when you create an alias,

107
00:04:44.860 --> 00:04:49.860
the alias gets linked to the actual
data that is stored for this file.

108
00:04:49.860 --> 00:04:52.780
And Apple tracks that file.

109
00:04:52.780 --> 00:04:56.690
They track all that information to make
sure that they stay linked together.

110
00:04:56.690 --> 00:04:59.660
So I could take this program, and

111

screwed up a preference that doesn't help.

570
00:25:35.200 --> 00:25:36.366
>> I would assume you could also copy

571
00:25:36.366 --> 00:25:39.076
that preference file and take it to
another machine, install the program and

572
00:25:39.076 --> 00:25:40.834
have all your preferences.
>> You could, yeah.

573
00:25:40.834 --> 00:25:44.948
In fact, if you really wanna get
advanced you can use iCloud and sync it,

574
00:25:44.948 --> 00:25:48.260
that way it stays in sync between
the two of your machines.

575
00:25:48.260 --> 00:25:51.785
You can really do some fun stuff with it,
but that's basically the way that you're

576
00:25:51.785 --> 00:25:55.340
gonna see that, those applications,
that bundle file.

577
00:25:55.340 --> 00:25:58.300
It's a special type of file and
it's just a Mac OS thing.

578
00:25:58.300 --> 00:26:02.160
They don't do that in Windows or Linux,
they all their own far more convoluted way

579
00:26:02.160 --> 00:26:03.280
of dealing with it.
>> Well Don,

580
00:26:03.280 --> 00:26:06.260
I know we're running short on time,
but I wanted to ask you this as well.

581
00:26:06.260 --> 00:26:10.440
Is that dot app, that's what
tells me this is an application,

582
00:26:10.440 --> 00:26:13.480
this is something I'm gonna run on
programs, install on the machine,

583
00:26:13.480 --> 00:26:18.350
is that the only type of applications
that we're gonna see in Mac OS?

584
00:26:18.350 --> 00:26:19.070
>> It usually is, but

585
00:26:19.070 --> 00:26:23.120
there are exceptions, for
example, you might have noticed

586
00:26:23.120 --> 00:26:26.300
I'm not using an official Apple keyboard.
>> How dare you, sir.

587
00:26:26.300 --> 00:26:27.890
>> Don't tell Apple.

588
00:26:27.890 --> 00:26:33.035
So anyhow, I'm using a Logitech keyboard,
mostly because I had it.

589
00:26:33.035 --> 00:26:34.615
>> [LAUGH]

590
00:26:34.615 --> 00:26:35.311
>> And when you buy a Mac,

591
00:26:35.311 --> 00:26:37.484
maybe it doesn't come with a keyboard,
so you have to get one anyway.

592
00:26:37.484 --> 00:26:38.915
I had this one.

593
00:26:38.915 --> 00:26:43.441
So, that's why I'm using it, and
I had to plug in a Logitech receiver and

594
00:26:43.441 --> 00:26:45.640
there's a Logitech driver for it.

595
00:26:45.640 --> 00:26:48.920
Now, drivers don't install
in the /applications folder,

596
00:26:48.920 --> 00:26:50.320
drivers are different, right?

597
00:26:50.320 --> 00:26:52.330
Drivers actually modify
part of your system,

598
00:26:52.330 --> 00:26:56.670
they get loaded into special folders
where that stuff is available, and

599
00:26:56.670 --> 00:26:59.780
as a result they can't run
like a normal program.

600
00:26:59.780 --> 00:27:02.750
So they're not sent out as a bundle file,
they're not sent out as something that

601
00:27:02.750 --> 00:27:07.450
ends in .app like what we've seen so far,
instead they're sent out as pkgs, right?

602
00:27:07.450 --> 00:27:09.150
Or package files.

603
00:27:09.150 --> 00:27:10.900
And package files?

604
00:27:10.900 --> 00:27:13.320
Remember all the stuff I
said about Windows and

605
00:27:13.320 --> 00:27:16.740
when you have to run a setup and you have
to click through menus and all that?

606
00:27:16.740 --> 00:27:18.390
That's how package files work.

607
00:27:18.390 --> 00:27:22.060
But it's necessary for a driver,
because it's gonna have to get elevated

608
00:27:22.060 --> 00:27:25.660
privileges, it's gonna have write to these
different directories in different places

609
00:27:25.660 --> 00:27:28.770
and to remove the driver, it's gotta be
able to reach out to the different places.

610
00:27:28.770 --> 00:27:31.860
That's the more traditional model you
see from other operating systems.

611
00:27:31.860 --> 00:27:36.640
But if I go back to my Downloads folder,
I should be able to find, here.

612
00:27:36.640 --> 00:27:39.000
Here's the Logitech
Control Center Installer,

613
00:27:39.000 --> 00:27:43.120
that I needed to install to be able to see
my keyboard, and the Unifying Installer to

614
00:27:43.120 --> 00:27:46.090
power the little dongle that's
the wireless receiver for all this stuff.

615
00:27:46.090 --> 00:27:50.460
So, those are programs, but they're
actually packages and they have the little

616
00:27:50.460 --> 00:27:55.970
package icon, which is different than
what you would normally see on a program.

617
00:27:55.970 --> 00:28:03.080
And if I look at that from the terminal,
and I kind of peek at it in here.

618
00:28:03.080 --> 00:28:07.900
There's that Unifying Installer,
see how Unifying Installer ends in .app?

619
00:28:07.900 --> 00:28:10.320
They actually made it a .app.

620
00:28:10.320 --> 00:28:15.140
And then the Logitech control
center is showing as .app,

621
00:28:15.140 --> 00:28:19.970
but those are actually packages,
they're doing more than what a .app does.

622
00:28:19.970 --> 00:28:23.560
And in fact, if they really wanted,
they could've compressed the files and

623
00:28:23.560 --> 00:28:26.140
then they wouldn't have ended in.app,
they would have ended in .pkg.

624
00:28:26.140 --> 00:28:31.193
Which, let's see, I should have, at least
one of these things should be a pkg.

625
00:28:31.193 --> 00:28:33.020
Actually I've got Adobe Air.

626
00:28:33.020 --> 00:28:36.210
Adobe is great at doing crazy things.
>> [LAUGH]

627
00:28:36.210 --> 00:28:37.870
>> And so it's a dmg,

628
00:28:37.870 --> 00:28:38.980
an image file, right?

629
00:28:38.980 --> 00:28:40.840
So, I download an image file,
I open it up.

630
00:28:40.840 --> 00:28:43.860
And then here's the Adobe Air Installer,
right?

631
00:28:43.860 --> 00:28:45.714
So, if we go and take a look at it.

632
00:28:48.729 --> 00:28:50.936
And shoot, it is a dot app also.
>> Well,

633
00:28:50.936 --> 00:28:51.880
how about that?
>> [LAUGH]

634
00:28:51.880 --> 00:28:53.380
>> Yeah, I know, I will find a pkg.

635
00:28:53.380 --> 00:28:58.820
If you have things like printer drivers or
any kind of hardware driver,

636
00:28:58.820 --> 00:29:02.450
those will always be, I shouldn't say
always, they will usually be a pkg.

637
00:29:02.450 --> 00:29:06.294
If it is a dot app like this, usually
if you browse inside of it, you'll find

638
00:29:06.294 --> 00:29:08.956
where there is a pkg in there somewhere.
>> I suppose

639
00:29:08.956 --> 00:29:12.289
you didn't have one before
the dongle that goes on to

>> Cuz this is a fairly new one, so yeah,

00:29:18.550 --> 00:29:19.780
it hasn't been loaded.

644
00:29:19.780 --> 00:29:23.878
Some of these other ones, let's see.

00:29:23.878 --> 00:29:25.850
>> The other thing is when you run stuff,

00:29:25.850 --> 00:29:29.242
they started with either Sierra or

00:29:29.242 --> 00:29:31.894
where they started saying

00:29:31.894 --> 00:29:34.086

649
00:29:34.086 --> 00:29:34.920
>> You don't need it anymore.

00:29:34.920 --> 00:29:36.040
I usually say yes.

651
00:29:36.040 --> 00:29:39.470
So, I don't have a huge
archive of install files,

00:29:39.470 --> 00:29:42.110

653
00:29:42.110 --> 00:29:44.230

00:29:44.230 --> 00:29:47.100
That usually indicates it's a driver,
you install it,

655
00:29:47.100 --> 00:29:49.520

need it anymore.

00:29:49.520 --> 00:29:51.970
Anything that runs a service

657
00:29:51.970 --> 00:29:57.620
Let me see if, I've got the VNC viewer,

658
00:29:57.620 --> 00:30:00.340
That one would've been a pkg.

659
00:30:00.340 --> 00:30:02.063
Yeah, you'll spot different ones.

660
00:30:02.063 --> 00:30:05.860
Let's see if this Flash Player Installer,

00:30:05.860 --> 00:30:09.010
Probably not, probably gonna regret this.

00:30:09.010 --> 00:30:10.541
>> Way to really go for it though.

663
00:30:10.541 --> 00:30:11.290
>> I know.

664
00:30:11.290 --> 00:30:14.550
>> Will not be deterred.

00:30:14.550 --> 00:30:15.580
>> Shoot, what is that one called?

We'll take a look at this one more,

episodes.description: In this episode, Don takes a look at hidden system folders. Don shows how to view the hidden system folders and emphasizes some of the places in which the folders appear to be redundant. This redundancy is really about the scope of what is effected that is File Domains, according to Don. He also takes the time to point out special folders and what their importance is to the OS.

00:03:20.820 --> 00:03:22.800

a program that's just for

00:03:34.216 --> 00:03:37.365

77
00:03:37.365 --> 00:03:40.670
And now they'll have applications that

78
00:03:40.670 --> 00:03:43.530
That one's not hidden, if you don't

79
00:03:43.530 --> 00:03:45.630
It doesn't exist, and

80
00:03:45.630 --> 00:03:48.796
So sometimes it's not that it's hidden,
it just hasn't been needed yet, all right.

81
00:03:48.796 --> 00:03:52.020
There's another folder in here

82
00:03:52.020 --> 00:03:53.905

00:04:04.114 --> 00:04:05.026
I've never heard of.

00:04:05.026 --> 00:04:08.317
That kind of stuff is a preference

00:04:08.317 --> 00:04:10.160
that's stored in the library.

00:04:10.160 --> 00:04:14.739
If I lost that library, it would

00:04:14.739 --> 00:04:18.101

00:04:18.101 --> 00:04:19.790

00:04:47.194 --> 00:04:48.016

00:04:48.016 --> 00:04:50.218
[LAUGH]

the library folder is there,

00:04:53.446 --> 00:04:54.080

00:27:04.850 --> 00:27:06.750
I can actually just drag and
drop it on this screen, or

571
00:27:06.750 --> 00:27:08.960
I can hit the + up here and add it in.

572
00:27:08.960 --> 00:27:12.495
But if I go into the preferences of this
application, so I go up here to Font Book

573
00:27:12.495 --> 00:27:16.820
> Preferences, in the preferences,
I can pick a default install location.

574
00:27:16.820 --> 00:27:21.000
All right, and here when I drop it down,
see how it just says User and Computer?

575
00:27:22.060 --> 00:27:29.580
What it really should say is
/Users/dpezet/Library/Fonts or

576
00:27:29.580 --> 00:27:32.950
/Library/Fonts, right?

577
00:27:32.950 --> 00:27:37.150
That's effectively what these
two items map to, right?

578
00:27:37.150 --> 00:27:39.950
Is it going to go into the Fonts
folder in my library or

579
00:27:39.950 --> 00:27:42.280
the one globally for everybody?

580
00:27:42.280 --> 00:27:45.530
Right, and it tells you that, but
it's kind of masking that complexity.

581
00:27:45.530 --> 00:27:48.780
Again, a regular end user
wouldn't even know that

582
00:27:48.780 --> 00:27:50.690
there was duplication here, right?

583
00:27:50.690 --> 00:27:53.840
That this is really mapping
to some other folder,

584
00:27:53.840 --> 00:27:56.460
they just see this easy entry, right?

585
00:27:56.460 --> 00:27:59.200
And speaking of duplicates this
one even has the feature to say

586
00:27:59.200 --> 00:28:04.080
if the font already exists globally,
there's no need to add it to a user.

587
00:28:04.080 --> 00:28:06.187
So we can just delete the user's version.

588
00:28:06.187 --> 00:28:08.787
So now we just have one copy, it can
clean that stuff up or it can leave it,

589
00:28:08.787 --> 00:28:11.260
it can leave it where there's two copies,
up to you.

590
00:28:11.260 --> 00:28:14.830
This is an example where they've given
us a tool that makes that decision easy,

591
00:28:14.830 --> 00:28:18.140
without even showing
us those folder names.

592
00:28:18.140 --> 00:28:22.080
>> Well Don, obviously managing files
has quite a bit of complexity to it,

593
00:28:22.080 --> 00:28:25.480
but we've managed to go
through hopefully all of it.

594
00:28:25.480 --> 00:28:29.770
I don't know of any other parts or any
other objectives that we need to cover.

595
00:28:29.770 --> 00:28:31.290
That being said, Don,

596
00:28:31.290 --> 00:28:34.810
is there anything else that we need to
know that comes to mind [INAUDIBLE]?

597
00:28:34.810 --> 00:28:37.760
>> Most of the folders that are hidden,
if they ever do get damaged or whatever,

598
00:28:37.760 --> 00:28:39.640
when you reinstall MacOS, they get fixed.

599
00:28:39.640 --> 00:28:41.040
>> Yeah.
>> So that's the nice part.

600
00:28:41.040 --> 00:28:43.570
If you hide your own stuff,
though, that's up to you, right?

601
00:28:43.570 --> 00:28:44.670
The ball's in your court.

602
00:28:44.670 --> 00:28:47.590
So do be aware, if you start hiding
things, it can mess with things.

603
00:28:47.590 --> 00:28:51.660
Time machine will still back them up even
if they're hidden, so that's good to know.

604
00:28:51.660 --> 00:28:57.010
But otherwise, that's about it for
our main kind of system and core folders.

605
00:28:57.010 --> 00:28:58.630
>> All right, well Don,
thanks for dropping by.

606
00:28:58.630 --> 00:29:01.470
Thanks for explaining how we can
manage files inside of Mac OS.

607
00:29:01.470 --> 00:29:03.060
We do thank you good folks out there for
watching.

608
00:29:03.060 --> 00:29:05.020
Hopefully you got a lot
out of this episode.

609
00:29:05.020 --> 00:29:07.430
But, we are at the time to call it a day.

610
00:29:07.430 --> 00:29:09.590
Thanks for watching yet again,
signing off for ITProTV,

611
00:29:09.590 --> 00:29:11.240
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

612
00:29:11.240 --> 00:29:12.073
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

613
00:29:12.073 --> 00:29:14.309
>> And we will see you next time.

614
00:29:14.309 --> 00:29:20.312
[MUSIC]

615
00:29:20.312 --> 00:29:23.586
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates using ZIP archives to combine and compress files for storage or transport. He then demonstrates creating DMG file images which are commonly used for software distribution.
episodes.title: Archives and Images
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:06.405
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:06.405 --> 00:00:07.870
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:07.870 --> 00:00:12.560
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Hello,

4
00:00:12.560 --> 00:00:16.390
thank you for watching ITProTV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

5
00:00:16.390 --> 00:00:17.520
I'm your host, Zach Memos,

6
00:00:17.520 --> 00:00:21.026
as we continue on with
Apple Certified Support Professional.

7
00:00:21.026 --> 00:00:23.836
Archives and
Images is the title of this episode, and

8
00:00:23.836 --> 00:00:26.280
we're gonna hear all
about it from Don Pezet.

9
00:00:26.280 --> 00:00:28.710
Don, great to have you here.
>> And great to be back, Zach.

10
00:00:28.710 --> 00:00:31.630
And like you said, we're gonna be
looking at archives and images.

11
00:00:31.630 --> 00:00:36.470
If you ever had to transfer multiple
files across the Internet either as like

12
00:00:36.470 --> 00:00:40.820
an email attachment, or upload to
a service like Dropbox or iCloud.

13
00:00:40.820 --> 00:00:44.360
You know that it can be difficult
working with a large quantity of files.

14
00:00:44.360 --> 00:00:47.240
So, the majority of the time,
we'll take those files and

15
00:00:47.240 --> 00:00:49.540
put them into an archive of some sort.

16
00:00:49.540 --> 00:00:53.760
An archive that allows us to compress
the files to make them smaller as well as

17
00:00:53.760 --> 00:00:58.560
bundle them together into a single file,
which is far easier to transmit and

18
00:00:58.560 --> 00:01:00.630
make sure that it gets to
its destination intact.

19
00:01:00.630 --> 00:01:04.020
So, we're gonna look at some of
the ways that you can do that

20
00:01:04.020 --> 00:01:08.050
right from inside of macOS.
>> Well, do we install any software in

21
00:01:08.050 --> 00:01:12.070
order to work with the archives?
>> Well, you certainly can, and

22
00:01:12.070 --> 00:01:15.170
I'll fess up here that I normally do.

23
00:01:15.170 --> 00:01:18.640
I have a little program that I use
on macOS that is called Entropy,

24
00:01:18.640 --> 00:01:23.020
that I like, it is a archive
application that generates,

25
00:01:23.020 --> 00:01:25.540
really any type of archive
that you want to use.

26
00:01:25.540 --> 00:01:29.010
Drag the files and drop it on there,
and it works really well.

27
00:01:29.010 --> 00:01:32.374
Really negative, it hasn't been updated in
a few years, which is disappointing, but

28
00:01:32.374 --> 00:01:33.657
it does a really really good job.

29
00:01:33.657 --> 00:01:38.064
But you don't have to buy anything,
macOS has native support for

30
00:01:38.064 --> 00:01:43.560
a number of archive types, and you can
just do it from right inside of the OS.

31
00:01:43.560 --> 00:01:48.960
For example, the most popular
archive format in the world

32
00:01:48.960 --> 00:01:51.400
is the zip archive.
>> Mm-hm.

33
00:01:51.400 --> 00:01:54.260
>> Zip was a container type format

34
00:01:54.260 --> 00:01:59.180
that was developed back in the late 1980s,
early 1990s by a company called PKWare.

35
00:01:59.180 --> 00:02:02.270
And it had just kind of
became the de facto standard.

36
00:02:02.270 --> 00:02:05.380
So, most of the content that
you get from the Internet.

37
00:02:05.380 --> 00:02:09.550
If it's compressed we'll be using
a variation of the zip format, and

38
00:02:09.550 --> 00:02:14.760
macOS has support for zips built right in,
we can actually just jump right in there,

39
00:02:14.760 --> 00:02:18.390
and you can open up zip files,
or whatever.

40
00:02:18.390 --> 00:02:19.870
And it works just fine.

41
00:02:19.870 --> 00:02:21.340
In fact, if I go to my Download folder,

42
00:02:21.340 --> 00:02:25.350
I'm sure I downloaded at
least one zip file here.

43
00:02:25.350 --> 00:02:27.770
So, I've got this Mini-Config
utility right here,

44
00:02:27.770 --> 00:02:31.350
where I downloaded from a website and
it downloaded as a zip.

45
00:02:31.350 --> 00:02:36.090
I'm gonna just take that and
move that to my desktop here.

46
00:02:36.090 --> 00:02:42.080
All right, so on my desktop I see that
mini config file and it shows up as a zip.

47
00:02:42.080 --> 00:02:43.640
The icon is showing as a zip.

48
00:02:43.640 --> 00:02:45.280
There's no quick look for
this or anything,

49
00:02:45.280 --> 00:02:48.060
it just let's me know
that it is a zip archive.

50
00:02:48.060 --> 00:02:51.350
And if I double click on that file,

51
00:02:52.490 --> 00:02:56.400
I saw a quick little bar up here
with a line that went across it and

52
00:02:56.400 --> 00:03:02.480
all a sudden I've got a folder with
the same name as that zip file.

53
00:03:02.480 --> 00:03:06.240
And if I browse into that folder,
there's the file contents.

54
00:03:06.240 --> 00:03:11.510
There's the AJ mini config utility and
the PDF and some documentation.

55
00:03:11.510 --> 00:03:15.180
There's the format and
the files that I need.

56
00:03:15.180 --> 00:03:19.480
So, if somebody sends me a zip,
I can open it right inside of macOS and

57
00:03:19.480 --> 00:03:21.690
I don't need third party software at all.

58
00:03:21.690 --> 00:03:25.245
It's handled right here natively.
>> How would we create our own

59
00:03:25.245 --> 00:03:28.100
zip archive if we wanted to do that?
>> Sure, so

60
00:03:28.100 --> 00:03:31.380
in this case, I got a zip from
somebody else, it was already made.

61
00:03:31.380 --> 00:03:32.400
So, what did I do?

62
00:03:32.400 --> 00:03:33.900
Double-clicked, that's easy.
>> Mm-hm.

63
00:03:33.900 --> 00:03:35.080
>> But what if I wanna send

64
00:03:35.080 --> 00:03:35.980
something to somebody else?

65
00:03:35.980 --> 00:03:39.450
So, Zach, I wanna send him some e-books.

66
00:03:39.450 --> 00:03:42.030
And so, in this folder over here,
I've got three e-books.

67
00:03:42.030 --> 00:03:44.350
And I wanna send these over to Zach.

68
00:03:44.350 --> 00:03:45.830
Well, it's three different files.

69
00:03:45.830 --> 00:03:47.460
And so, if I go into my email client,

70
00:03:47.460 --> 00:03:51.310
I'll have to add it as three different
attachments and send them along.

71
00:03:51.310 --> 00:03:52.936
Wouldn't it be nice to stick them all

72
00:03:52.936 --> 00:03:53.630
together?
>> Yeah.

73
00:03:53.630 --> 00:03:56.370
>> And individually, they are,

74
00:03:56.370 --> 00:03:57.830
let's see how big these things are.

75
00:03:57.830 --> 00:04:01.560
We've got 11 and a half megs, 15 and
a half megs, 9 and a half megs.

76
00:04:01.560 --> 00:04:05.675
So, we'll see how quick my math can be,
17, 26 and a half megs.

77
00:04:05.675 --> 00:04:08.660
26 and a half megs in size.

78
00:04:08.660 --> 00:04:11.980
Well, if I can bundle them together and
compress them,

79
00:04:11.980 --> 00:04:16.700
which a zip can do, it can make them
smaller and easier to transmit.

80
00:04:16.700 --> 00:04:20.290
So, if I highlight all three of those, so

81
00:04:20.290 --> 00:04:24.890
I've highlighted the files that I want
to compress, I can two finger tap,

82
00:04:24.890 --> 00:04:28.990
or Ctrl-click, or whichever way you bring
up the context menu on your Mac, and

83
00:04:28.990 --> 00:04:31.840
you'll see this option right here,
Compress 3 items.

84
00:04:33.070 --> 00:04:38.450
And when I choose Compress 3 items,
it's going to build a zip for me.

85
00:04:38.450 --> 00:04:41.520
And that zip file is going to contain each

86
00:04:41.520 --> 00:04:44.350
of the files that were compressed,
all right?

87
00:04:44.350 --> 00:04:46.510
It's gonna be stucked right
inside of that archive,

88
00:04:46.510 --> 00:04:51.670
that zip now called the archive.zip,
I might want to rename that to Ebooks.zip.

89
00:04:51.670 --> 00:04:53.680
There's that zip file, right?

90
00:04:53.680 --> 00:04:57.200
Now, the reason I did that math
a moment ago is I wanted to highlight

91
00:04:57.200 --> 00:04:58.240
something here.

92
00:04:58.240 --> 00:05:01.570
These PDF files are already compressed.

93
00:05:01.570 --> 00:05:03.970
Like the Adobe format tries to
compress these things down, and

94
00:05:03.970 --> 00:05:05.020
there's images inside there.

95
00:05:05.020 --> 00:05:06.690
The image is already compressed.

96
00:05:06.690 --> 00:05:11.000
When you try and compress something
that's already compressed

97
00:05:11.000 --> 00:05:13.430
sometimes it gets bigger,
and that's what happened.

98
00:05:13.430 --> 00:05:18.340
If I added up these three files,
it added up to, what did I say?

99
00:05:18.340 --> 00:05:19.510
Actually, you know what, no.

100
00:05:19.510 --> 00:05:21.706
I did bad math a minute ago.
>> [LAUGH]

101
00:05:21.706 --> 00:05:22.716
>> I said 26 and a half,

102
00:05:22.716 --> 00:05:24.631
it's actually 36 and a half megabytes,

103
00:05:24.631 --> 00:05:26.655
is what it was.
>> I know that's what you meant.

104
00:05:26.655 --> 00:05:27.600
[LAUGH]
>> And now,

105
00:05:27.600 --> 00:05:29.870
it's down to 32.7,
it actually got smaller.

106
00:05:29.870 --> 00:05:32.280
So, I guess, the PDFs weren't compressed.

107
00:05:32.280 --> 00:05:34.380
So, it got smaller.

108
00:05:34.380 --> 00:05:36.006
My math skills also got smaller.
>> [LAUGH]

109
00:05:36.006 --> 00:05:38.590
>> [LAUGH] So, it did get smaller, and

110
00:05:38.590 --> 00:05:39.780
now it is all combined.

111
00:05:39.780 --> 00:05:42.240
But what I was saying is absolutely true.

112
00:05:42.240 --> 00:05:44.630
If you have JPEGs.
>> Mm-hm.

113
00:05:44.630 --> 00:05:46.260
>> JPEG image files,

114
00:05:46.260 --> 00:05:47.550
they're already compressed.

115
00:05:47.550 --> 00:05:49.520
And they will often times get bigger.

116
00:05:49.520 --> 00:05:53.550
MP4 files, AVI files, most video files.

117
00:05:53.550 --> 00:05:55.765
If you compress them,
they'll actually get bigger.

118
00:05:55.765 --> 00:05:59.111
Cuz they're already as compressed as
they can get without losing data.

119
00:05:59.111 --> 00:06:03.660
So, it's not always a great
idea to try and compress down.

120
00:06:03.660 --> 00:06:08.350
But once they're put together like this,
I can send Zach just this one file.

121
00:06:08.350 --> 00:06:09.980
He gets it,
all he has to do is double click on it.

122
00:06:09.980 --> 00:06:13.850
And then, he'll have these three books
that he can go in, open up, start reading,

123
00:06:13.850 --> 00:06:15.430
and have a great time.

124
00:06:15.430 --> 00:06:17.260
So, super easy to come in and

125
00:06:17.260 --> 00:06:20.050
create that archive ourselves.
>> Now, are there archive

126
00:06:20.050 --> 00:06:22.830
types we should be aware of?
>> There are, absolutely.

127
00:06:22.830 --> 00:06:27.160
And I mentioned if we have compressed
data, we don't necessarily want to

128
00:06:27.160 --> 00:06:32.450
compress it again,
that can be a problem with ZIP format.

129
00:06:32.450 --> 00:06:36.693
If I do it here inside of macOS,
it's automatically going to compress.

130
00:06:36.693 --> 00:06:38.650
If I use third-party software,
I can disable that.

131
00:06:38.650 --> 00:06:41.230
I could say, put it in zip,
but don't compress.

132
00:06:41.230 --> 00:06:42.920
And that can help, right?

133
00:06:42.920 --> 00:06:46.030
But inside of macOS, there's actually
another type of archive format that's

134
00:06:46.030 --> 00:06:48.800
really popular that
doesn't do compression.

135
00:06:48.800 --> 00:06:53.210
And that's called a disk image,
or a DMG, right?

136
00:06:53.210 --> 00:06:54.900
When you download software for

137
00:06:54.900 --> 00:07:00.540
a Mac, nine times out of ten it's not
gonna be a zip, it's going to be a DMG.

138
00:07:00.540 --> 00:07:04.170
I've got one here on my desktop for
Viscosity.

139
00:07:04.170 --> 00:07:06.930
Viscosity is a VPN client that I use.

140
00:07:06.930 --> 00:07:10.534
And if you go to their website and
download it, you'll download a dmg file.

141
00:07:10.534 --> 00:07:13.544
That AJA Mini-Config that
I downloaded was a zip,

142
00:07:13.544 --> 00:07:16.350
did you notice the files
when I extracted them?

143
00:07:16.350 --> 00:07:18.110
Where is that, here.

144
00:07:18.110 --> 00:07:19.991
When I extracted them,
what was inside of it?

145
00:07:19.991 --> 00:07:22.571
The PDF help documentation, and

146
00:07:22.571 --> 00:07:24.967
AJA_MiniConfig.dmg.
>> Yeah.

147
00:07:24.967 --> 00:07:26.969
>> The put a dmg inside of the zip,

148
00:07:26.969 --> 00:07:28.740
which is super redundant.

149
00:07:28.740 --> 00:07:31.690
They could have easily put
these other files in the dmg.

150
00:07:31.690 --> 00:07:33.690
There's a reason why they didn't,
I'll show you in a moment.

151
00:07:33.690 --> 00:07:37.457
But those dmg files those are disc images.

152
00:07:37.457 --> 00:07:42.245
And it's not a compressed archive,
like a ZIP would be, it's an archive

153
00:07:42.245 --> 00:07:47.050
that's supposed to be a mirror of
a disc that was created somewhere else.

154
00:07:47.050 --> 00:07:51.200
And the way that is used to be used was,
if I was a software vendor and

155
00:07:51.200 --> 00:07:55.500
I was selling CDs, or DVDs, I could
create a disk image of that DVD and

156
00:07:55.500 --> 00:08:00.201
that disk image will be a dmg file, and
I can distribute that out to people.

157
00:08:00.201 --> 00:08:02.920
And they would see it as a DMG.

158
00:08:02.920 --> 00:08:09.440
And if they double-click on it,
it will pop up and do something.

159
00:08:09.440 --> 00:08:13.080
Now, this one pops up and
starts to install software.

160
00:08:13.080 --> 00:08:17.210
But other ones will actually pop up and
show me the contents that are inside it.

161
00:08:17.210 --> 00:08:20.190
They have the ability to do other things,

162
00:08:20.190 --> 00:08:22.520
unlike a zip where it just
extracts it on the disk.

163
00:08:22.520 --> 00:08:23.710
Here, we can do more.

164
00:08:23.710 --> 00:08:28.823
So the DMG format is actually really built
around this idea of distributing software.

165
00:08:28.823 --> 00:08:30.979
But you can put anything in a DMG.

166
00:08:30.979 --> 00:08:33.767
And it is a common format that
you are going to encounter.

167
00:08:33.767 --> 00:08:37.990
Are they opened the same way as zip files?
>> So they're different, right?

168
00:08:37.990 --> 00:08:39.300
I mean, we double-click, right?

169
00:08:39.300 --> 00:08:41.530
That's what I just did,
and we double-click a zip.

170
00:08:41.530 --> 00:08:47.370
But where it's different is with a zip,
the system knows it's just an archive,

171
00:08:47.370 --> 00:08:50.030
and it just takes the files out of it,
and that's the end of it, right?

172
00:08:50.030 --> 00:08:53.300
But with a DMG,
the system doesn't really know what it is.

173
00:08:53.300 --> 00:08:56.340
It knows that it's a disk image, but
it doesn't know what's on the disk.

174
00:08:56.340 --> 00:08:58.520
And so,
what will happen with a lot of them, and

175
00:08:58.520 --> 00:09:01.950
let me just cancel this,
and get out of this one.

176
00:09:01.950 --> 00:09:06.908
What happens with a lot of them is that
when you double-click on them it treats it

177
00:09:06.908 --> 00:09:08.095
like a hard drive.

178
00:09:08.095 --> 00:09:12.892

00:20:54.210 --> 00:20:57.330
With a virtual disk like that, there's not
really a whole lot of point for it, but

404
00:20:57.330 --> 00:20:58.500
if you want, you can go crazy.

405
00:20:58.500 --> 00:21:01.980
It will let you do it and, yeah,
you can have fun with that.

406
00:21:01.980 --> 00:21:04.180
Again, most of the time we're
just gonna stick with one,

407
00:21:04.180 --> 00:21:08.120
but this last one is the important
one I wanna show you.

408
00:21:08.120 --> 00:21:10.340
It's gonna create a read,
write, disk image,

409
00:21:10.340 --> 00:21:13.220
by default, cuz a disk would
normally be read and write.

410
00:21:13.220 --> 00:21:17.685
But if I expand that out, I see something
very different than what we saw before.

411
00:21:17.685 --> 00:21:23.310
DVD/CD Master, I guess we saw that one,
but I'm not seeing some of the other ones,

412
00:21:23.310 --> 00:21:26.300
like the hybrid system, or
read-only, or compressed.

413
00:21:26.300 --> 00:21:31.100
Those go away, and they've been
replaced by sparse disk image and

414
00:21:31.100 --> 00:21:32.390
sparse bundle disk image.

415
00:21:33.840 --> 00:21:34.860
What are those?

416
00:21:36.110 --> 00:21:41.388
A sparse disk image says even though
you said the size was a 100 MB,

417
00:21:41.388 --> 00:21:47.020
if you put 20 MB in there,
the file will only be 20 megs in size.

418
00:21:47.020 --> 00:21:48.840
By doing this sparse image,

419
00:21:48.840 --> 00:21:53.720
you're saying that it won't take up
any more space than is necessary.

420
00:21:53.720 --> 00:21:57.460
Empty space won't actually
consume actual space.

421
00:21:57.460 --> 00:22:00.740
So we normally want a sparse disk image.

422
00:22:00.740 --> 00:22:04.420
Very very few people are doing a full one.

423
00:22:04.420 --> 00:22:08.120
There is reasons for it, but for
most of us, it's not gonna be useful.

424
00:22:08.120 --> 00:22:10.170
So that's particularly what we want.

425
00:22:10.170 --> 00:22:14.280
The difference between sparse bundle disk
images and sparse disk image, originally

426
00:22:14.280 --> 00:22:18.590
Apple envisioned the sparse disk image
was used for actual disk storage, and

427
00:22:18.590 --> 00:22:22.210
the sparse bundle disk image was used for
distributing software.

428
00:22:22.210 --> 00:22:26.590
Applications are bundles, and so we're
bundling those together and moving along.

429
00:22:26.590 --> 00:22:31.730
In today's world, very, very few
people are using them as actual disks.

430
00:22:31.730 --> 00:22:34.970
With the actual disks,
this is where read write comes in handy.

431
00:22:36.250 --> 00:22:41.460
If you have it where you're writing into
one of these DMGs, every time it grows,

432
00:22:41.460 --> 00:22:45.320
the next spot on the physical disk might
already be full with somebody else's data,

433
00:22:45.320 --> 00:22:46.890
or some other program's data.

434
00:22:46.890 --> 00:22:50.130
So it might have to break the file
up on the hard drive to fit it.

435
00:22:50.130 --> 00:22:53.210
That creates fragmentation,
that hurts performance.

436
00:22:53.210 --> 00:22:55.780
Now if it's just an archive,
we don't care about performance.

437
00:22:55.780 --> 00:22:59.350
But if I'm actually using this disk
to store a database or a file,

438
00:22:59.350 --> 00:23:00.250
like a FileMaker Pro database, or

439
00:23:00.250 --> 00:23:03.730
something like that,
it will make that database run slow.

440
00:23:03.730 --> 00:23:06.340
If I choose to keep it all together,

441
00:23:06.340 --> 00:23:09.690
it makes one big file right
now that never grows.

442
00:23:09.690 --> 00:23:13.570
And it gets all the space, all in order,
fragmentation's not a problem.

443
00:23:13.570 --> 00:23:15.590
You get great performance out of it.

444
00:23:15.590 --> 00:23:18.610
But that's really an old way
of using this thing, and

445
00:23:18.610 --> 00:23:20.580
very very few people do that today.

446
00:23:20.580 --> 00:23:23.995
So for most of us, we'll just go
with a sparse bundle disc image.

447
00:23:23.995 --> 00:23:27.490
And the moment I do that, see how it
changed my file extension up there to be

448
00:23:27.490 --> 00:23:29.320
sparsebundle?
>> Mm-hm.

449
00:23:29.320 --> 00:23:32.390
>> You can leave it that way, but

450
00:23:32.390 --> 00:23:37.480
almost every person on the planet just
takes that and says, you know what,

451
00:23:37.480 --> 00:23:41.420
I'm just gonna rename that dmg because
people don't know what sparse bundles are,

452
00:23:41.420 --> 00:23:42.800
and that's what they do.

453
00:23:42.800 --> 00:23:48.620
And so when I ran that viscosity DMG,
well, that was a sparse bundle.

454
00:23:48.620 --> 00:23:51.350
It was the exact size of
the data inside of it,

455
00:23:51.350 --> 00:23:55.000
but they just renamed it dmg
cuz they're all disk images.

456
00:23:55.000 --> 00:23:56.500
And it's shorter, right?

457
00:23:56.500 --> 00:23:57.487
The sparse bundle's kinda long.

458
00:23:57.487 --> 00:23:59.555
So we can set that, and we can save it.

459
00:23:59.555 --> 00:24:04.592
And now instead of creating a file
that's 100 MB, When I save that,

460
00:24:04.592 --> 00:24:08.625
it's gonna warn me,
it's warning me about the extension.

461
00:24:08.625 --> 00:24:10.315
I'll go ahead and
let it use the sparse bundle,

462
00:24:10.315 --> 00:24:12.330
we can just rename it after it's made.

463
00:24:12.330 --> 00:24:19.626
Once it's made, we'll find, way down here,
dons-ebooks-v12.1-sparsebundle.

464
00:24:19.626 --> 00:24:22.360
Now we can rename it, and
it'll be happy again.

465
00:24:22.360 --> 00:24:24.628
So I'll just rename that.

466
00:24:24.628 --> 00:24:28.570
And once I do,
it still shows up as a disk image.

467
00:24:28.570 --> 00:24:31.786
And I can double-click on it and
it's gonna mount it.

468
00:24:31.786 --> 00:24:38.440
And so I can see the file was
called don's-ebooks-v12.1.dmg.

469
00:24:38.440 --> 00:24:42.073
Up here, I can see that it's
just called Don's eBooks.

470
00:24:42.073 --> 00:24:43.986
You remember I gave it the alternate name.

471
00:24:43.986 --> 00:24:48.182
And if I look at the file data on that,

472
00:24:50.791 --> 00:24:54.670
Hang on, let me get that,
I'll do a little command i here.

473
00:24:54.670 --> 00:24:57.515
The file right now is 20 megabyte.

474
00:24:57.515 --> 00:25:01.450
Now it's empty, and I said it wasn't
gonna make empty space take up space.

475
00:25:01.450 --> 00:25:03.066
Well, there's a minimum.

476
00:25:03.066 --> 00:25:05.340
The minimum is 20 megabytes.

477
00:25:05.340 --> 00:25:08.024
It has to have some overhead
just to store the file system.

478
00:25:08.024 --> 00:25:10.485
It's formatted macOS Extended Journaled.

479
00:25:10.485 --> 00:25:14.554
macOS Extended Journaled needs at least
20 megabytes to store its file table.

480
00:25:14.554 --> 00:25:16.590
So it's gonna be at least that size.

481
00:25:16.590 --> 00:25:19.738
But once I start chucking some data into
it, we'll see some interesting things.

482
00:25:19.738 --> 00:25:26.290
So if I take Don's eBooks and open it up,
and then I take my PDFs that I had.

483
00:25:26.290 --> 00:25:31.405
And we'll just drag those in there and
throw them in.

484
00:25:31.405 --> 00:25:33.760
Oops, I only grabbed one,
let me try that again.

485
00:25:33.760 --> 00:25:36.338
I'll grab a few more.

486
00:25:36.338 --> 00:25:38.835
I'm having the hardest time with drag and
drop today,

487
00:25:38.835 --> 00:25:39.788
>> [LAUGH]

488
00:25:39.788 --> 00:25:42.177
>> That concept is apparently beyond me.

489
00:25:42.177 --> 00:25:45.910
And then I'm gonna paste
it in the wrong place.

490
00:25:47.140 --> 00:25:49.376
There we go, so we can paste those in.

491
00:25:49.376 --> 00:25:54.119
As I do that, the disk image is
effectively growing to encompass these,

492
00:25:54.119 --> 00:25:56.940
now I'm more than 20 megabytes in size.

493
00:25:56.940 --> 00:25:59.470
It's growing and adding onto it.

494
00:25:59.470 --> 00:26:03.031
And now I can take that and
distribute it out to people as a disk.

495
00:26:03.031 --> 00:26:04.767
I'll need to eject it when I'm done,

496
00:26:04.767 --> 00:26:08.280
which I'm actually creating
a really big mess here, whoops.

497
00:26:08.280 --> 00:26:12.310
So I'll take these and
we can just eject them.

498
00:26:12.310 --> 00:26:16.098
And when we do that,
that data is now in the dmg.

499
00:26:16.098 --> 00:26:18.436
I can go and distribute that out,
and off we go.

500
00:26:18.436 --> 00:26:21.177
It's far easier to make
the dmg from the folder.

501
00:26:21.177 --> 00:26:25.616
But the reason I wanted to show you that
was because, if you create an empty one,

502
00:26:25.616 --> 00:26:29.923
and you pick that file size and you don't
tell it you wanna do a sparse bundle,

503
00:26:29.923 --> 00:26:32.657
the file will be as big as
the size you designate.

504
00:26:32.657 --> 00:26:34.142
So definitely something
to keep an eye out for.

505
00:26:34.142 --> 00:26:36.408
>> Fantastic episode as usual, Don.

506
00:26:36.408 --> 00:26:37.383
Well done, sir.

507
00:26:37.383 --> 00:26:41.798
Archives and images, and
I know you have something else you'd

508
00:26:41.798 --> 00:26:44.420
like to say.
>> Key thing here, I kind of already

509
00:26:44.420 --> 00:26:47.864
mentioned my main caveat, which is,
you'll probably wanna stick with

510
00:26:47.864 --> 00:26:51.486
the macOS extended file system just to
get the most compatibility out of it.

511
00:26:51.486 --> 00:26:55.420
The other thing is DMGs
can be far more advanced.

512
00:26:55.420 --> 00:26:59.423
The AJA one that I opened up a moment ago,
it auto launched the installer.

513
00:26:59.423 --> 00:27:00.940
Not many developers do that.

514
00:27:00.940 --> 00:27:03.400
But you can, it does have that capability.

515
00:27:03.400 --> 00:27:04.474
And that's just, again,

516
00:27:04.474 --> 00:27:07.570
more extended functionality that's
tucked away in the background of those.

517
00:27:07.570 --> 00:27:09.683
So if you go to the Apple developer
website they have all that documented.

518
00:27:09.683 --> 00:27:10.830
I don't know how to do it.

519
00:27:10.830 --> 00:27:13.781
If you're just trying to distribute files
though, you've seen how to do that.

520
00:27:13.781 --> 00:27:14.979
You can chuck them in there.

521
00:27:14.979 --> 00:27:17.180
I'll be honest with you,
I normally just do zips.

522
00:27:17.180 --> 00:27:18.866
And throw them in there.

523
00:27:18.866 --> 00:27:23.524
If you have other archive formats,
like RARs,

524
00:27:23.524 --> 00:27:27.371
7Zip, things like that, GZip even.

525
00:27:27.371 --> 00:27:30.200
macOS doesn't have data support for those.

526
00:27:30.200 --> 00:27:32.283
And there's always third
party applications,

527
00:27:32.283 --> 00:27:34.833
like the Entropy application that I use or
other programs.

528
00:27:34.833 --> 00:27:37.225
And you can use them to
manage the archives as well.

529
00:27:37.225 --> 00:27:39.155
>> Apple certified support professionals,

530
00:27:39.155 --> 00:27:40.124
a fantastic series.

531
00:27:40.124 --> 00:27:42.455
Make sure you watch all the episodes.

532
00:27:42.455 --> 00:27:46.077
Don's worked very hard and done such a

533
00:27:46.077 --> 00:27:48.550
And you're gonna be in

00:27:48.550 --> 00:27:52.037
And while you're there there's thousands

00:27:52.037 --> 00:27:53.659
go further, so check those out too.

And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

ITProTV is binge worthy.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the function and use of Time Machine as the macOS built-in backup solution. He shows you how to set up Time Machine to take backups, configuration settings to fine tune with, and restoring in the event of a failure.
episodes.title: Time Machine
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.387
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.387 --> 00:00:02.791
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.791 --> 00:00:06.852
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.852 --> 00:00:08.257
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.257 --> 00:00:13.157
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Hello, and thank you for

6
00:00:13.157 --> 00:00:16.180
choosing ITProTV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.180 --> 00:00:17.310
I'm your host, Zach Memos.

8
00:00:17.310 --> 00:00:23.150
In this episode of Apple Certified
Support Professional Time Machine,

9
00:00:23.150 --> 00:00:24.590
what's with a Time Machine?

10
00:00:24.590 --> 00:00:26.310
How do we use a Time Machine?

11
00:00:26.310 --> 00:00:28.350
Well, Don Pezet is here
to tell us about that.

12
00:00:28.350 --> 00:00:30.560
Don, great to have you.
>> Hey, thanks for having me, Zach.

13
00:00:30.560 --> 00:00:33.107
And I'm just trying to figure
out how we're gonna do this

14
00:00:33.107 --> 00:00:36.249
episode without the wavy line effect
that you need in pretty much any-

15
00:00:36.249 --> 00:00:38.883
>> [LAUGH] [SOUND]

16
00:00:38.883 --> 00:00:39.559
>> All right,

17
00:00:39.559 --> 00:00:43.275
in this episode we are gonna be
talking about Time Machine which is

18
00:00:43.275 --> 00:00:46.490
the backup solution provided
by Apple as part of macOS.

19
00:00:46.490 --> 00:00:51.981
And Ill go on record as saying this, that
Time Machine is probably one of the most

20
00:00:51.981 --> 00:00:56.929
reliable and easy to use backup
solutions found on any operating system.

21
00:00:56.929 --> 00:01:01.520
I mean, Apple nailed it with this,
it is so easy to back up and

22
00:01:01.520 --> 00:01:04.600
restore your data, if we do it, right?

23
00:01:04.600 --> 00:01:08.670
That's kinda the key secret here, is that
Time Machine is not enabled by default.

24
00:01:08.670 --> 00:01:11.680
It's not running and backing your stuff
up, you have to know to turn it on.

25
00:01:11.680 --> 00:01:13.960
And so in this episode we're gonna
talk about what's involved with that,

26
00:01:13.960 --> 00:01:17.300
how we get it turned on,
the considerations we have.

27
00:01:17.300 --> 00:01:20.824
And the consideration we have beyond just
a home user, but what a business needs to

28
00:01:20.824 --> 00:01:23.700
be thinking about with Time Machine and
how that data is backed up.

29
00:01:23.700 --> 00:01:26.566
And how we can make sure that
if we ever get into trouble and

30
00:01:26.566 --> 00:01:29.554
we're missing our data,
that we'll be able to recover and

31
00:01:29.554 --> 00:01:32.560
get right back to where we need
to be as quickly as possible.

32
00:01:32.560 --> 00:01:34.790
So that's all coming up
right here in this episode.

33
00:01:34.790 --> 00:01:35.387
>> So then,

34
00:01:35.387 --> 00:01:38.966
how does Time Machine work?
>> So Zach, the way a Time Machine works

35
00:01:38.966 --> 00:01:44.240
is actually really neat because it
seems extremely easy to the end user.

36
00:01:44.240 --> 00:01:47.000
In fact, most of them just turn it on and
forget they even have it,

37
00:01:47.000 --> 00:01:49.680
but in the background,
it's actually pretty complex.

38
00:01:49.680 --> 00:01:54.180
Because what it's gonna do is it's gonna
grab a backup of all of your data,

39
00:01:54.180 --> 00:01:56.190
your entire disk.

40
00:01:56.190 --> 00:01:59.160
And if you've got a one terabyte drive or
something, there's a pretty big chunk of

41
00:01:59.160 --> 00:02:01.474
data it's gotta back up.
>> Yeah.

42
00:02:01.474 --> 00:02:03.163
>> Well, if it had to do that backup

43
00:02:03.163 --> 00:02:08.020
every single day, that's a huge amount
of data that's having to be backed up.

44
00:02:08.020 --> 00:02:10.540
So what they did with Time Machine
is they set it up to where

45
00:02:10.540 --> 00:02:11.890
it would take all of your data.

46
00:02:11.890 --> 00:02:15.470
And the very first time it runs, yes,
it backs up your entire set of data,

47
00:02:15.470 --> 00:02:18.000
and that first backup
could take hours to run.

48
00:02:19.080 --> 00:02:25.290
But once it's done, from then on
it only backs up what changed.

49
00:02:25.290 --> 00:02:27.270
It doesn't back up everything.

50
00:02:27.270 --> 00:02:31.160
If something hasn't changed, it's already
got a backup of it, it's already there.

51
00:02:31.160 --> 00:02:34.410
So now it's just backing
the changes which are much smaller.

52
00:02:34.410 --> 00:02:37.470
Now it will back up by
default once an hour.

53
00:02:37.470 --> 00:02:38.910
So it's running every hour.

54
00:02:38.910 --> 00:02:40.650
You'll have 24 backups a day.

55
00:02:40.650 --> 00:02:41.904
That sounds like a lot of backups.
>> Yeah.

56
00:02:41.904 --> 00:02:42.897
>> We're gonna run out of space.

57
00:02:42.897 --> 00:02:46.490
But how much can you change in an hour?

58
00:02:47.570 --> 00:02:48.610
I can only do so much work.

59
00:02:48.610 --> 00:02:51.770
I can only modify couple of documents,
send some emails,

60
00:02:51.770 --> 00:02:53.880
whatever it is that happens in an hour.

61
00:02:53.880 --> 00:02:55.670
And that's all it has to backup.

62
00:02:55.670 --> 00:02:57.290
And it does that over and over and

63
00:02:57.290 --> 00:03:01.160
over throughout the day,
all without us interacting with it.

64
00:03:01.160 --> 00:03:04.880
All we have to do is plug in a disc and
tell it, hey, this disc is available for

65
00:03:04.880 --> 00:03:05.970
Time Machine.

66
00:03:05.970 --> 00:03:07.100
And then Time Machine will use it.

67
00:03:07.100 --> 00:03:08.840
And that's it,
that's the last we interact with it.

68
00:03:08.840 --> 00:03:12.500
And now it's doing those backups and
we can come in there and restore.

69
00:03:12.500 --> 00:03:16.920
By backing up every hour,
it really creates a safety net for us.

70
00:03:16.920 --> 00:03:20.900
A lot of backup systems out there will
back up the entire set of data, right?

71
00:03:20.900 --> 00:03:23.450
And as a result,
there's a big chunk of data.

72
00:03:23.450 --> 00:03:26.080
So they've gotta do it
during a maintenance window,

73
00:03:26.080 --> 00:03:27.130
usually like in the middle of the night.

74
00:03:27.130 --> 00:03:31.240
You'll hear people say my computer
is set to back up every day at 3 AM.

75
00:03:31.240 --> 00:03:32.670
All right, well, that's fine,
that makes sense.

76
00:03:32.670 --> 00:03:35.520
If you're backing up a large chunk of data
you want it to happen at night when you're

77
00:03:35.520 --> 00:03:38.420
not using the computer so
it has full access to resources and

78
00:03:38.420 --> 00:03:39.840
it goes in and backs up.

79
00:03:39.840 --> 00:03:43.590
Even if it's just backing up changes,
you've got 24 hours of changes, so

80
00:03:43.590 --> 00:03:46.907
that can be a pretty big chunk,
and it's gotta back it up at 3 AM.

81
00:03:46.907 --> 00:03:51.240
The problem there is if I'm
using my computer, or maybe not,

82
00:03:51.240 --> 00:03:52.370
it's just sitting there.

83
00:03:52.370 --> 00:03:57.268
And at 2 AM, it explodes, catches on fire,
whatever, I lose my data, right?

84
00:03:57.268 --> 00:04:00.680
Well, a backup was scheduled for 3 AM.

85
00:04:00.680 --> 00:04:01.760
It hasn't backed up yet.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don takes a look at installing applications. He demonstrates how to install an application from the App Store and from a non-App Store source. He also takes a look at how features like Gatekeeper and Mission Control interact with apps.
