00:29:12.080 --> 00:29:14.660
I can add more widgets, all right.

567
00:29:14.660 --> 00:29:17.792
These are all the official
Apple supported widgets.

568
00:29:17.792 --> 00:29:18.750
>> Mm-hm.

569
00:29:18.750 --> 00:29:20.760
>> But there's companies that
make third-party widgets.

570
00:29:20.760 --> 00:29:24.400
You can install all sorts of crazy things
here to run as a Dashboard widget, and

571
00:29:24.400 --> 00:29:25.270
they do run.

572
00:29:25.270 --> 00:29:28.130
They are programs, they're applications.

573
00:29:28.130 --> 00:29:31.380
So you might have instances,
where you've installed an application, and

574
00:29:31.380 --> 00:29:32.600
you don't see an icon for it.

575
00:29:32.600 --> 00:29:35.310
You don't see the program in
the applications folder and

576
00:29:35.310 --> 00:29:37.360
it actually turns out to
be a Dashboard widget.

577
00:29:37.360 --> 00:29:39.997
>> Mm-hm.
>> So I wanted to highlight that, again,

578
00:29:39.997 --> 00:29:44.928
not the most common thing on the planet,
not, I don't think a ton of people use

579
00:29:44.928 --> 00:29:48.450
this stuff
>> But I can throw in the movie widget,

580
00:29:48.450 --> 00:29:53.000
now I can see all these great
movies which is often a tangent but

581
00:29:53.000 --> 00:29:54.752
I'm almost done reading
the annihilation book.

582
00:29:54.752 --> 00:29:56.833
>> [LAUGH]
>> It is terrible.

583
00:29:56.833 --> 00:29:58.820
Any how, so [LAUGH]
>> But

584
00:29:58.820 --> 00:30:01.170
you're going to finish it aren't you?

585
00:30:01.170 --> 00:30:02.570
You've got to finish it.

586
00:30:02.570 --> 00:30:04.743
>> Yeah, I only got like 50 pages,
I've got to stick it through.

587
00:30:04.743 --> 00:30:06.278
>> [LAUGH]
>> But it's tough,

588
00:30:06.278 --> 00:30:10.130
[COUGH] So that's what the dashboard
can do, those are applications.

589
00:30:10.130 --> 00:30:13.020
I personally don't use that feature, so
I'm gonna go and turn it back off again,

590
00:30:13.020 --> 00:30:14.170
but I just wanted you guys to be aware.

591
00:30:14.170 --> 00:30:19.420
So the primary sources of applications
is going to be the Apple App Store.

592
00:30:19.420 --> 00:30:21.590
After that,
you can go to third party websites and

593
00:30:21.590 --> 00:30:22.930
download applications that way.

594
00:30:22.930 --> 00:30:25.315
Perfectly fine, and lots of people do it.

595
00:30:25.315 --> 00:30:26.555
It's what we've been doing for decades.

596
00:30:26.555 --> 00:30:28.094
And then lastly, Dashboard bridges.

597
00:30:28.094 --> 00:30:30.710
That's really the three main ones
that we need to worry about.

598
00:30:30.710 --> 00:30:34.130
>> Awesome, episode as usual,
Don, on managing applications.

599
00:30:34.130 --> 00:30:36.081
So rewatch it a couple of times.

600
00:30:36.081 --> 00:30:37.143
>> [LAUGH]
>> I know I'm going to.

601
00:30:37.143 --> 00:30:39.547
And then before we move on,
anything else you'd like to say?

602
00:30:39.547 --> 00:30:40.744
>> That's the main thing,

603
00:30:40.744 --> 00:30:44.410
I do wanna mention if you do install
an app from the App Store it auto updates.

604
00:30:44.410 --> 00:30:47.500
I didn't really talk about updates for
non App Store Apps.

605
00:30:47.500 --> 00:30:49.080
You just have to go to
the vendor's website.

606
00:30:49.080 --> 00:30:51.390
You have to find out
that they have an update.

607
00:30:51.390 --> 00:30:55.420
Some of them like Microsoft Office,
if you install that from Microsoft,

608
00:30:55.420 --> 00:30:58.920
they have a special application that
you run that is the update application.

609
00:30:58.920 --> 00:31:01.950
But you have to run it to check for
updates, otherwise you don't know.

610
00:31:01.950 --> 00:31:06.140
So updates, the ball is in your court if
you're installing the application from

611
00:31:06.140 --> 00:31:07.440
outside of the App Store.

612
00:31:07.440 --> 00:31:08.550
>> Good advice, Don.

613
00:31:08.550 --> 00:31:12.400
And Apple Certified Support Professionals,
a wonderful series.

614
00:31:12.400 --> 00:31:14.125
Make sure you watch Watch every episode.

615
00:31:14.125 --> 00:31:15.365
You'll be glad you did.

616
00:31:15.365 --> 00:31:19.005
And you'll be in the course library too,
where there's thousands of other videos

617
00:31:19.005 --> 00:31:22.035
that are there for one thing,
to help you go further.

618
00:31:22.035 --> 00:31:25.205
Check it out, And
tell everyone you know about ITProTV.

619
00:31:25.205 --> 00:31:26.935
ITProTV is binge worthy.

620
00:31:26.935 --> 00:31:28.585
Thanks for watching, I'm, Zach Memmis.

621
00:31:28.585 --> 00:31:29.435
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

622
00:31:29.435 --> 00:31:30.883
>> And we will see you again very soon.

623
00:31:30.883 --> 00:31:38.712
[MUSIC]

624
00:31:38.712 --> 00:31:41.220
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don dives into how macOS handles application data. He shows how application files are stored on disk and how to locate related files that are not immediately visible by default.
episodes.title: Application Data
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:04.933
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:04.933 --> 00:00:06.664
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.664 --> 00:00:07.610
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.610 --> 00:00:12.859
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Hello, and thank you for

5
00:00:12.859 --> 00:00:17.010
choosing ITPro.TV, empowering
the world with engaging learning.

6
00:00:17.010 --> 00:00:17.870
I'm your host Zach Memos.

7
00:00:17.870 --> 00:00:21.160
For this episode of Apple
certified Support Professionals

8
00:00:21.160 --> 00:00:24.560
we are going to be application data now.

9
00:00:24.560 --> 00:00:27.890
That's right, and the person who is going
to be helping us with that is the one and

10
00:00:27.890 --> 00:00:29.620
only Don Pezet.

11
00:00:29.620 --> 00:00:30.720
Hey Don, good to see you.

12
00:00:30.720 --> 00:00:34.370
Hey great to see you too Zach and we are
continuing our adventure on applications.

13
00:00:34.370 --> 00:00:38.321
If you watched our last episode we talked
about how to install applications, and

14
00:00:38.321 --> 00:00:40.719
where they came from, and
all that other stuff.

15
00:00:40.719 --> 00:00:45.228
And we really kind of painted this picture
of an application is being one file.

16
00:00:45.228 --> 00:00:48.213
But there's actually a lot more
to an application as you run it,

17
00:00:48.213 --> 00:00:49.535
it generates a lot data.

18
00:00:49.535 --> 00:00:53.065
And so in this episode, we're gonna be
focusing on what that other data is.

19
00:00:53.065 --> 00:00:57.784
All the ancillary files and
information that goes along with that

20
00:00:57.784 --> 00:01:01.055
single file that looks
like an application.

21
00:01:01.055 --> 00:01:04.175
It's involved, and
it's easy to lose track of.

22
00:01:04.175 --> 00:01:08.435
If you've ever bumped into this where you
uninstall an application to delete it, and

23
00:01:08.435 --> 00:01:10.091
then later you reinstall it, and

24
00:01:10.091 --> 00:01:12.770
everything's still set up
the way that it used to be.

25
00:01:12.770 --> 00:01:15.350
It remembers everything,
how the heck did it do that?

26
00:01:15.350 --> 00:01:18.862
It's because there's all of these
other files that get left behind.

27
00:01:18.862 --> 00:01:21.502
So we're gonna look at some of those
right here in this episode and

28
00:01:21.502 --> 00:01:24.346
kinda find out how that works,
know where to look to find those files.

29
00:01:24.346 --> 00:01:26.463
And see how we can kinda use those for
troubleshooting and

30
00:01:26.463 --> 00:01:29.160
resetting an application to get
it back to the way that it was.

31
00:01:29.160 --> 00:01:31.166
That's all coming up right
here in this episode.

32
00:01:31.166 --> 00:01:31.818
>> Good stuff, so

33
00:01:31.818 --> 00:01:35.087
where does application data get stored?
>> Well,

34
00:01:35.087 --> 00:01:36.774
I wish I had a single answer for that,

35
00:01:36.774 --> 00:01:41.410
cuz there's actually a number of different
places where the data gets stored.

36
00:01:41.410 --> 00:01:43.827
First off, there's the stuff
that's really visible to us.

37
00:01:43.827 --> 00:01:48.366
If I install Microsoft Word and
I start typing a letter and I save it,

38
00:01:48.366 --> 00:01:52.922
wherever I choose to save that is
where some of it's data's going.

39
00:01:52.922 --> 00:01:55.632
Now that's visible data,
that's data we wanna see.

40
00:01:55.632 --> 00:01:58.345
And visible stuff like that normally
goes into our documents folders.

41
00:01:58.345 --> 00:02:05.300
So for example if I go into my finder, and
in my finder, I'n in my home directory.

42
00:02:05.300 --> 00:02:07.790
And in my home directory,
I've got a Documents folder.

43
00:02:07.790 --> 00:02:11.420
And so that's likely where my
application is storing the data that it

44
00:02:11.420 --> 00:02:12.770
generates, right?

45
00:02:12.770 --> 00:02:17.380
Although if it's a graphics editing
program, maybe it saves into the Pictures

46
00:02:17.380 --> 00:02:20.050
folder, or Movies, or Music, right?
>> Mm-hm,

47
00:02:20.050 --> 00:02:20.560
mm-hm.
>> But

48
00:02:20.560 --> 00:02:23.220
this is the highly visible
stuff that we see.

49
00:02:23.220 --> 00:02:26.390
As a end-user,I could choose
to store stuff other places.

50
00:02:26.390 --> 00:02:29.600
So for example,
I have a program called AJA MiniConfig,

51
00:02:29.600 --> 00:02:32.000
which lets me use a little zoom-in
tool under the desk here [LAUGH].

52
00:02:32.000 --> 00:02:35.970
I have a program called Resilio Sync
that I use to synchronize files

53
00:02:35.970 --> 00:02:37.170
between my computers.

54
00:02:37.170 --> 00:02:39.000
And those two programs, for

55
00:02:39.000 --> 00:02:42.710
whatever reason the authors of those
programs decided, well, it would be crazy

56
00:02:42.710 --> 00:02:46.800
to stick that in Documents, we're gonna
put them out here in these folders, right?

57
00:02:46.800 --> 00:02:50.590
And there is actually a reason for
that, the main reason is iCloud.

58
00:02:50.590 --> 00:02:53.790
iCloud synchronizes
the Documents folder by default,

59
00:02:53.790 --> 00:02:58.210
synchronizes this right up
into the iCloud storage.

60
00:02:58.210 --> 00:02:59.300
Well, for

61
00:02:59.300 --> 00:03:03.720
something like Resilio Sync, I could have
terabytes of files being synchronized.

62
00:03:03.720 --> 00:03:05.260
And I might not want those
to go into iCloud, and

63
00:03:05.260 --> 00:03:07.900
I wouldn't have that choice if
it was in the documents folder.

64
00:03:07.900 --> 00:03:10.050
I also run a program called VMware Fusion,
and

65
00:03:10.050 --> 00:03:11.920
with VMware Fusion I can
create virtual machines.

66
00:03:11.920 --> 00:03:16.110
And those virtual machine files,
they'll end up being 60 gigs sometimes,

67
00:03:16.110 --> 00:03:18.210
they can be pretty big files.

68
00:03:18.210 --> 00:03:22.830
Well, VMware Fusion does put the virtual
machines in the Documents folder.

69
00:03:22.830 --> 00:03:25.966
So I can see it right here, here's a bunch
of these virtual machines that I've made.

70
00:03:25.966 --> 00:03:27.145
So, for example,

71
00:03:27.145 --> 00:03:32.402
in some of the earlier episodes you guys
might have seen me running OS10 10.8.

72
00:03:32.402 --> 00:03:35.520
I don't actually have a computer here
running 10.8, that would be crazy.

73
00:03:35.520 --> 00:03:38.054
I'd have to have a time machine,
like a real time machine.

74
00:03:38.054 --> 00:03:39.434
>> Good, let's get one.

75
00:03:39.434 --> 00:03:40.763
>> Can we get Orson Wells in here or

76
00:03:40.763 --> 00:03:42.479
whatever, no, Jules?
>> H.G.

77
00:03:42.479 --> 00:03:43.709
Wells.
>> Was it H.G.

78
00:03:43.709 --> 00:03:44.239
Wells?
>> Mm-hm.

79
00:03:44.239 --> 00:03:44.809
>> All right, so

80
00:03:44.809 --> 00:03:47.260
we have to really get creative
here to be able to do that.

81
00:03:47.260 --> 00:03:50.220
So I use the virtual machine and
it's all stored right here in that file.

82
00:03:50.220 --> 00:03:53.580
Well those files can be
a little on the big side,

83
00:03:53.580 --> 00:03:58.379
right, this one is 100 gigs in size.
>> I don't wanna synchronize

84
00:03:58.379 --> 00:04:01.410
that into iCloud, iCloud's free
storage is only 5 gigs anyway.

85
00:04:01.410 --> 00:04:03.227
I'd have to pay to get to this level.
>> Mm.

86
00:04:03.227 --> 00:04:04.411
>> In fact that's even over the second

87
00:04:04.411 --> 00:04:05.800
tier, the second tier's 100 gigs.

88
00:04:05.800 --> 00:04:10.110
I'd have to pay for the higher tier
of storage, it would cost some money.

89
00:04:10.110 --> 00:04:12.410
So a lot of vendors choose
not store that way.

90
00:04:12.410 --> 00:04:16.710
And that means that the visible
files your application creates,

91
00:04:16.710 --> 00:04:20.730
they can be in any number places and
you can even overwrite it.

92
00:04:20.730 --> 00:04:24.307
When I go into Microsoft Word,
I'll fire it up.

93
00:04:24.307 --> 00:04:27.067
And I start to type a nice new,
yeah, great,

94
00:04:27.067 --> 00:04:30.387
I definitely wanna do that Microsoft,
thank you [LAUGH].

95
00:04:30.387 --> 00:04:35.192
And I create a new document, so
this is a document, it is awesome, and

96
00:04:35.192 --> 00:04:36.620
I go to save it.

97
00:04:36.620 --> 00:04:38.950
When I save,
it asks me where I wanna save it.

98
00:04:38.950 --> 00:04:42.770
And it will usually default
to your Documents folder, but

99
00:04:42.770 --> 00:04:46.390
you can actually come in and
pick anywhere you want.

100
00:04:46.390 --> 00:04:49.220
So finding that application
data's really hard,

101
00:04:49.220 --> 00:04:52.668
but it's made a little bit easier
in that these files are visible.

102
00:04:52.668 --> 00:04:55.992
If I save it to my Desktop,
I'm going to see that document, right?

103
00:04:55.992 --> 00:05:00.593
It'll show up on my Desktop,
I can see it right here in the background,

104
00:05:00.593 --> 00:05:03.600
right, or
I can see it in my Documents folder.

105
00:05:03.600 --> 00:05:06.883
The files I really need to worry about
though, are the ones that are hidden,

106
00:05:06.883 --> 00:05:08.130
the ones that we can't see.

107
00:05:09.160 --> 00:05:13.090
Every application is gonna generate
at least one of these, and

108
00:05:13.090 --> 00:05:15.540
that is what's called a preference file.

109
00:05:15.540 --> 00:05:18.030
A preference file is a file that contains

110
00:05:18.030 --> 00:05:20.810
all the settings inside
of that application.

111
00:05:20.810 --> 00:05:23.380
So for example if I take,

112
00:05:23.380 --> 00:05:27.070
I'll use the program I was using in
the last episode, ForkLift, all right?

113
00:05:27.070 --> 00:05:29.670
Here's ForkLift,
it's a little file manager, all right?

114
00:05:29.670 --> 00:05:33.810
And it doesn't really make files itself
it allows me to manage my files, so

115
00:05:33.810 --> 00:05:37.490
I can browse around here and start
managing files, doing all sorts of stuff.

116
00:05:37.490 --> 00:05:41.780
Well, if I want,
I can change ForkLift's appearance.

117
00:05:41.780 --> 00:05:45.060
Maybe I don't like this light appearance,
I want it to be a dark appearance.

118
00:05:45.060 --> 00:05:49.410
So I can go up into ForkLift and
Preferences.

119
00:05:49.410 --> 00:05:53.349
And when I go into the preferences for
ForkLift, I can enable dark mode.

120
00:05:54.620 --> 00:05:59.250
And in the background it just changed and
now it's a file manager suitable for

121
00:05:59.250 --> 00:06:00.030
Batman, right?

122
00:06:00.030 --> 00:06:01.170
It's got.
>> I like it.

123
00:06:01.170 --> 00:06:03.970
>> Multiple shades of grey, that's it, and

124
00:06:03.970 --> 00:06:04.850
there we are.

125
00:06:04.850 --> 00:06:10.380
So how does it remember that
I want it to be in dark mode?

126
00:06:10.380 --> 00:06:12.182
It saved in a preference file, and

127
00:06:12.182 --> 00:06:14.925
that preference file is
an example of a hidden file.

128
00:06:14.925 --> 00:06:20.396
One that's stashed away, that we can't
normally get at, we can't normally see.

129
00:06:20.396 --> 00:06:24.663
And there may be many of these files,
not just preference files, but things like

130
00:06:24.663 --> 00:06:29.204
library files, or extensions, other things
that make this application do its job.

131
00:06:29.204 --> 00:06:31.130
So let me show you where
these are in terminal.

132
00:06:32.700 --> 00:06:35.570
And I'll kinda help you
spot some of those.

133
00:06:35.570 --> 00:06:40.690
Now, where it gets tricky is there
are global preferences that affect

134
00:06:40.690 --> 00:06:45.380
the entire computer, and then there's
user preferences that affect just me.

135
00:06:45.380 --> 00:06:49.120
So if I log in, I might have ForkLift
set up for the dark mode and then,

136
00:06:49.120 --> 00:06:52.320
if Zack logs in, he might have
ForkLift set for the light mode.

137
00:06:52.320 --> 00:06:56.420
So two separate sets of preferences,
but there'll be a third set

138
00:06:56.420 --> 00:06:59.120
of preferences at the global that
says these are the defaults.

139
00:06:59.120 --> 00:07:01.085
When a new user fires up Forklift,

140
00:07:01.085 --> 00:07:04.350
[COUGH] this is how it'll be
configured by default, and then

141
00:07:04.350 --> 00:07:08.150
they can change it if they want and it'll
change in their user preferences, right?

142
00:07:08.150 --> 00:07:12.800
Same thing goes for the support files that
go along with it, any other extensions or

143
00:07:12.800 --> 00:07:13.770
libraries.

144
00:07:13.770 --> 00:07:15.670
Theres global ones,
that are available for everybody, and

145
00:07:15.670 --> 00:07:17.980
then theres user ones that
are available just for you.

146
00:07:17.980 --> 00:07:20.500
Let me show you the global ones first.

147
00:07:20.500 --> 00:07:25.000
If I go into the /Library folder,
inside of /Library,

148
00:07:25.000 --> 00:07:29.750
youll find a folder called
Application Support.

149
00:07:29.750 --> 00:07:32.400
So, /Library/Application Support.
>> Mm-hm.

150
00:07:32.400 --> 00:07:34.530
>> And inside of there,

151
00:07:34.530 --> 00:07:36.300
youll find support files.

152
00:07:36.300 --> 00:07:40.804
And I can see files in here for
VMware, my virtualization software,

153
00:07:40.804 --> 00:07:45.710
I've got Viscosity, it's a VPN software
I use, I don't see AGA in here.

154
00:07:45.710 --> 00:07:49.040
So, I guess the Mini-Config software
doesn't have any support files,

155
00:07:49.040 --> 00:07:50.176
not every program does.

156
00:07:50.176 --> 00:07:54.540
Logitech does, GarageBand, So these
are places where they have files that

157
00:07:54.540 --> 00:07:58.080
extend the functionality
of that application, right.

158
00:07:58.080 --> 00:07:58.990
Microsoft has something.

159
00:07:58.990 --> 00:08:04.850
If I go into Microsoft,
that should be Office, the MAU2.0

160
00:08:04.850 --> 00:08:08.642
is the Microsoft Automatic Updater,
the tool that updates Microsoft Office.

161
00:08:08.642 --> 00:08:12.410
And so
there is the actual auto update app.

162
00:08:12.410 --> 00:08:15.790
It is an entire application
stored in the support folder, and

163
00:08:15.790 --> 00:08:20.522
that is because all of the Microsoft
applications can call this one program.

164
00:08:20.522 --> 00:08:23.520
And it has to be allowed
through Apple sandbox.

165
00:08:23.520 --> 00:08:26.560
The protected boundaries it
puts around applications.

166

Mobile phones, tablets,

00:03:44.580 --> 00:03:47.880

00:19:05.022 --> 00:19:07.340
you can just voice out
dictate that out email.

384
00:19:07.340 --> 00:19:10.450
You don't have to type anything
you just ride along and

385
00:19:10.450 --> 00:19:13.120
off it goes ready to rock and you're done.

386
00:19:13.120 --> 00:19:17.050
So really cool system there, and that's
been a part of Mac OS for a long time.

387
00:19:17.050 --> 00:19:19.340
If you use it in
conjunction of voice over,

388
00:19:19.340 --> 00:19:23.530
now it's reading to us on the screen, and
then you're just telling it what to type.

389
00:19:23.530 --> 00:19:25.630
And you've got a fully
voice interactive system.

390
00:19:25.630 --> 00:19:26.850
>> That's very impressive, but

391

what commands does dictation listen for?
>> There

392
00:19:30.590 --> 00:19:33.360
whole list of command I'll put
a bunch of them as shown in the photo.

393

Just give me an example.

394

let me just show you.

395

Select on.

396

Copy that.

397

Paste that.

398

Paste that.

399

Paste that.

400
00:19:50.834 --> 00:19:54.102
All right, I've done a select all so
when I did paste that the first time,

401
00:19:54.102 --> 00:19:56.020
it just over wrote what was already there.

402
00:19:56.020 --> 00:19:59.630
So I did it a couple times, but
what you can see is I was telling it,

403
00:19:59.630 --> 00:20:02.920
select all the text, copy it,
paste it, it's doing that, right?

404
00:20:02.920 --> 00:20:05.160
It's going through and
running through those commands.

405
00:20:05.160 --> 00:20:08.670
Couple examples of other ones,
that was like cut, copy, and paste.

406
00:20:08.670 --> 00:20:13.350
It does those, you can tell it to bold,
italicize, underline.

407
00:20:13.350 --> 00:20:14.460
It can do those.

408
00:20:14.460 --> 00:20:20.780
You can tell it to scroll up,
scroll down, so it can navigate that way.

409
00:20:20.780 --> 00:20:22.380
What else can it do?

410
00:20:22.380 --> 00:20:26.418
Move left, move right for
navigating around that way.

411
00:20:26.418 --> 00:20:28.036
Here's a pretty handy one.

412

Show commands.

413

There we go.

414

Turn that off.

415

So now when I did show commands,
it brings up a little window here.

416
00:20:40.230 --> 00:20:41.600
No it went away.

417

Well it brought up a little window for
a brief while.

418

>> [LAUGH]

419
00:20:44.760 --> 00:20:47.190
>> Wow, I am, now I've shrunk my document

420
00:20:47.190 --> 00:20:48.630
down by chopping.
>> It's very tiny.

421
00:20:48.630 --> 00:20:49.640
>> Apparently I don't know how to use

422
00:20:49.640 --> 00:20:50.610
Microsoft Word.

423
00:20:50.610 --> 00:20:54.789
But I show command,
it's kind of a nice one.

424
00:20:54.789 --> 00:20:55.605
Let's try this again.

425
00:20:55.605 --> 00:20:59.930
[LAUGH]
Well eventually I get this work,

426
00:20:59.930 --> 00:21:00.575
show commands.

427
00:21:00.575 --> 00:21:05.783
[SOUND] And so now I can see the selection
commands, navigation commands,

428
00:21:05.783 --> 00:21:11.327
I can see the editing commands,
formatting system like starting dictation,

429
00:21:11.327 --> 00:21:14.108
stopping dictation, all right here.

430
00:21:14.108 --> 00:21:16.640
You get an idea of what
commands are supported.

431
00:21:16.640 --> 00:21:19.160
So I said I was gonna put
some on the show notes,

432
00:21:19.160 --> 00:21:20.970
it wasn't gonna be nearly
as thorough as this.

433
00:21:20.970 --> 00:21:23.080
So definitely take a browse through there,
and

434
00:21:23.080 --> 00:21:26.970
you'll see these commands vary depending
on which application you get into.

435
00:21:26.970 --> 00:21:30.920
Another thing to watch out for
is notice I've been talking a lot, and

436
00:21:30.920 --> 00:21:32.320
it thinks that I'm still navigating.

437
00:21:32.320 --> 00:21:36.112
And so it tried typing, but
eventually, I ran through its buffer.

438
00:21:36.112 --> 00:21:38.580
>> It can only get so much text at a time.

439

So be conscious of that as
you're dictating out that

440
00:21:42.320 --> 00:21:43.460
you need to pause every now and

441
00:21:43.460 --> 00:21:46.260
then to give it a chance to catch up.
>> Fantastic.

442
00:21:46.260 --> 00:21:50.640
Application support part two,
another wonderful episode done well done.

443
00:21:50.640 --> 00:21:54.620
Before we move on anything
else you like to say?

444
00:21:54.620 --> 00:21:55.894
>> As far as all this voice stuff,

445
00:21:55.894 --> 00:21:57.908
make sure you take a look
at a mess around with it.

446
00:21:57.908 --> 00:22:03.370
If you're working with people are visually
impaired then get their opinion.

447
00:22:03.370 --> 00:22:06.000
Talk to them, don't try to force
one of these solutions on them.

448
00:22:06.000 --> 00:22:09.520
They usually have something that helps
make the system work the best for them.

449
00:22:09.520 --> 00:22:11.030
They might have third party software.

450
00:22:11.030 --> 00:22:14.970
There's plenty of amazing third party
solutions that do a lot of the same stuff.

451
00:22:14.970 --> 00:22:18.180
You want to make sure
the computers are accessible and

452
00:22:18.180 --> 00:22:22.740
easy to use as possible and that
doesn't mean shoe-horning somebody into

453
00:22:22.740 --> 00:22:25.440
one particular solution just
because it's already installed.

454
00:22:25.440 --> 00:22:28.200
But if they have nothing,
these solutions are great.

455
00:22:28.200 --> 00:22:29.830
You can leverage them right away.

456
00:22:29.830 --> 00:22:35.520
You provide that access, and you're giving
access to a whole new world to people.

457
00:22:35.520 --> 00:22:37.305
It's really an amazing thing.
>> It really is amazing.

458
00:22:37.305 --> 00:22:38.910
And what else is amazing?

459

Apple Certified support professional,
the series.

460

Make sure you watch every single episode.

461

You're gonna be so glad you did.

And you'll be in the course library where
there's thousands of other videos that

so look at those too.

And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

465

ITProTV is binge-worthy.

466

Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

467
00:22:57.240 --> 00:22:58.975
>> And we will see you again very soon.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues to explore application support in macOS 10.13 High Sierra. He discusses application improvements in High Sierra including application sandboxing, application monitoring, and Diagnostic reporting and logging.
episodes.title: Application Support Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.419
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.419 --> 00:00:06.362
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.362 --> 00:00:08.163
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.163 --> 00:00:12.230
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.
>> Hello,

5
00:00:12.230 --> 00:00:15.939
thank you for watching ITPRO.TV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:15.939 --> 00:00:17.655
I'm Zach Memos, your host for

7
00:00:17.655 --> 00:00:22.496
this episode of Apple Certified Support
Professional Applications Support Part 3.

8
00:00:22.496 --> 00:00:25.585
And, of course, Don Pezet is here to take
us through it, Don, good to see you, sir.

9
00:00:25.585 --> 00:00:26.580
>> Hey, glad to be back, Zach.

10
00:00:26.580 --> 00:00:29.767
And we're going to talk a little
bit more about the odd and

11
00:00:29.767 --> 00:00:33.568
unusual applications that we might
bump into as we work with Mac OS.

12
00:00:33.568 --> 00:00:37.675
In the first episode, we talked about Java
applications and iCloud applications.

13
00:00:37.675 --> 00:00:40.596
In the second episode, we talked about
voice enabled applications like Siri.

14
00:00:40.596 --> 00:00:41.516
>> Very cool.

15
00:00:41.516 --> 00:00:42.297
>> In this episode,

16
00:00:42.297 --> 00:00:44.278
we're going to get
a little more technical,

17
00:00:44.278 --> 00:00:47.054
we're going to talk about things
like 64 bit applications.

18
00:00:47.054 --> 00:00:51.256
And applications that are sandboxed,
that have security boundaries on them.

19
00:00:51.256 --> 00:00:52.758
And kind of explain how those work and

20
00:00:52.758 --> 00:00:55.390
understand how they might impact
the way that our programs run.

21
00:00:55.390 --> 00:00:59.256
So that should get us to the end
of our Application Support series.

22
00:00:59.256 --> 00:01:01.154
But there's a few more little quirks and
odds and

23
00:01:01.154 --> 00:01:03.700
ends that we need to know to
understand how all of our applications

24
00:01:03.700 --> 00:01:04.294
behave.
>> And

25
00:01:04.294 --> 00:01:07.331
what do we need to know
about 64 bit apps in Mac OS?

26
00:01:07.331 --> 00:01:07.839
>> All right, so

27
00:01:07.839 --> 00:01:09.669
Apple has been promoting this pretty big,
right?

28
00:01:09.669 --> 00:01:15.878
Mac OS has been a 64 bit operating system
for a long time, since I think 10.7,

29
00:01:15.878 --> 00:01:19.324
Lion, Mountain Lion, I don't know.
>> [LAUGH]

30
00:01:19.324 --> 00:01:20.201
>> A while back, so

31
00:01:20.201 --> 00:01:22.092
it's been a 64 bit OS for a while.

32
00:01:22.092 --> 00:01:24.439
Prior to that,
it was a 32 bit operating system.

33
00:01:24.439 --> 00:01:27.331
Applications written for
Mac OS were 32 bit,

34
00:01:27.331 --> 00:01:31.681
and what that means is they can only
address a certain amount of memory.

35
00:01:31.681 --> 00:01:36.667
They had a number that was limited
to 32 binary bits, zeroes and ones,

36
00:01:36.667 --> 00:01:40.932
and that meant that it was kinda
capped out at a certain point.

37
00:01:40.932 --> 00:01:44.706
That if you had an application
that was 32 bit,

38
00:01:44.706 --> 00:01:48.035
it could not use more
than four gigs of RAM.

39
00:01:48.035 --> 00:01:51.940
Now, there's tons of Macs these days
that come with 16 gigs of RAM, or

40
00:01:51.940 --> 00:01:53.624
even more if you have a Mac Pro.

41
00:01:53.624 --> 00:01:57.700
If an application can't use more than four
gigs of RAM, why sell a Mac with 16 gigs?

42
00:01:57.700 --> 00:02:03.776
Well, I could run four applications, for
each one use 4 gigs of memory, right?

43
00:02:03.776 --> 00:02:08.643
But if I had one application,
maybe like AutoCAD, or a database server.

44
00:02:08.643 --> 00:02:11.003
And I wanted it to have 10 gigs of memory,

45
00:02:11.003 --> 00:02:13.637
you can't do that with
a 32 bit application.

46
00:02:13.637 --> 00:02:17.761
A 64-bit application, though, it can.

47
00:02:17.761 --> 00:02:22.458
So, for example, a 32 bit application
is limited to four gigs of RAM.

48
00:02:22.458 --> 00:02:28.018
But a 64 bit application can access,
I've got the number written down

49
00:02:28.018 --> 00:02:33.508
here because it's hard to remember,
is 18.4 exabytes of memory.

50
00:02:33.508 --> 00:02:35.016
That's a lot of memory, right?

51
00:02:35.016 --> 00:02:39.095
So it goes from megabytes to gigabytes to

52
00:02:39.095 --> 00:02:43.990
terabytes to petabytes to exabytes.
>> It's way out there.

53
00:02:43.990 --> 00:02:45.598
>> You can't buy exabytes of memory in

54
00:02:45.598 --> 00:02:48.232
a single system right now,
it's just not even possible.

55
00:02:48.232 --> 00:02:52.183
So 64 bit applications give us
access to a ton more memory,

56
00:02:52.183 --> 00:02:54.361
that means better performance.

57
00:02:54.361 --> 00:02:56.274
But there's also security enhancements and

58
00:02:56.274 --> 00:02:58.701
other things that are built
into 64 bit applications.

59
00:02:58.701 --> 00:03:03.407
So Apple has been banging the drum for
years, saying, developers,

60
00:03:03.407 --> 00:03:07.477
you need to switch your
applications over to 64 bit mode.

61
00:03:07.477 --> 00:03:11.254
Well, with Mac OS High Sierra,
they've thrown down the gauntlet.

62
00:03:11.254 --> 00:03:13.328
And they've said, that's it,

63
00:03:13.328 --> 00:03:17.857
this the last version of Mac OS that
will support 32 bit applications.

64
00:03:17.857 --> 00:03:22.465
When the next version comes out,
when 10.14 comes out,

65
00:03:22.465 --> 00:03:24.688
Mac OS, even higher Sierra.

66
00:03:24.688 --> 00:03:29.377
When that one comes out, then that one
will only run 64 bit applications,

67
00:03:29.377 --> 00:03:32.906
and the 32 bit apps you have
will no longer run, right?

68
00:03:32.906 --> 00:03:35.845
If you want to run them, you'll have to
run them inside of a virtual machine.

69
00:03:35.845 --> 00:03:39.976
Or you won't be able to upgrade to
the newer OS if you need to maintain those

70
00:03:39.976 --> 00:03:41.519
apps, that's a big deal.

71
00:03:41.519 --> 00:03:45.388
Now I'll tell you that most developers
have already moved over to 64 bit.

72
00:03:45.388 --> 00:03:49.642
If you got it from the app store, the odds
are it's already 64 bit as well, so

73
00:03:49.642 --> 00:03:51.009
you're probably fine.

74
00:03:51.009 --> 00:03:53.745
If you don't know, though, like,
hey, maybe I have an app and

75
00:03:53.745 --> 00:03:55.394
I don't know if it's 32 bit or not.

76
00:03:55.394 --> 00:03:59.738
Well, in High Sierra, if you run a 32
bit app, you get a pop up box, and

77
00:03:59.738 --> 00:04:00.604
it tells you.

78
00:04:00.604 --> 00:04:01.197
It says, hey,

79
00:04:01.197 --> 00:04:04.177
warning, this is the last version of
Sierra that's going to run this thing.

80
00:04:04.177 --> 00:04:06.425
And so it tells you that,
it lets you know,

81
00:04:06.425 --> 00:04:09.184
real easy to tell if you've
got a 32 bit app or not.

82
00:04:09.184 --> 00:04:13.298
But after that, if it's already 64 bit,
you'll be in good shape,

83
00:04:13.298 --> 00:04:15.964
you can run it, pop it up,
and you can see it.

84
00:04:15.964 --> 00:04:20.733
Now, some developers have had a bit of
a hard time transitioning from 32 bit to

85
00:04:20.733 --> 00:04:21.385
64 bit.

86
00:04:21.385 --> 00:04:26.656
And so their app might be both,
where it's got 32 and 64 bit inside.

87
00:04:26.656 --> 00:04:28.993
Firefox was like this for
several versions,

88
00:04:28.993 --> 00:04:32.629
they actually just removed the 32
bit mode out of it not too long ago.

89
00:04:32.629 --> 00:04:35.653
But there are some apps
that still have it, and

90
00:04:35.653 --> 00:04:40.320
a great example of that is the Mac
OS High Sierra installation program.

91
00:04:40.320 --> 00:04:44.085
And you might ask yourself,
why would Apple still have a 32 bit app?

92
00:04:44.085 --> 00:04:48.508
And the reason is, I might want to install
Mac OS High Sierra, if I can find it,

93
00:04:48.508 --> 00:04:50.397
it's in here somewhere, here.

94
00:04:50.397 --> 00:04:53.811
I might want to install High Sierra on a
system that's currently running the 32 bit

95
00:04:53.811 --> 00:04:55.219
version of the operating system.

96
00:04:55.219 --> 00:04:58.059
So it needs to run
the installer in 32 bit, and

97
00:04:58.059 --> 00:05:02.758
then it installs the 64 bit version,
so that's why they have that support.

98
00:05:02.758 --> 00:05:05.426
If your application supports both modes,

99
00:05:05.426 --> 00:05:08.250
you can see it in
the Get Information screen.

100
00:05:08.250 --> 00:05:12.862
If you two-finger tap and
do Get Info, or just do Command I and

101
00:05:12.862 --> 00:05:15.365
pull up the Information screen.

102
00:05:15.365 --> 00:05:20.299
Inside of the Information screen, what
you'll see is this little box right here,

103
00:05:20.299 --> 00:05:21.787
Open in 32-bit mode.

104
00:05:21.787 --> 00:05:25.832
That's telling me this application
has both 64 bit and 32 bit mode,

105
00:05:25.832 --> 00:05:29.692
it's going to open in 64 bit mode
by default, that's what I want.

106
00:05:29.692 --> 00:05:33.564
Or I could open it in 32 bit mode,
I've mentioned Firefox,

107
00:05:33.564 --> 00:05:37.073
Firefox used to be like this,
which if I find it in here.

108
00:05:37.073 --> 00:05:40.682
Here's Firefox and
I'll do a Get Info on that one, and

109
00:05:40.682 --> 00:05:44.151
see that Open in 32-bit mode is gone now,
right?

110
00:05:44.151 --> 00:05:47.162
It's gone because they don't support it,
they moved,

111
00:05:47.162 --> 00:05:49.932
they are a 64 bit browser now and
that's how it is.

112
00:05:49.932 --> 00:05:53.417
But you'll find over time
that a lot of applications,

113
00:05:53.417 --> 00:05:56.234
the developers just had
to do a little work.

114
00:05:56.234 --> 00:05:58.844
With Firefox, the challenge
they had were with the plugins.

115
00:05:58.844 --> 00:06:02.503
They had all these 32 bits plugins,
and when they switch to 64 bit mode,

116
00:06:02.503 --> 00:06:05.490
all of those plugins break, so
that was a lot of work for them.

117
00:06:05.490 --> 00:06:10.296
Other developers, like,
take an application like gas masks,

118
00:06:10.296 --> 00:06:13.948
that's a little name look
up utility that I use.

119
00:06:13.948 --> 00:06:16.704
And with that utility,
all the developer had to do is go in and

120
00:06:16.704 --> 00:06:18.938
recompile it in 64 bit mode and
they were done.

121
00:06:18.938 --> 00:06:23.474
They had it ported over years ago, just
super easy to make that transition, so

122
00:06:23.474 --> 00:06:26.522
some applications are more
difficult than others.

123
00:06:26.522 --> 00:06:30.266
If you're getting that pop up that's
telling you, hey, this is a 32 bit app,

124
00:06:30.266 --> 00:06:32.701
it's not going to work in
the next version of Mac OS.

125
00:06:32.701 --> 00:06:35.042
You need to reach out to
that developer and say, hey,

126
00:06:35.042 --> 00:06:37.084
are you going to publish
the 64 bit version?

127
00:06:37.084 --> 00:06:39.004
Hopefully they say yes, if they say no,

128
00:06:39.004 --> 00:06:41.217
you need to find
an alternative application.

129
00:06:41.217 --> 00:06:44.078
You need to be looking for
what you're going to migrate to,

130
00:06:44.078 --> 00:06:47.353
because going forward,
those 32 cubit apps are going to be dead.

131
00:06:47.353 --> 00:06:49.453
>> And you mentioned better security,

132
00:06:49.453 --> 00:06:52.656
how does Mac OS secure applications?
>> So there is a lot of magic

133
00:06:52.656 --> 00:06:56.317
that goes on behind the scenes, and we've
seen some of that in some of our episodes.

134
00:06:56.317 --> 00:06:58.896
Like when you download
an application from the Internet and

135
00:06:58.896 --> 00:07:01.178
you run it,
you get the gatekeeper functionality.

136
00:07:01.178 --> 00:07:04.069
We covered that in another episode
where it pops up and says,

137
00:07:04.069 --> 00:07:05.722
are you sure you want to open this?

138
00:07:05.722 --> 00:07:09.165
It's an untrusted developer,
so that's going on, right, but

139
00:07:09.165 --> 00:07:10.990
there's actually another part.

140

00:18:58.635 --> 00:19:01.195
You'll get that with
applications sometimes where,

367
00:19:01.195 --> 00:19:03.410
let me fire the terminal backup again.

368
00:19:03.410 --> 00:19:08.090
And down here in my doc, I'll have that
icon and if I two finger tap it and

369
00:19:08.090 --> 00:19:10.510
go to Quit, it will try and close it.

370
00:19:10.510 --> 00:19:14.749
But if it's stuck, if it's lock and
I choose quit again and it will say,

371
00:19:14.749 --> 00:19:16.640
do you wanna force quit it?

372
00:19:16.640 --> 00:19:18.230
Right, so it'll give you that option.

373
00:19:18.230 --> 00:19:22.860
If it doesn't give you the option, you can
hold down the Option key on your keyboard.

374
00:19:22.860 --> 00:19:24.430
See what happens when I hold that option?

375
00:19:24.430 --> 00:19:26.782
Quit becomes Force Quit, right?

376
00:19:26.782 --> 00:19:30.525
So a little hard to see,
but it's changing that one.

377
00:19:30.525 --> 00:19:32.385
And so I can tell it to Force Quit,

378
00:19:32.385 --> 00:19:36.850
even if it's the first time that I'm doing
it and then I can relaunch terminal.

379
00:19:36.850 --> 00:19:39.900
It'll try to recover that session and
put me right back where I was.

380
00:19:39.900 --> 00:19:42.580
So a couple of different ways if
an application is going crazy but

381
00:19:42.580 --> 00:19:47.830
that fixes the symptom, not the cause,
so why did the application go crazy.

382
00:19:47.830 --> 00:19:49.251
I might need to reinstall it.

383
00:19:49.251 --> 00:19:52.996
I might need to delete the application and
reinstall it or find out what happened,

384
00:19:52.996 --> 00:19:55.071
dig through my system logs and
other things.

385
00:19:55.071 --> 00:19:58.065
And for that, you want to jump over
to our troubleshooting episodes.

386
00:19:58.065 --> 00:20:01.210
They are at the end of the series and
we walk through how to troubleshoot

387
00:20:01.210 --> 00:20:04.570
applications and a few other things to
try and figure out what went wrong and

388
00:20:04.570 --> 00:20:07.360
get that system back up and going.
>> Well, speaking of troubleshooting,

389
00:20:07.360 --> 00:20:09.650
is there any way to find
out why the app went rogue?

390
00:20:09.650 --> 00:20:10.800
>> All right, so

391
00:20:10.800 --> 00:20:15.040
if I was left to my own devices and
I had to figure out what happened,

392
00:20:15.040 --> 00:20:18.860
the application itself might give you
an error but a lot of times they don't.

393
00:20:18.860 --> 00:20:23.200
So that's normally where I'm going to
jump to a utility called the console.

394
00:20:23.200 --> 00:20:27.230
Console is found inside of
/applications/utilities and

395
00:20:27.230 --> 00:20:31.840
it is a log,
a log of what's going on on your system.

396
00:20:31.840 --> 00:20:34.770
And I know we've brought this up
in some other episodes as well but

397
00:20:34.770 --> 00:20:37.280
you can see what those
applications are doing.

398
00:20:37.280 --> 00:20:41.530
And if there was an error, if there was a
fault of some sort, it'll show up in here.

399
00:20:41.530 --> 00:20:46.350
Now some applications are really good
about maintaining their own log files, so

400
00:20:46.350 --> 00:20:50.060
if you browse around in here,
you might be able to find where has it's

401
00:20:50.060 --> 00:20:54.240
own separate log file but
if it doesn't, then it's just gonna

402
00:20:54.240 --> 00:20:57.160
be integrated with the rest of
the logs and let the search for it.

403
00:20:57.160 --> 00:20:59.168
So, if I look under /Library and

404
00:20:59.168 --> 00:21:03.115
/Logs here I find a Microsoft is
separating out their own logs and

405
00:21:03.115 --> 00:21:08.313
that's nice cuz now I can find them in one
place but plenty of other programs aren't.

406
00:21:08.313 --> 00:21:11.020
Pulse SMS level,
text message program I use.

407
00:21:11.020 --> 00:21:14.970
A few other things here showing
up under my logs but that's it.

408
00:21:14.970 --> 00:21:18.540
So other applications like
the terminal aren't showing up there.

409
00:21:18.540 --> 00:21:23.470
So when we first pull this up,
it might be too much information.

410
00:21:23.470 --> 00:21:25.910
So up top,
you can use this search field and

411
00:21:25.910 --> 00:21:29.800
you can type in whatever the application
name is that you're having a problem with.

412
00:21:29.800 --> 00:21:31.530
And you can search based on that.

413
00:21:31.530 --> 00:21:33.324
And it'll look and try and find it.

414
00:21:33.324 --> 00:21:36.058
Be aware that you might
have the casing wrong,

415
00:21:36.058 --> 00:21:39.190
like capital letter
versus lower case letter.

416
00:21:39.190 --> 00:21:43.340
The name of the program might be wrong,
things like that.

417
00:21:43.340 --> 00:21:45.170
So you might need to
tweak it a little bit.

418
00:21:45.170 --> 00:21:47.950
A lot of times, I'll come in and
just search for the word error.

419
00:21:47.950 --> 00:21:50.170
Because hey, who knows what
the application might be called,

420
00:21:50.170 --> 00:21:52.620
I'll search for error and
see if I can find that and

421
00:21:52.620 --> 00:21:56.580
you can get information that way and
start to find out what's going on.

422
00:21:56.580 --> 00:21:59.430
I've got some kind of decoding
completed with errors message up here.

423
00:21:59.430 --> 00:22:03.060
So I can look and
possibly get some more information and

424
00:22:03.060 --> 00:22:04.630
figure what the cause of that problem is.

425
00:22:04.630 --> 00:22:09.140
So the console utility, really handy for
trying to find what the actual cause of

426
00:22:09.140 --> 00:22:11.910
your problem was.
>> And another great episode,

427
00:22:11.910 --> 00:22:13.510
Application Support Part Three.

428
00:22:13.510 --> 00:22:16.420
Make sure you see parts one,
two and three, importante.

429
00:22:16.420 --> 00:22:17.588
And before we move on, Don,

430
00:22:17.588 --> 00:22:19.417
anything else you'd like to say?
>> All right,

431
00:22:19.417 --> 00:22:21.890
we definitely started to weigh in to
the troubleshooting models there.

432
00:22:21.890 --> 00:22:23.650
So make sure you check out
the troubleshooting episodes.

433
00:22:23.650 --> 00:22:24.450
But otherwise,

434
00:22:24.450 --> 00:22:28.440
I think we did a good job of covering
the weird applications that occur.

435
00:22:28.440 --> 00:22:31.550
Obviously, there's even
weirder ones that are just so

436
00:22:31.550 --> 00:22:33.640
edge case that we don't worry about.

437
00:22:33.640 --> 00:22:36.070
Your mileage may vary but

438
00:22:36.070 --> 00:22:38.770
I think we cover them pretty
much in the order of occurence.

439
00:22:38.770 --> 00:22:43.910
Java, pretty common, iCloud integration
becoming more common, voice integration,

440
00:22:43.910 --> 00:22:47.540
pretty common, once we get into things
like the sand boxing and so on.

441
00:22:47.540 --> 00:22:49.450
It's common but
we don't usually have problems with it.

442
00:22:49.450 --> 00:22:52.942
So each of these were exceptions
as to how applications work and

443
00:22:52.942 --> 00:22:54.510
hopefully you have a better idea of this.

444
00:22:54.510 --> 00:22:58.220
So when you see odd behavior it a program,
now you can match it up

445
00:22:58.220 --> 00:23:00.619
to why it's behaving that way.
>> Great job as usual Don.

446
00:23:00.619 --> 00:23:02.604
You wanna make sure you
watch every episode of

447
00:23:02.604 --> 00:23:05.906
Apple Certified Support Professional,
you're gonna be so glad you did.

448
00:23:05.906 --> 00:23:09.654
And you'll be in the course library where
there's other videos there designed to do

449
00:23:09.654 --> 00:23:12.840
one thing, help you go further,
so check those out as well.

450
00:23:12.840 --> 00:23:16.320
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
ITProTV is binge worthy.

451
00:23:16.320 --> 00:23:18.481
Thanks for watching I'm Zach Memos.

>> Thank you for watching ITPro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don takes a dive into network configuration in macOS 10.13. He begins by exploring physical and wireless network connections. Next he introduces you to the protocols and addressing used to create network connections. This includes TCP/IP, IPv4, IPv6, and MAC.
episodes.title: Network Configuration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.495
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.495 --> 00:00:03.079

Apple Certified Support Professional,

we are going to be doing network
configuration with the one and only,

12

>> [LAUGH] All right-

13
00:00:28.964 --> 00:00:29.633
>> There was no drum roll.

14

16

>> [LAUGH]

17

>> [LAUGH] All right, well,

18
00:00:35.148 --> 00:00:39.000
just like Zach said, we are doing
network configuration in this episode.

19
00:00:39.000 --> 00:00:42.650
I know that I said in some of
the earlier episodes that by and

20
00:00:42.650 --> 00:00:45.320
large macOS automatically
configured your network so

21
00:00:45.320 --> 00:00:46.880
you don't have to do
a whole heck of a lot.

22
00:00:46.880 --> 00:00:51.440
But that is not always true, especially
when you're dealing with enterprise or

23
00:00:51.440 --> 00:00:54.300
large business type networks,
universities,

24
00:00:54.300 --> 00:00:57.930
there often is a bit of configuration we
have to do to get our network set up.

25
00:00:57.930 --> 00:01:01.910
And so, in this episode, we're gonna take
a look at what network configuration looks

26
00:01:01.910 --> 00:01:04.740
like, what the different things
are that we need to be aware of.

27
00:01:04.740 --> 00:01:07.230
How addressing works, and
even basic network communications.

28
00:01:07.230 --> 00:01:11.380
Now, if you've already, let's say,
you're Network+ certified,

29
00:01:11.380 --> 00:01:14.590
then a lot of this stuff you're
already going to know, but

30
00:01:14.590 --> 00:01:18.110
we need to cover at least the basics here
to make sure that everybody is exam ready.

31
00:01:18.110 --> 00:01:21.032
On the exam, they expect you to
understand how addressing works and

32
00:01:21.032 --> 00:01:21.912
a few other things.

33
00:01:21.912 --> 00:01:24.644
Not just, here is where I
go to Internet address, but

34
00:01:24.644 --> 00:01:26.790
understand why the address is what it is.

35
00:01:26.790 --> 00:01:28.605
And so we're gonna cover all of that,

36
00:01:28.605 --> 00:01:32.166
starting right here in this episode.
>> So Don, what type of network

37
00:01:32.166 --> 00:01:35.923
connections does macOS support?
>> All right, now that is part of why

38
00:01:35.923 --> 00:01:39.901
this is so complex, because macOS supports
many different types of networks.

39
00:01:39.901 --> 00:01:43.051
And for most people,
there is going to be one big one,

40
00:01:43.051 --> 00:01:46.559
which is a wifi network,
right, Wi-Fi or 802.11.

41
00:01:46.559 --> 00:01:51.060
Let me clarify that,
an IEEE 802.11 wireless network.

42
00:01:51.060 --> 00:01:54.840
Those are wireless networks that
are standardized by the IEEE.

43
00:01:54.840 --> 00:01:59.895
That is an international organization
that creates, well, standards.

44
00:01:59.895 --> 00:02:02.229
It's an organization of
electrical engineers,

45
00:02:02.229 --> 00:02:03.954
I forget what all of the Es stand for.

46
00:02:03.954 --> 00:02:07.971
But basically they say, here is
a standard method of communication,

47
00:02:07.971 --> 00:02:10.664
the two systems are gonna use to talk.

48
00:02:10.664 --> 00:02:13.522
And those Wi-Fi networks
are wildly popular,

49
00:02:13.522 --> 00:02:16.524
people use them at home,
at work, at Starbucks,

50
00:02:16.524 --> 00:02:20.965
at the sports stadium, all over
the place you see those Wi-Fi networks.

51
00:02:20.965 --> 00:02:24.400
That is the number one way that
we're going to communicate.

52
00:02:24.400 --> 00:02:27.590
In fact, when you buy a Mac,
some of the newer Macs,

53
00:02:27.590 --> 00:02:31.710
the Wi-Fi network is the only thing they
have built into them, that's the way.

54
00:02:31.710 --> 00:02:36.365
But there are still plenty of
macs like Mac Minis and iMac, and

55
00:02:36.365 --> 00:02:41.010
Mac Pros, that still have ethernet or
physical network jacks on them,

56
00:02:41.010 --> 00:02:44.280
so you can plug in that link and
get connected that way.

57
00:02:44.280 --> 00:02:46.610
That's gonna give you the most stable and

58
00:02:46.610 --> 00:02:50.140
fastest communication which is really
good, but it's becoming less and

59
00:02:50.140 --> 00:02:53.490
less common, because, well,
you gotta run a cable.

60
00:02:53.490 --> 00:02:54.520
So for example,

61
00:02:54.520 --> 00:02:58.810
my MacBook is a newer MacBook, it doesn't
even have a physical network jack on it.

62
00:02:58.810 --> 00:03:00.170
I can't plug a cable in.

63
00:03:00.170 --> 00:03:01.330
I'd have to get an adapter,

64
00:03:01.330 --> 00:03:03.780
just stick that on there which
you certainly can, right.

65
00:03:03.780 --> 00:03:05.690
Those are available.

66
00:03:05.690 --> 00:03:09.120
There's also some of the older
standards like FireWire.

67
00:03:09.120 --> 00:03:12.010
FireWire is still supported by macOS.

68
00:03:12.010 --> 00:03:18.480
Although I don't think any Mac sold
today has a FireWire jack on it anymore.

69
00:03:18.480 --> 00:03:20.280
So we are seeing FireWire go away.

70
00:03:20.280 --> 00:03:22.540
It's being replaced
largely by Thunderbolt.

71
00:03:22.540 --> 00:03:27.450
And Thunderbolt is a, well, I always
think of Thunderbolt as storage, like,

72
00:03:27.450 --> 00:03:29.460
hey, I've got a Thunderbolt hard drive,
I'll pop it on there.

73
00:03:29.460 --> 00:03:32.390
Or a display, a monitor,
that uses Thunderbolt and

74
00:03:32.390 --> 00:03:36.040
I'll plug that in, but
Thunderbolt can do networking as well.

75
00:03:36.040 --> 00:03:37.790
We can actually communicate across it.

76
00:03:37.790 --> 00:03:40.000
So it's yet another network type.

77
00:03:40.000 --> 00:03:41.640
Who else am I leaving out?

78
00:03:41.640 --> 00:03:43.770
A big one here, Bluetooth.
>> Mm-hm.

79
00:03:43.770 --> 00:03:44.940
>> Bluetooth, which

80
00:03:44.940 --> 00:03:48.350
you might connect a keyboard,
a mouse, your cellphone.

81
00:03:48.350 --> 00:03:51.263
You might tether your cellphone
to your laptop, with Bluetooth.

82
00:03:51.263 --> 00:03:54.870
Bluetooth is a networking connection type.

83
00:03:54.870 --> 00:03:58.500
It's different than an 802.11 network
in the way that it functions, Bluetooth

84
00:03:58.500 --> 00:04:02.680
functions on a different frequency, and
so that's yet another network type.

85
00:04:02.680 --> 00:04:06.880
All of these are different networks that
are all natively supported by macOS.

86
00:04:06.880 --> 00:04:10.780
So when you go in to configure your
network, you may see one, or two, or

87
00:04:10.780 --> 00:04:15.664
all of the ones that I just mentioned.
>> Are they all configured the same way?

88
00:04:15.664 --> 00:04:17.280
>> Sometimes, yes.

89
00:04:17.280 --> 00:04:17.870
Sometimes, no.

90
00:04:17.870 --> 00:04:20.990
So there's a couple different
protocols that are out there.

91
00:04:20.990 --> 00:04:22.750
When you communicate over the network,

92
00:04:22.750 --> 00:04:24.990
I don't wanna go too crazy into
the technical details, but

93
00:04:24.990 --> 00:04:29.680
there's this whole seven layer OSIM model
that gets kind of thrown into the frame.

94
00:04:29.680 --> 00:04:32.650
And at the very first layer,
you're talking about the hardware.

95
00:04:32.650 --> 00:04:35.460
So, if it's a physical network,
you've got a copper cable.

96
00:04:35.460 --> 00:04:36.630
If it's a wireless network,

97
00:04:36.630 --> 00:04:40.130
you've got a wireless antenna and
that's what makes up that first layer.

98
00:04:40.130 --> 00:04:43.760
And the second layer is the basic
addressing that you use to communicate.

99
00:04:43.760 --> 00:04:49.960
And so, in a Wi-Fi network that
would be the 802.11 A-B-G-N-A-C.

100
00:04:52.440 --> 00:04:53.612
Seems like I left one out.

101
00:04:53.612 --> 00:04:58.635
Anyhow, one of those crazy wireless
standards on a copper network,

102
00:04:58.635 --> 00:05:01.240
it would be the ethernet protocol.

103
00:05:01.240 --> 00:05:02.915
That's what happens at layer two.

104
00:05:02.915 --> 00:05:06.717
And then when you get to layer three,
though, that's where things start

105
00:05:06.717 --> 00:05:10.290
to become the same across all
of the different network types.

106
00:05:10.290 --> 00:05:16.410
So for example the most common
network protocol on the entire planet,

107
00:05:16.410 --> 00:05:20.320
is a protocol called IP,
the Internet Protocol, right?

108
00:05:20.320 --> 00:05:24.657
IP, actually there's 2 different versions
right now, there's IP version 4 and

109
00:05:24.657 --> 00:05:25.460
IP version 6.

110
00:05:25.460 --> 00:05:31.927
And it is supported across bluetooth,
Wi-Fi, ethernet, fiber.

111
00:05:31.927 --> 00:05:33.370
I didn't even mention fiber a minute ago.

112
00:05:33.370 --> 00:05:34.548
You'll see fiber in some networks.

113
00:05:34.548 --> 00:05:38.391
It usually is running ethernet, though,
so it kind of gets grouped together.

114
00:05:38.391 --> 00:05:41.912
But you see IP used in
a lot of different places.

115
00:05:41.912 --> 00:05:43.300
IP stands for Internet Protocol.

116
00:05:43.300 --> 00:05:48.270
It was designed for the Internet, but
it's used in a lot of other areas.

117
00:05:48.270 --> 00:05:51.850
So when you tether your cell phone
to your laptop using Bluetooth,

118
00:05:51.850 --> 00:05:55.910
it's actually using an IP network
between the two to talk, to communicate.

119
00:05:55.910 --> 00:05:59.260
When you fire up your laptop and

120
00:05:59.260 --> 00:06:03.440
you connect to a Time Capsule on your
network to do Time Machine backups,

121
00:06:03.440 --> 00:06:06.920
it's using an IP network to communicate,
to talk back and forth.

122
00:06:06.920 --> 00:06:10.671
So that's used across them and
that is considered really set up the same,

123
00:06:10.671 --> 00:06:13.225
even though the network
type might be different.

124
00:06:13.225 --> 00:06:16.181
But there are other protocols
that are out there, right?

125
00:06:16.181 --> 00:06:18.812
Apple used to use a protocol
called AppleTalk.

126
00:06:18.812 --> 00:06:22.283
And AppleTalk is set up
differently than IP.

127
00:06:22.283 --> 00:06:28.181
So AppleTalk was designed just for Apple
networks, IP was designed for everything.

128
00:06:28.181 --> 00:06:32.523
There's NetBIOS which was used
in Microsoft or Windows worlds.

129
00:06:32.523 --> 00:06:36.258
And NetBIOS is actually supported by
a number of platforms including macOS.

130
00:06:36.258 --> 00:06:40.234
You won't see it in the GUI, but
in the background support is still there,

131
00:06:40.234 --> 00:06:43.093
Apple's maintained
the backwards compatibility.

132
00:06:43.093 --> 00:06:46.453
There's other ones like VPNs,
Virtual Private Networks and

133
00:06:46.453 --> 00:06:47.883
even dialogue networks.

134
00:06:47.883 --> 00:06:50.045
People still use dialogue and
there is PPP,

483

episodes.description: In this episode, Don takes a dive into network configuration in macOS 10.13. He begins by exploring physical and wireless network connections. Next he introduces you to the protocols and addressing used to create network connections. This includes TCP/IP, IPv4, IPv6, and MAC.

00:01:12.420 --> 00:01:16.170
>> And Don, how does a wireless

28
00:01:16.170 --> 00:01:18.614
All right, so it's almost a,

it differs really just in a couple areas

all the stuff we talked about in the last

WiFi.

32

The primary difference is that there's
not a physical cable plugged in.

33
00:01:36.510 --> 00:01:39.147
It's just a signal that's being
thrown out into the air, right?

34
00:01:39.147 --> 00:01:42.284
Slowly irradiating us and
leading us to our death.

35
00:01:42.284 --> 00:01:44.031
>> [LAUGH]
>> But allowing us to get to YouTube,

36
00:01:44.031 --> 00:01:45.098
which is important.

37
00:01:45.098 --> 00:01:47.451
So, [LAUGH]
>> There's important, [LAUGH]

38
00:01:47.451 --> 00:01:49.440
>> WiFi has no boundaries, right?

39
00:01:49.440 --> 00:01:51.700
That's the big difference, right?

40
00:01:51.700 --> 00:01:53.200
I know that if I have a copper cable.

41
00:01:53.200 --> 00:01:55.300

42

00:01:57.830 --> 00:01:59.869
And there's no real way to confuse that.

44
00:01:59.869 --> 00:02:03.330
With WiFi though there could
be eight different networks.

45
00:02:03.330 --> 00:02:07.390
And I can't tell if I'm plugged in or
not, because it's just wireless.

46
00:02:07.390 --> 00:02:11.470
There's little, protons or
something floating around in the air.

47
00:02:11.470 --> 00:02:15.470
That's the wrong term,
I don't know what the heck they are but.

48
00:02:15.470 --> 00:02:16.150
>> Frequencies.

49
00:02:16.150 --> 00:02:18.720
>> Magical waves in the air, frequencies?

50
00:02:18.720 --> 00:02:19.390
>> Maybe, I don't know.

51
00:02:19.390 --> 00:02:20.630
>> All right, well something.

52
00:02:20.630 --> 00:02:24.370
So, anyway this stuff is passing
through the air and I can't tell.

53
00:02:24.370 --> 00:02:27.650
I could be connected to the wrong network,
might not know it, right?

54
00:02:27.650 --> 00:02:31.016
That's a risk that we don't
have with a wired network.

55
00:02:31.016 --> 00:02:34.692
In the WiFi world, they solved that
through a few means, the main means is

56
00:02:34.692 --> 00:02:38.092
through making it where we have to
choose to turn our controller on.

57
00:02:38.092 --> 00:02:40.612
We have to connect to these networks.

58
00:02:40.612 --> 00:02:43.220
So make sure you wanna mean by
that when I say turn it on.

59
00:02:43.220 --> 00:02:48.740
If I go into my system preferences, and in
my system preferences I go into network.

60
00:02:48.740 --> 00:02:50.700
Inside of network,

61
00:02:50.700 --> 00:02:55.190
I wanna show you guys the difference

62
00:02:55.190 --> 00:02:59.270

63

Is it DHCP, is it static?

64
00:03:00.840 --> 00:03:01.800
What's your DNS server?

65
00:03:01.800 --> 00:03:03.920
These are things that we know we need.

66
00:03:03.920 --> 00:03:08.590
If I go to the Wi-Fi side, it's not
asking me about an IP address at all.

67
00:03:08.590 --> 00:03:12.980
It's asking me, should the wireless
antenna be turned on or off?

68
00:03:12.980 --> 00:03:16.770
And if it's on, what network
should I be connected to, okay?

69
00:03:16.770 --> 00:03:19.730
Those are the settings that
it is presenting to me here.

70
00:03:19.730 --> 00:03:23.750
And that's because with Wi-Fi, we don't
know what networks are gonna be out there.

71
00:03:23.750 --> 00:03:27.890
And it's not a matter of, they plugged
in a cable, they must want to be on.

72
00:03:27.890 --> 00:03:33.070
We might see eight networks out there, and

73
00:03:33.070 --> 00:03:34.613
We don't wanna connect that one.

74
00:03:34.613 --> 00:03:36.889
How does a Mac know that's malicious?

75
00:03:36.889 --> 00:03:39.730
It doesn't, so
it has to be leave that up to us.

76
00:03:39.730 --> 00:03:42.550
When you do the initial install of Mac OS

77
00:03:42.550 --> 00:03:45.090
if it sees a wireless network it
can give you a chance to join it.

78
00:03:45.090 --> 00:03:46.430
As you might want to set it up.

79
00:03:46.430 --> 00:03:48.450
But I got a laptop, I travel.

00:03:48.450 --> 00:03:49.500
I go to hotel, or school, or

00:03:49.500 --> 00:03:52.750
something more like that, I need to

82
00:03:52.750 --> 00:03:56.480
So I can come in here, and
I can drop down this box and

00:03:56.480 --> 00:03:58.552

00:03:58.552 --> 00:04:03.340

00:04:03.340 --> 00:04:06.670

00:04:06.670 --> 00:04:09.230
And then I've got some I don't
really recognize, right?

87
00:04:09.230 --> 00:04:11.283
Gainesville Dev Academy or
ExceptionalDentistry,

00:04:11.283 --> 00:04:12.884
these are businesses that are around us.

89
00:04:12.884 --> 00:04:13.860
>> Right.

90
00:04:13.860 --> 00:04:18.440
>> And those might be perfectly safe
networks, but they're not my network.

91
00:04:18.440 --> 00:04:21.715
If I try to connect to one, if I try to
connect to ExceptionalDentistry, let's go.

92
00:04:21.715 --> 00:04:23.220
>> O-oh.

93
00:04:23.220 --> 00:04:26.250
>> It's gonna ask for a password, right,
or hopefully it asked for password,

00:04:26.250 --> 00:04:28.440
not everything does,

95
00:04:28.440 --> 00:04:32.672
Let's see, I cancel out,
>> But the password there is Goodtooth.

96
00:04:32.672 --> 00:04:34.186
>> [LAUGH] Or Badtooth you never know.

97
00:04:34.186 --> 00:04:35.329
>> Yeah, it could be, you're right.

98
00:04:35.329 --> 00:04:38.700
>> So these are all secured,
see the little lock on them?

99
00:04:38.700 --> 00:04:42.370
But it could be public Wi-Fi,
one that doesn't have a lock,

100
00:04:42.370 --> 00:04:45.580
that's just sitting right there,
you can connect to and jump right on it.

101
00:04:45.580 --> 00:04:48.881
Well, the Mac is waiting for
you to choose to get connected,

102
00:04:48.881 --> 00:04:50.714
and once you pick you can jump on.

103
00:04:50.714 --> 00:04:55.152
Once you've connected a single time from
then on anytime you power on your system

00:04:55.152 --> 00:04:58.820
it's gonna go in and connect, and
it just pops on automatically.

105
00:04:58.820 --> 00:05:00.860
We don't have to worry about it, but

106
00:05:00.860 --> 00:05:06.370
if it is a secure network you at least
have to provide that password one time.

107
00:05:06.370 --> 00:05:09.500
And once you've done that, that
password gets stored in your keychain,

108
00:05:09.500 --> 00:05:11.420
which we don't really see

109
00:05:11.420 --> 00:05:14.830
If I go into Advanced, under Advanced,

110
00:05:14.830 --> 00:05:18.905
there's a list of all these WiFi
networks that I've connected to.

111
00:05:18.905 --> 00:05:19.520
>> Mm-hm.

112
00:05:19.520 --> 00:05:23.150
>> And the keys that are stored
alongside them, right?

113
00:05:23.150 --> 00:05:25.200
So it's keeping track of those keys.

114
00:05:25.200 --> 00:05:31.280
So if I ever go back out to wherever
CenturyLink1588 is, I have no idea.

00:05:31.280 --> 00:05:34.470
But if I ever go back out there,
it's got the key stored in my keychain.

116
00:05:34.470 --> 00:05:38.090
It'll reconnect and I can pop right on and
get onto the network.

117
00:05:38.090 --> 00:05:39.460
I don't have to provide it over and over.

118
00:05:39.460 --> 00:05:41.920
I just have to provide it that one
>> Well,

where do the credentials come from though?

00:05:44.550 --> 00:05:47.452
>> That password it comes from

00:05:47.452 --> 00:05:51.189
I can't remember CentralLink1588,

00:05:51.189 --> 00:05:52.202

00:05:52.202 --> 00:05:57.570
So at home that's the network that I

00:05:57.570 --> 00:06:00.370
Man, that's my password, and

Exactly, you come over to the house and

00:06:03.720 --> 00:06:07.010
I'll tell you right, you gotta go to

00:06:07.010 --> 00:06:10.338
If you go to Starbucks,

00:06:10.338 --> 00:06:13.391
So they don't set a password,
that it's just open you can connect and

129
00:06:13.391 --> 00:06:14.660
it's no big deal.

130
00:06:14.660 --> 00:06:18.130
But if it's a private network you've

131
00:06:18.130 --> 00:06:22.960
Now, if you are setting up laptops
you're a support professional.

132
00:06:22.960 --> 00:06:24.760

00:06:24.760 --> 00:06:28.353

00:06:28.353 --> 00:06:33.250

00:06:33.250 --> 00:06:34.760

00:06:34.760 --> 00:06:38.070

00:06:38.070 --> 00:06:41.320

00:06:41.320 --> 00:06:44.990
And you can add a network that
you've never even seen yet, right?

139
00:06:44.990 --> 00:06:47.800
So maybe this is the ITProTV-Beta, right?

140
00:06:49.010 --> 00:06:51.340
And I can tell yeah, that's a WPA2 key.

141
00:06:52.630 --> 00:06:56.595
And the password is password123, right?

00:06:56.595 --> 00:06:57.595
We punch that in.

143
00:06:57.595 --> 00:06:58.100
>> Mm-hm.

00:06:58.100 --> 00:06:59.300

00:06:59.300 --> 00:07:03.842
And now, that's gonna be added in

00:07:03.842 --> 00:07:07.915
It's on that list and
now whenever I see the network pop-up,

00:07:07.915 --> 00:07:12.790
I can connect instead of giving
the credentials ahead of time.

148
00:07:12.790 --> 00:07:15.470
Now those credentials right
there are really simple,

149
00:07:15.470 --> 00:07:16.770
it's just a password, right?

150
00:07:16.770 --> 00:07:20.546
They sometimes refer to as a PSK or
a Pre-Shared Key.

151
00:07:20.546 --> 00:07:25.830
A Pre-Shared Key,
it's good cuz it's easy, but it's bad

152
00:07:25.830 --> 00:07:31.450
in that if everybody at a particular
school is using the same password.

153
00:07:31.450 --> 00:07:34.350

some bad stuff, and so we say no,

00:07:34.350 --> 00:07:35.540

155
00:07:35.540 --> 00:07:39.130
We can't,
cuz everybody is using the same password.

156
00:07:39.130 --> 00:07:40.120
What if I change the password?

157
00:07:40.120 --> 00:07:44.250
Now everybody is gonna change
the password, that's not effective.

158
00:07:44.250 --> 00:07:46.260
So in enterprise environments,

159
00:07:46.260 --> 00:07:51.160

certificates for authentication.

160
00:07:51.160 --> 00:07:52.951
I mentioned 802.1X authentication
in the last episode.

161
00:07:52.951 --> 00:07:54.172
>> Mm-hm.

162
00:07:54.172 --> 00:07:54.990
>> That's certificate-based.

163
00:07:54.990 --> 00:07:57.436
So let me go back in here, and
I'm gonna take that ITProTV-Beta, and

164
00:07:57.436 --> 00:07:59.230
let me just remove that.

165
00:07:59.230 --> 00:08:05.140
So it's gone, and
I'm gonna add it back here, ITProTV-Beta.

166
00:08:05.140 --> 00:08:08.260
And under Security, I pick WPA2 Personal.

167
00:08:08.260 --> 00:08:11.807
I tell this personal ones,
those are Pre-Shared Keys, the Passwords.

168
00:08:11.807 --> 00:08:16.320
But if we go a little further,
you are at Enterprise, right?

169
00:08:16.320 --> 00:08:19.420
Enterprises, they are not
gonna use a password,

170
00:08:19.420 --> 00:08:23.130
they are going to use 802.1X certificates.

171
00:08:23.130 --> 00:08:26.250
And that's all handle to the extensible
authentication protocol or EAP.

172
00:08:27.420 --> 00:08:30.584
TLS is Transport Layer Security,
you don't need to know that for the exam.

173
00:08:30.584 --> 00:08:32.172
But you can come in, and

174
00:08:32.172 --> 00:08:36.394
you can pick a certificate that
you have issued to your system.

175
00:08:36.394 --> 00:08:39.154
And if the administrator has
approved your certificate,

176
00:08:39.154 --> 00:08:41.923
