Work, those are my two locations.

267
00:13:31.350 --> 00:13:35.998
And so under Travel, I'm gonna come in and
add a new network adapter.

268
00:13:35.998 --> 00:13:39.150
And the adaptor I'm gonna
add is a VPN adaptor.

269
00:13:39.150 --> 00:13:45.160
When you choose VPN, the configuration for
VPN is actually pretty hard.

270
00:13:45.160 --> 00:13:46.210
Whoever set up the server,

271
00:13:46.210 --> 00:13:51.480
they've got a lot of choices they can
make and there's no one set standard.

272
00:13:51.480 --> 00:13:55.070
I can't tell you, 99% of the time
these are gonna be the settings.

273
00:13:55.070 --> 00:13:56.982
Because it's up to
whoever set up your VPN.

274
00:13:56.982 --> 00:14:00.140
If you're the one who set it up,
you should know all this information.

275
00:14:00.140 --> 00:14:03.730
So, for example,
there are numerous types of VPNs, and

276
00:14:03.730 --> 00:14:05.240
you'll see that here on the list.

277
00:14:05.240 --> 00:14:08.388
When I choose VPN,
it immediately asks for a VPN type.

278
00:14:08.388 --> 00:14:12.066
And I've got three different options here,

279
00:14:12.066 --> 00:14:16.920
L2TP over IPsec, CISCO IPsec and
IKEv2, all right?

280
00:14:16.920 --> 00:14:19.390
Each one of these are related.

281
00:14:19.390 --> 00:14:21.760
Actually all three of
these are using IPsec.

282
00:14:21.760 --> 00:14:24.580
IPsec stands for
Internet Protocol Security.

283
00:14:24.580 --> 00:14:28.530
And it's a way of encrypting our
IP traffic across the network.

284
00:14:28.530 --> 00:14:30.083
But there's different
implementations of it.

285
00:14:30.083 --> 00:14:36.500
The first one, L2TP, that's layer
2 tunneling protocol over IPSec.

286
00:14:36.500 --> 00:14:40.030
Layer 2 tunneling protocol was originally
developed for Microsoft environments.

287
00:14:40.030 --> 00:14:45.199
So if I'm connecting into
a Microsoft VPN server, I'll use L2TP.

288
00:14:45.199 --> 00:14:47.992
Now there's a lot of third
parties that support L2TP also,

289
00:14:47.992 --> 00:14:49.590
it's not just Microsoft.

290
00:14:49.590 --> 00:14:53.580
But most of them have moved away from
it because L2TP is kind of cloggy.

291
00:14:54.840 --> 00:15:00.430
Cisco is the market leader for networking
technologies that are out there.

292
00:15:00.430 --> 00:15:03.080
They have their own
implementation of IPsec, and so

293
00:15:03.080 --> 00:15:05.740
Cisco IPsec is an option right here.

294
00:15:05.740 --> 00:15:10.376
Technically that would be IKE version
one when you chose Cisco IPsec.

295
00:15:10.376 --> 00:15:14.030
And if I choose L2TP, see it's not
really asking me any questions,

296
00:15:14.030 --> 00:15:16.928
if I chose Cisco IPSec it's
not asking any questions,

297
00:15:16.928 --> 00:15:21.860
it's gonna ask questions in a moment
as far as how I need to configure that.

298
00:15:21.860 --> 00:15:24.950
The third option though I will tell
you is the most common today, and

299
00:15:24.950 --> 00:15:29.010
that's because it's IKEv2,
it's the strongest of the three.

300
00:15:29.010 --> 00:15:31.457
IKE stands for Internetwork Key Exchange.

301
00:15:31.457 --> 00:15:36.220
And with Internetwork Key Exchange
you connect to a VPN server and

302
00:15:36.220 --> 00:15:40.740
the VPN server can communicate to you,
hey, we need a key strength of this size.

303
00:15:40.740 --> 00:15:44.093
You gotta have this password, you gotta
have this other hashing algorithm,

304
00:15:44.093 --> 00:15:47.306
these are all the thing you've gotta
have to meet our security policies.

305
00:15:47.306 --> 00:15:49.862
IKE is all about defining a policy.

306
00:15:49.862 --> 00:15:53.526
So that process is the most
powerful with IKEv2, so

307
00:15:53.526 --> 00:15:56.623
that's the one you're gonna see the most.

308
00:15:56.623 --> 00:16:01.610
But the other two are still perfectly
viable, you'll see them out there.

309
00:16:01.610 --> 00:16:02.690
There's others,

310
00:16:02.690 --> 00:16:06.200
like you might hear people talk about
PPTP, point to point tunneling protocol.

311
00:16:06.200 --> 00:16:10.180
PPTP is probably the most compatible,

312
00:16:10.180 --> 00:16:12.860
it works with the most
systems that are out there.

313
00:16:12.860 --> 00:16:15.206
But now that I've said that,
if it's the most compatible,

314
00:16:15.206 --> 00:16:16.264
why isn't it in this list?

315
00:16:16.264 --> 00:16:21.180
That's because PPTP uses weak encryption
and it's been shown that it can be broken.

316
00:16:21.180 --> 00:16:23.190
You don't wanna use a protocol
that's not safe, so

317
00:16:23.190 --> 00:16:24.810
Apple doesn't even put it in the list.

318
00:16:24.810 --> 00:16:27.580
If you wanna do PPTP,
you gotta drop to the command line and

319
00:16:27.580 --> 00:16:29.890
actually get it set up or
use a third party client,

320
00:16:29.890 --> 00:16:31.770
which is just not recommended.
>> No.

321
00:16:31.770 --> 00:16:33.764
>> So, I could use IKEv2, and

322
00:16:33.764 --> 00:16:37.920
when I choose Create,
it's gonna build that adapter, and

323
00:16:37.920 --> 00:16:41.085
see how it has that little padlock on it.
>> Mm-hm.

324
00:16:41.085 --> 00:16:42.331
>> Letting me know it's not

325
00:16:42.331 --> 00:16:45.654
a real adapter, it's a virtual adapter,
and now it's asking for

326
00:16:45.654 --> 00:16:47.720
the configuration settings.

327
00:16:47.720 --> 00:16:50.530
At a minimum,
I need a server to connect to, and

328
00:16:50.530 --> 00:16:53.770
then I need a remote ID and a local ID.

329
00:16:53.770 --> 00:16:55.290
It's gonna complain about
that server address.

330
00:16:56.430 --> 00:17:00.340
So let's say that I come in here and
I'll just make something up.

331
00:17:02.270 --> 00:17:06.473
Let's say I'm connecting to
vpn.itprotv.local, right, and

332
00:17:06.473 --> 00:17:09.923
I need a remote ID,
which a lot of times these remote and

333
00:17:09.923 --> 00:17:12.488
local IDs will be IP addresses, right?

334
00:17:12.488 --> 00:17:14.298
What is the IP range
of the remote network,

335
00:17:14.298 --> 00:17:17.540
what is the IP range of my local network,
so I've gotta know that.

336
00:17:17.540 --> 00:17:20.290
Or potentially it's just an identifier,

337
00:17:20.290 --> 00:17:25.430
a string that identifies you, so it might
even be for example like a username.

338
00:17:25.430 --> 00:17:27.560
What's the username of the server
that I'm connecting to, or

339
00:17:27.560 --> 00:17:30.630
the username that I'm using?

340
00:17:30.630 --> 00:17:35.720
So, I might have the vpnserver,
vpnuser, this depends.

341
00:17:35.720 --> 00:17:39.250
And again, I can't tell you, it's gonna be
an IP address, it's gonna be a username,

342
00:17:39.250 --> 00:17:41.100
because I don't know how
your system is set up.

343
00:17:41.100 --> 00:17:44.080
And it's gonna be really
determined on your end.

344
00:17:45.140 --> 00:17:48.710
Once those are set though, you can go to
authentication settings and here you can

345
00:17:48.710 --> 00:17:51.848
define the actual username and password
that the user is going to make use of.

346
00:17:51.848 --> 00:17:54.916
Or if they're doing certificate
based authentication, and

347
00:17:54.916 --> 00:17:56.595
you could pick the certificate.

348
00:17:56.595 --> 00:17:58.280
That's the strongest form but

349
00:17:58.280 --> 00:18:01.760
it requires issuing certs to all of
your users which some people don't like.

350
00:18:01.760 --> 00:18:04.490
So you might choose to go username and
password, so

351
00:18:04.490 --> 00:18:09.360
I can punch that in, and get that defined.

352
00:18:09.360 --> 00:18:13.270
All right, once you've got all that set,
now you've got a VPN.

353
00:18:13.270 --> 00:18:18.480
And to connect to the VPN, you could come
in here, you'll go to system preferences,

354
00:18:18.480 --> 00:18:23.490
network, choose the location,
choose the VPN, and hit Connect.

355
00:18:23.490 --> 00:18:26.030
But that's a lot of steps to go through,
so normally,

356
00:18:26.030 --> 00:18:30.280
we'll choose to show the VPN option in
the menu bar, I'm gonna turn that on.

357
00:18:30.280 --> 00:18:34.140
And the VPN icon, I'm not exactly
sure what that is supposed to be,

358
00:18:34.140 --> 00:18:37.482
this little box with bunch of lines in it,
nut once it's-

359
00:18:37.482 --> 00:18:39.780
>> It's a toaster pastry.

360
00:18:39.780 --> 00:18:40.444
>> I can see that.

361
00:18:40.444 --> 00:18:41.111
>> [LAUGH]

362
00:18:41.111 --> 00:18:42.000
>> It's like a Pop-Tart.

363
00:18:42.000 --> 00:18:44.914
All right, so we've got the highly
secure Pop-Tart up here.

364
00:18:44.914 --> 00:18:50.630
[LAUGH] And you were doing it the right
way and not violating a trademark.

365
00:18:50.630 --> 00:18:51.970
I'm throwing caution to the wind.
>> I know.

366
00:18:51.970 --> 00:18:53.081
>> So [LAUGH]

367
00:18:53.081 --> 00:18:54.270
>> Keep it generic.

368
00:18:54.270 --> 00:18:57.210
>> So I'm gonna click on the VPN toaster

369
00:18:57.210 --> 00:18:59.490
pastry and what you'll find is,

370
00:18:59.490 --> 00:19:01.870
well mine is saying VPN is not configured
cuz I haven't saved yet, right?

371
00:19:01.870 --> 00:19:04.594
So let me come down here and hit Apply,
this whole thing makes more sense when you

372
00:19:04.594 --> 00:19:05.218
hit Apply.
>> Yeah,

373
00:19:05.218 --> 00:19:07.929
that would work.
>> And then when I come up top,

374
00:19:07.929 --> 00:19:12.546
I can hit the toaster pastry and
now I can see connect VPN (IKEv2),

375
00:19:12.546 --> 00:19:14.545
right, and I can connect up.

376
00:19:14.545 --> 00:19:17.040
I can show the time connected and so on.

377
00:19:17.040 --> 00:19:19.100
That's gonna show up right
here on my menu bar,

378
00:19:19.100 --> 00:19:21.410
thanks to the VPN being defined down here.

379
00:19:21.410 --> 00:19:25.410
Now, if you just have
one configuration and

380
00:19:25.410 --> 00:19:28.100
one VPN, then it doesn't
make sense to use location.

381
00:19:28.100 --> 00:19:31.660
You just leave it automatic, and
have this VPN option show up in the bar.

382
00:19:31.660 --> 00:19:34.689
But if you've got multiple VPNs that you
use, then this becomes really handy.

383
00:19:34.689 --> 00:19:38.780
Because you can click on this,
you can choose the different ones,

384
00:19:38.780 --> 00:19:43.178
you can hide certain VPNs depending
on which location that you're in.

385
00:19:43.178 --> 00:19:46.780
You get a lot more control over
that all tucked away in here.

386
00:19:46.780 --> 00:19:50.490
Now I left mine called IKEv2
which I'm never gonna remember.

387
00:19:50.490 --> 00:19:55.010
So you can highlight that VPN and if you
click the little gear at the bottom,

388
00:19:55.010 --> 00:19:57.620
you'll see where you
can rename the service.

389
00:19:57.620 --> 00:20:02.160
And so
I might call this the ITProTV Studios VPN,

390
00:20:02.160 --> 00:20:06.184
can't believe I misspelled VPN, twice.

391
00:20:06.184 --> 00:20:08.310
So I'm gonna rename that so
I can remember it.

392
00:20:08.310 --> 00:20:11.960
That's a little more handy because now
when I come up here to the menu bar and

393
00:20:11.960 --> 00:20:14.780
I drop that down, shoot,
I haven't applied.

394
00:20:14.780 --> 00:20:18.340
Gotta remember to hit Apply,
but once we've done that,

395
00:20:18.340 --> 00:20:22.000
I can go to the menu bar and
now it says Connect ITProTV Studios VPN.

396
00:20:23.320 --> 00:20:29.430
It's a lot more intuitive than Connect
IKEv2, which an end user isn't gonna know.

397
00:20:29.430 --> 00:20:31.810
So those are a few little
tweaks that we can do.

398
00:20:31.810 --> 00:20:38.510
Now I've been showing you this using the
built in networking functionality, right?

399
00:20:38.510 --> 00:20:40.450
And on the exam,
that's what you're going to see, but

400
00:20:40.450 --> 00:20:43.380
let me give you a little
real world piece of advice.

401
00:20:43.380 --> 00:20:47.210
The built-in VPN client
here is fairly inflexible.

402
00:20:48.420 --> 00:20:51.020
Apple built it up really
to work with their

403
00:20:51.020 --> 00:20:53.240
VPN solution as part of the Server app.

404
00:20:53.240 --> 00:20:55.630
Apple has announced that
they're ending support for

405
00:20:55.630 --> 00:20:57.010
that in the next version
of the Server app.

406
00:20:57.010 --> 00:21:00.278
So if you're running
macOS 10.3 High Sierra,

407
00:21:00.278 --> 00:21:05.520
and you've got the server I've deployed,
you can use that VPN right now.

408
00:21:05.520 --> 00:21:10.683
But if you just watch this show and said,
wait, I can do a VPN, don't do Apple.

409
00:21:10.683 --> 00:21:13.934
If this is a new deployment don't do Apple
cuz this is the last version that's gonna

410
00:21:13.934 --> 00:21:14.454
support it.

411
00:21:14.454 --> 00:21:18.136
So when 10.14 comes out and
really to be Server app 6,

412
00:21:18.136 --> 00:21:23.500
I guess, or whatever comes after 5.5,
they are gonna kill off the VPN.

413
00:21:23.500 --> 00:21:28.430
And that's gonna make it where it's not so
convenient to use this VPN client anymore.

414
00:21:28.430 --> 00:21:31.610
I guess, if you're connecting
with Cisco VPN or whatever, so

415
00:21:31.610 --> 00:21:34.900
there are plenty of third party
clients that are out there.

416
00:21:34.900 --> 00:21:36.869
Now on the ACSP exam, it's just this one,

417
00:21:36.869 --> 00:21:39.650
they're not gonna hit you
on any third party stuff.

418
00:21:39.650 --> 00:21:42.001
But in the real world,
there's plenty of thirdparty ones,

419
00:21:42.001 --> 00:21:45.340
I actually use one called Viscosity,
that's this little red circle up here.

420
00:21:45.340 --> 00:21:47.760
And you'll see where I actually
have the ITProTV Studios-

421
00:21:47.760 --> 00:21:48.880
>> Hey there you go!

422
00:21:48.880 --> 00:21:49.388
>> As a VPN,

423
00:21:49.388 --> 00:21:51.310
the Viscosity client is a good one.

424
00:21:51.310 --> 00:21:55.470
Cisco has the Cisco AnyConnect client
that you can run on top of MacOS.

425
00:21:55.470 --> 00:21:57.790
And there's tons of third party
ones that are out there as well.

426
00:21:57.790 --> 00:22:00.540
So don't hesitate to reach out and

427
00:22:00.540 --> 00:22:03.950
check out third party ones because
a lot of them are really good, and

428
00:22:03.950 --> 00:22:07.190
they're gonna continue to be
supported beyond this last version.

429
00:22:07.190 --> 00:22:11.620
After High Sierra,
Apple will still support the client, but

430
00:22:11.620 --> 00:22:15.840
not the server, and on the client side,
it just doesn't have a ton of options,

431
00:22:15.840 --> 00:22:17.200
it doesn't have a ton of features.

432
00:22:17.200 --> 00:22:20.920
At no point in this configuration
was I able to hard set

433
00:22:20.920 --> 00:22:23.390
a minimum encryption protocol.

434
00:22:23.390 --> 00:22:25.130
So all of these are working profile based,

435
00:22:25.130 --> 00:22:28.512
when I connect to the server I'm expecting
the server to tell me what profile to use.

436
00:22:28.512 --> 00:22:31.412
Well if the server tells me
to use something weak, right?

437
00:22:31.412 --> 00:22:34.254
Somebody's pulling a man
in the middle attack and

438
00:22:34.254 --> 00:22:39.070
they send a message saying, yeah we
need you to use DES encryption, right?

439
00:22:39.070 --> 00:22:44.440
Well DES takes like three seconds
to break and it's just trivial.

440
00:22:44.440 --> 00:22:48.140
But my system might say, okay,
I'll do what you told me, right?

441
00:22:48.140 --> 00:22:49.821
That's the kind of risk that we have, and

442
00:22:49.821 --> 00:22:52.961
third party clients will usually let you
hard set what that minimum level is.

443
00:22:52.961 --> 00:22:58.221
Like I will connect unless I can
get AES 128 or higher, right?

444
00:22:58.221 --> 00:23:02.700
This is something like that that ensures
your minimum level of protection.

445
00:23:02.700 --> 00:23:06.940
That's already being done server side, but
if somebody doesn't a man in the middle of

446
00:23:06.940 --> 00:23:08.160
the tech,
you might not be hitting the server.

447
00:23:08.160 --> 00:23:09.500
You might be hitting something in between,

448
00:23:09.500 --> 00:23:11.410
and it's nice to have the client
to participate in that.

449
00:23:11.410 --> 00:23:15.830
So in a high security environment, Apple's
VPN client is not really the most robust.

450
00:23:16.880 --> 00:23:18.560
>> Another excellent episode,

451
00:23:18.560 --> 00:23:21.270
advanced network configuration, loved it.
>> [LAUGH]

452
00:23:21.270 --> 00:23:22.200
>> Don, before we move on,

453
00:23:22.200 --> 00:23:25.970
anything else you'd like to say?
>> The key thing here for

454
00:23:25.970 --> 00:23:29.450
us as support professionals, we learn
about locations, we remember them,

455
00:23:29.450 --> 00:23:32.480
but end users, they don't know about them.

456
00:23:32.480 --> 00:23:36.300
And so when you first roll
out locations like this,

457
00:23:36.300 --> 00:23:37.670
you're gonna get support desk calls.

458
00:23:37.670 --> 00:23:40.170
You're gonna get people calling in saying,
hey I'm at home and

459
00:23:40.170 --> 00:23:41.600
my network's not working.

460
00:23:41.600 --> 00:23:44.070
And it's because they still have
a static configuration from work,

461
00:23:44.070 --> 00:23:45.510
they haven't changed the locations.

462
00:23:45.510 --> 00:23:48.168
So you're gonna have to educate your
users on how to use these locations,

463
00:23:48.168 --> 00:23:49.750
how to know to flip between them.

464
00:23:49.750 --> 00:23:53.450
If you don't educate your users,
the Mac doesn't know how to switch.

465
00:23:53.450 --> 00:23:56.150
It doesn't know when you're at home or
when you're at work,

466
00:23:56.150 --> 00:23:57.420
it doesn't have that information.

467
00:23:57.420 --> 00:23:59.990
So the end users have to get involved with
that, you're going to have to put together

468
00:23:59.990 --> 00:24:02.440
at least a little bit of training
to make sure everybody is aware.

469
00:24:02.440 --> 00:24:03.590
>> Thank you Don, and listen,

470
00:24:03.590 --> 00:24:07.790
make sure you watch every single episode
of Apple Certified Support Professional.

471
00:24:07.790 --> 00:24:09.931
You're gonna be so glad you did,
and it will help you, and

472
00:24:09.931 --> 00:24:11.349
you'll be in the course library too.

473
00:24:11.349 --> 00:24:14.950
And there's thousands of other videos
there all designed to do one thing,

474
00:24:14.950 --> 00:24:16.170
help you go further.

475
00:24:16.170 --> 00:24:19.622
Check those out too, and
tell everybody you know about ITProTV,

476
00:24:19.622 --> 00:24:21.020
ITProTV is binge worthy.

477
00:24:21.020 --> 00:24:23.480
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

478
00:24:23.480 --> 00:24:25.218
>> We shall see you very soon.

00:28:01.270 --> 00:28:03.090
In my case that's a local machine.

00:28:07.490 --> 00:28:10.710

00:28:10.710 --> 00:28:14.190
Port Scans are really handy cuz they can

522
00:28:14.190 --> 00:28:15.910

00:28:15.910 --> 00:28:20.753
So if I punch in the IP address

00:28:29.880 --> 00:28:34.530

either the services aren't turned on or

527
00:28:34.530 --> 00:28:36.270

528
00:28:36.270 --> 00:28:40.510
If it comes back with actual port numbers,
then I'll know that I'm able to talk to

529
00:28:40.510 --> 00:28:42.890
it, it must be some other
problem that's going on.

530
00:28:42.890 --> 00:28:45.520
So the network utility is really handy for

531
00:28:45.520 --> 00:28:46.509
You get a quick kind of view.

532
00:28:46.509 --> 00:28:49.170
Here, I'm already starting to get

FTP is open, SSH is open, and it'll

00:28:53.460 --> 00:28:56.890

episodes.description: In this episode, Don walks the viewers through the various ways macOS can make resources available through the network. He demonstrates using file sharing, printer sharing, remote management and Internet connection sharing. He also does an extra demonstration of the Apple Remote Desktop utililty.

1

7

As we continue on with Apple Certified
Support Professional, Sharing Resources,

8
00:00:22.024 --> 00:00:22.618
Part Two.

9
00:00:22.618 --> 00:00:26.141

10
00:00:26.141 --> 00:00:28.201
Don, good to see you sir.

11
00:00:28.201 --> 00:00:31.690
And in part one we talked about a lot
of different sharing protocols.

12
00:00:31.690 --> 00:00:36.270
We went over Apple file protocol and
SMB, just standard file sharing.

13
00:00:36.270 --> 00:00:39.770
We talked about printer sharing,
screen sharing, Back to My Mac.

14
00:00:39.770 --> 00:00:41.320
All these different ways of sharing stuff,

15
00:00:41.320 --> 00:00:43.700
but there's several more
services that we didn't get to.

16
00:00:43.700 --> 00:00:45.820
So we're gonna run through some of
those right here in this episode.

17
00:00:45.820 --> 00:00:50.277
Especially some management services that I
think personally are really, really cool.

18
00:00:50.277 --> 00:00:53.157
And as a home user you don't care
about them, but as a certified support

19
00:00:53.157 --> 00:00:56.661
professional you're working in a business
environment, you're supporting a lot of

20
00:00:56.661 --> 00:00:59.260
Macs, and these are the tools
that you're going to want to use.

21
00:00:59.260 --> 00:01:01.850
So we're going to take a look at
those right here in this subset.

22
00:01:01.850 --> 00:01:03.320
>> Here's a captain obvious question,

23
00:01:03.320 --> 00:01:06.650
what other services are available?
>> All right, well there's a couple.

24
00:01:06.650 --> 00:01:10.620
I touched lightly on some of
them like remote log in, right?

25
00:01:10.620 --> 00:01:17.300
Remote login enables, ssh, and sftp
access file transfers now, when I talk

26
00:01:17.300 --> 00:01:21.910
about in part one, I was talking about it
from the file transfer perspective, right?

27
00:01:21.910 --> 00:01:23.560
I wanna transfer some files,

28
00:01:23.560 --> 00:01:28.180
sftp let's me do it as an encrypted
connection great but, from

29
00:01:28.180 --> 00:01:33.160
a management perspective we could use ssh
to be able to connect in, and run scripts,

30
00:01:33.160 --> 00:01:36.380
run all the utilities, check permissions,
fix permissions, back up files.

31
00:01:36.380 --> 00:01:38.840
Whatever it is that you want to do,
you can do from the terminal.

32
00:01:38.840 --> 00:01:41.720
You're basically gaining access to
the terminal of another Mac and

33
00:01:41.720 --> 00:01:44.300
you can do it without even
bothering the end users.

34
00:01:44.300 --> 00:01:46.010
They can be in the system and working and

35
00:01:46.010 --> 00:01:48.010
they don't even see that
connection is occurring.

36
00:01:48.010 --> 00:01:51.323
It's all in the background,
which is somewhat scary in a way.

37
00:01:51.323 --> 00:01:52.025
>> I was just going to say a little bit

00:01:52.025 --> 00:01:53.920
frightening.
>> But if you're the administrator

00:01:53.920 --> 00:01:57.097

40
00:01:57.097 --> 00:01:59.460
>> So part in parcel of the system.

41
00:01:59.460 --> 00:02:00.650
So that's one thing.

42
00:02:00.650 --> 00:02:03.444
There's also something
called Remote Apple Events.

43
00:02:03.444 --> 00:02:06.190
Here, let me instead of just
saying the names, let me show you.

44
00:02:06.190 --> 00:02:10.640
I'm going to go into System Preferences
and I'm going to go into Sharing.

45
00:02:10.640 --> 00:02:14.880
And inside of my Sharing here, you'll see
Remote Login that I was talking about.

46
00:02:14.880 --> 00:02:20.750
And that's what enabled that SSH access or
SFTP if you're doing file transfers.

47
00:02:20.750 --> 00:02:24.966
But we also have this remote Apple events,
okay?

48
00:02:24.966 --> 00:02:29.329
In some of our troubleshooting
episodes I showed the console utility.

49
00:02:29.329 --> 00:02:29.975
>> Right.

50
00:02:29.975 --> 00:02:32.305
>> And the console utility shows me

51
00:02:32.305 --> 00:02:36.985
the log activity on my Mac, all the stuff
that's going on as programs run and

52
00:02:36.985 --> 00:02:38.775
if there's errors and
failures and stuff like that.

53
00:02:40.045 --> 00:02:41.690
The logs are great.

54
00:02:41.690 --> 00:02:46.710
But every single MAC has its own logs,
and so if you've got 1000 MACs

55
00:02:46.710 --> 00:02:51.760
that you're managing and you say,
I see this error on MAC number 273,

56
00:02:51.760 --> 00:02:55.340
I wonder if any other MACs
are getting the same error.

57
00:02:56.620 --> 00:03:00.555
Well, you'd have to go to all 1000
of them searching to see if they

58
00:03:00.555 --> 00:03:03.240
had that same error,
showing up at the places.

59
00:03:03.240 --> 00:03:09.385
Wouldn't it be nice if we had all
these logs centralized in one place?

60
00:03:09.385 --> 00:03:09.980
>> Mm-hm.

61
00:03:09.980 --> 00:03:11.330
>> And you can do that,

62
00:03:11.330 --> 00:03:13.940
if you have a macOS server stood up right?

63
00:03:13.940 --> 00:03:16.790
Which is just macOS with
the Server app installed.

64
00:03:16.790 --> 00:03:20.880
So if we have a server up, we can use that
as a central logging destination, and

65
00:03:20.880 --> 00:03:26.350
on any of our Macs we can go into our
System Preferences, go into Sharing.

66
00:03:26.350 --> 00:03:29.040
And you can turn on Remote Apple Events,
and

67
00:03:29.040 --> 00:03:33.800
that allows you to be able to exchange
that information with a central server.

68
00:03:33.800 --> 00:03:37.520

69
00:03:37.520 --> 00:03:39.730
If you ever used the automator
utility to create script and

70
00:03:39.730 --> 00:03:44.520
automations, remote apple events
can be powered by automation.

71
00:03:44.520 --> 00:03:49.200
And so, you can say, hey everyday at 7 pm,
all these computers go to sleep, and

72
00:03:49.200 --> 00:03:51.600
it can generate that event in
pushing out to the systems and

73
00:03:51.600 --> 00:03:52.910
actually have them go to sleep.

74
00:03:52.910 --> 00:03:54.730
Kind of cool stuff that you can do there.

75
00:03:54.730 --> 00:03:57.970
So that's a big management service
that's available kind of tucked away in

76
00:03:57.970 --> 00:03:59.450
the background.

77
00:03:59.450 --> 00:04:03.540
All right, now I talked about remote login
and I talked about Remote Apple Events,

78
00:04:03.540 --> 00:04:08.680
I'll tell you in all honesty I don't
usually make use of either of these.

79
00:04:08.680 --> 00:04:10.580
And the reason is,
not that they aren't good,

80
00:04:10.580 --> 00:04:13.820

something even better, right.

81
00:04:13.820 --> 00:04:16.010
I skipped over Remote Management.

82
00:04:16.010 --> 00:04:17.150
This guy right here.

83
00:04:17.150 --> 00:04:19.430
This one is commonly misunderstood.

84
00:04:19.430 --> 00:04:22.840
A lot of people look at this and they see,
all right, Remote Management is off.

85
00:04:22.840 --> 00:04:25.970
Remote management allows other
users to access this computer using

86
00:04:25.970 --> 00:04:26.879
Apple Remote Desktop.

87
00:04:28.090 --> 00:04:31.494
Microsoft has a product
called Remote Desktop, and

88
00:04:31.494 --> 00:04:36.378
with Remote Desktop it lets you see
the screen of another Windows machine.

89
00:04:36.378 --> 00:04:41.320
That sounds a lot like screen sharing,
we already talked about screen sharing.

90
00:04:41.320 --> 00:04:45.500
This sounds like it does the same
thing and so people overlook it.

91
00:04:45.500 --> 00:04:48.910
When Apple says remote desktop,
they are not talking about screen sharing.

92
00:04:48.910 --> 00:04:50.210
That's one piece of it.

93
00:04:50.210 --> 00:04:52.060
But there's a heck of a lot more.

94
00:04:52.060 --> 00:04:56.433
If you're managing five or more Macs,
I mean really if you're managing two Macs,

95
00:04:56.433 --> 00:04:57.556
you can use this, but

96
00:04:57.556 --> 00:05:02.060
if you're managing five or more, this is
a really, really incredibly useful tool.

97
00:05:02.060 --> 00:05:07.025
Called Apple Remote Desktop that let's
you completely manage your max and

98
00:05:07.025 --> 00:05:09.004
it makes life so much easier.

99
00:05:09.004 --> 00:05:10.358
Now it's not free.

100
00:05:10.358 --> 00:05:15.458
Apple Remote Desktop is in
the Appstore as of right now it's $80.

101
00:05:15.458 --> 00:05:18.407
So it's actually more expensive then
the server app which is kind of funny.

102
00:05:18.407 --> 00:05:20.458
>> But that's a one time purchase though,

103
00:05:20.458 --> 00:05:21.532
right?
>> Right you buy it,

104
00:05:21.532 --> 00:05:22.454
it's part of your account.

105
00:05:22.454 --> 00:05:25.011
I bought it years ago and so
it's been apart of my account for

106
00:05:25.011 --> 00:05:27.610
a long time
>> But once you've got it,

107
00:05:27.610 --> 00:05:32.680
you can then connect out of Manager Max

right there, I can see it.

526
00:24:41.710 --> 00:24:43.389
I can even see the file
systems that are on it.

527
00:24:43.389 --> 00:24:47.157
And it'll show up under some of
these other connector types as

528
00:24:47.157 --> 00:24:50.430
well because it is storage
somewhere buried in here.

529
00:24:53.150 --> 00:24:54.747
Well somewhere in here, it'll turn up.

530
00:24:54.747 --> 00:24:57.010
But either way,
we can spot that and see it.

531
00:24:57.010 --> 00:24:58.862
So that's really the best
way to come in and

532
00:24:58.862 --> 00:25:00.874
verify that hardware is
actually showing up.

533
00:25:00.874 --> 00:25:03.638
If it shows up in here and
it's like an unknown device,

534
00:25:03.638 --> 00:25:07.850
that's usually the indicator that it's
time to go and download a driver.

535
00:25:07.850 --> 00:25:10.834
You gotta load a driver in order for
that device to show up and work.

536
00:25:10.834 --> 00:25:12.237
>> Another great episode,

537
00:25:12.237 --> 00:25:13.740
peripheral devices!

538
00:25:13.740 --> 00:25:16.608
Don, I know you wanna say
something else before we move on.

539
00:25:16.608 --> 00:25:18.138
>> Key thing here, or key take away for

540
00:25:18.138 --> 00:25:20.994
a support professional,
is that just because a device works now,

541
00:25:20.994 --> 00:25:22.530
doesn't mean it'll work later.

542
00:25:22.530 --> 00:25:26.484
[LAUGH] So make sure that you update
your drivers, get the hardware loaded,

543
00:25:26.484 --> 00:25:27.373
get it working.

544
00:25:27.373 --> 00:25:32.330
But anytime MAC OS updates,
it can potentially break the drivers.

545
00:25:32.330 --> 00:25:35.254
This is really true with docking
stations that use DisplayLink for

546
00:25:35.254 --> 00:25:36.148
their video cards.

547
00:25:36.148 --> 00:25:39.918
Every new version of Mac OS seems to
break those really, really reliably.

548
00:25:39.918 --> 00:25:43.093
So you wanna make sure that
whenever you update Mac OS,

549
00:25:43.093 --> 00:25:47.098
you also take some time to look and
see if there's updated drivers for

550
00:25:47.098 --> 00:25:50.430
your hardware,
that will usually solve most problems.

551
00:25:50.430 --> 00:25:54.380
If you add some new hardware and your
computer starts locking up or freaking

552
00:25:54.380 --> 00:25:56.816
out, remember that you can do Safe Boot.
>> Mm.

553
00:25:56.816 --> 00:25:58.562
>> If you boot your system while holding

554
00:25:58.562 --> 00:26:01.714
the Shift keys on your keyboard,
you'll boot into Safe Boot, and

555
00:26:01.714 --> 00:26:03.200
it won't load those drivers.

556
00:26:03.200 --> 00:26:06.183
That way you can get in, uninstall
the drivers, and get yourself back up and

557
00:26:06.183 --> 00:26:06.840
running again.

558
00:26:06.840 --> 00:26:09.801
So kind of nice functionality to have
there, just remember that it's all

559
00:26:09.801 --> 00:26:13.376
a part of our troubleshooting process.
>> Great advice, thank you Don.

560
00:26:13.376 --> 00:26:16.760
And remember, Apple Certified Support
Professional is a fantastic series.

561
00:26:16.760 --> 00:26:19.676
Make sure you watch every episode,
you'll be glad you did.

562
00:26:19.676 --> 00:26:21.444
You'll be in the course library too,

563
00:26:21.444 --> 00:26:24.940
where there's thousands of other videos
designed to help you go further.

564
00:26:24.940 --> 00:26:26.643
So check those out, too.

565
00:26:26.643 --> 00:26:29.000
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

566
00:26:29.000 --> 00:26:29.816
ITProTV is binge-worthy.

567
00:26:29.816 --> 00:26:32.195
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

568
00:26:32.195 --> 00:26:34.556
>> And we will see you again soon.

569
00:26:34.556 --> 00:26:40.442
[MUSIC]

570
00:26:40.442 --> 00:26:43.090
>> Thank you for watching, ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don looks into supporting printers in macOS High Sierra. He covers topics like connection types, printer drivers, managing the print queue, and sharing print devices with other users.
episodes.title: Supporting Printers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:01.593
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.593 --> 00:00:02.806
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.806 --> 00:00:05.923
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.923 --> 00:00:08.468
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.468 --> 00:00:11.988
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.988 --> 00:00:14.361
>> Hello, thanks for watching ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.361 --> 00:00:16.850
Helping you learn everywhere you go.

8
00:00:16.850 --> 00:00:21.630
I'm your host Zach Memos for this episode
of Apple Certified Support Professionals.

9
00:00:21.630 --> 00:00:24.220
We're gonna be looking
at supporting prayers.

10
00:00:24.220 --> 00:00:25.370
That's what we're gonna do.

11
00:00:25.370 --> 00:00:27.430
And Don Pezet's here to
show us how to do that.

12
00:00:27.430 --> 00:00:28.160
Don, good to see you.

13
00:00:28.160 --> 00:00:33.665
>> Hey, glad to be here, Zach, and glad
help people kill trees whenever they can.

14
00:00:33.665 --> 00:00:36.226
>> [LAUGH]
>> Our advancing society, more and

15
00:00:36.226 --> 00:00:38.440
more people have moved away from printers,
right?

16
00:00:38.440 --> 00:00:39.770
They have-
>> It's true.

17
00:00:39.770 --> 00:00:43.270
>> Digital documents, PDFs,
things of that nature.

18
00:00:43.270 --> 00:00:45.535
But printing is still a very,

19
00:00:45.535 --> 00:00:48.725
very critical piece of almost
every business that's out there.

20
00:00:48.725 --> 00:00:50.625
When you go to a store they
give you a paper receipt.

21
00:00:50.625 --> 00:00:54.125
When you go to the bank you
fill out a paper deposit slip.

22
00:00:54.125 --> 00:00:56.635
That stuff is still done on paper, and

23
00:00:56.635 --> 00:00:59.415
as a result,
printers are still really important.

24
00:00:59.415 --> 00:01:01.855
So in this episode,
we're gonna talk about printers.

25
00:01:01.855 --> 00:01:03.185
How we can use them with our Mac?

26
00:01:03.185 --> 00:01:05.666
How we can get them set up,
all that magic?

27
00:01:05.666 --> 00:01:09.261
And just get a chance to see what it's
like to support printers in a general Mac

28
00:01:09.261 --> 00:01:11.381
environment all right
here in this episode.

29
00:01:11.381 --> 00:01:13.960
>> So basic question,
how do we add printers to a Mac?

30
00:01:13.960 --> 00:01:16.323
>> All right, well, there are two ways.

31
00:01:16.323 --> 00:01:17.741
There's the old way and there's new way.

32
00:01:17.741 --> 00:01:21.480
And the old way is you buy
this brand new printer.

33
00:01:21.480 --> 00:01:25.181
And you hook a cable into it, and
you plug that cable into your Mac.

34
00:01:25.181 --> 00:01:29.980
And your Mac magically sees the printer,
and it works, and that's that, right?

35
00:01:29.980 --> 00:01:30.990
>> Yay!

36
00:01:30.990 --> 00:01:35.325
>> But, I will tell you that very
few people do that these days.

37
00:01:35.325 --> 00:01:39.070
Older style printers used a syntronix
cable and a parallel connector.

38
00:01:39.070 --> 00:01:41.800
There were some Mac specific
printers that used scuzzy cables.

39
00:01:41.800 --> 00:01:44.120
None of those ports are found on any Mac,

40
00:01:44.120 --> 00:01:46.020
anymore manufactured in the last decade,
really.

41
00:01:46.020 --> 00:01:47.780
So all of that's old news.

42
00:01:47.780 --> 00:01:49.780
If you go to the store and
buy a printer today,

43
00:01:49.780 --> 00:01:54.240
it will likely have a USB port on it so
that you can plug it in via USB.

44
00:01:54.240 --> 00:01:58.731
Well, I have yet to see a printer
that had a USB-C connector on it, so

45
00:01:58.731 --> 00:02:03.777
it's usually gonna come with the older
style USB-B connector or whatever.

46
00:02:03.777 --> 00:02:05.380
A, B, I mix those up.

47
00:02:05.380 --> 00:02:08.440
But either way, most of our Macs
are not gonna use that, and

48
00:02:08.440 --> 00:02:10.800
even if they did it would not matter.

49
00:02:10.800 --> 00:02:15.190
Most of us are gonna want the printer
to be on the network instead.

50
00:02:15.190 --> 00:02:19.600
If I take a printer and I plug it right
into my computer, I can print to it,

51
00:02:19.600 --> 00:02:20.820
but what about Zack?

52
00:02:20.820 --> 00:02:22.770
What about the other
people in the building?

53
00:02:22.770 --> 00:02:23.820
They can't, right?

54
00:02:23.820 --> 00:02:26.090
Unless we share it on the network.

55
00:02:26.090 --> 00:02:30.070
But if I want everybody
to be able to access it,

56
00:02:30.070 --> 00:02:33.360
wouldn't it be better if the printer
was plugged into the network.

57
00:02:33.360 --> 00:02:35.960
Or if it was connected via
wireless onto the network.

58
00:02:35.960 --> 00:02:38.820
>> Yes.
>> And that's what we're gonna see on

59
00:02:38.820 --> 00:02:40.510
almost every environment today.

60
00:02:40.510 --> 00:02:43.140
Ranging from the little
printers that you get at home,

61
00:02:43.140 --> 00:02:46.970
to the massive corporate size
business machines that you can get.

62
00:02:46.970 --> 00:02:50.870
All of those are moving into
that network-enabled world.

63
00:02:50.870 --> 00:02:53.270
And this isn't a process that started,
or the year before.

64
00:02:53.270 --> 00:02:55.580
This is a process that
started 15 years ago.

65
00:02:55.580 --> 00:03:00.072
So by this point, if you walk
into Staples, or Office Depot, or

66
00:03:00.072 --> 00:03:01.667
some place like that.

67
00:03:01.667 --> 00:03:05.800
Pretty much every printer they have
supports being connected to the network.

68
00:03:05.800 --> 00:03:08.840
And a big driver of that
are mobile phones and

69
00:03:08.840 --> 00:03:12.790
tablets, because they don't have ports on
them to be able to connect to a printer.

70
00:03:12.790 --> 00:03:16.070
They need to communicate over the
wireless, and so your Mac can do that too.

71
00:03:16.070 --> 00:03:19.990
So as far as getting a printer connected,
you usually don't even have to.

72
00:03:19.990 --> 00:03:22.250
You just connect right over the network.

73
00:03:22.250 --> 00:03:23.920
>> Do we need to load drivers for
it first?

74
00:03:24.930 --> 00:03:27.640
>> Sometimes yes,
actually a lot of times you do.

75
00:03:27.640 --> 00:03:30.170
This is an area where Apple's
really done some impressive stuff.

76
00:03:30.170 --> 00:03:33.912
So in the olden days,
when you bought a printer,

77
00:03:33.912 --> 00:03:38.950
you had to make sure that it supported
Mac OS, that was a big deal.

78
00:03:38.950 --> 00:03:41.240
If it didn't, the odds are you
weren't gonna get it to work.

79
00:03:41.240 --> 00:03:43.616
So the old rule of thumb was buy an HP,

80
00:03:43.616 --> 00:03:47.618
Hewlett Packard partnering with
apple on quite a few things.

81
00:03:47.618 --> 00:03:51.661
And they're really good about making
sure the Apple always had drivers for

82
00:03:51.661 --> 00:03:52.700
every HP printer.

83
00:03:52.700 --> 00:03:55.440
So you knew you couldn't go wrong
if you bought an HP printer.

84
00:03:55.440 --> 00:03:58.842
But if you bought a Lexmark,
or a Canon, or a Brotheror, or

85
00:03:58.842 --> 00:04:03.950
somebody else Okie Data right one of
the other companies that are out there.

86
00:04:03.950 --> 00:04:08.352
You didn't know you just didn't know
is it gonna work, is it not gonna work,

87
00:04:08.352 --> 00:04:09.722
what's gonna happen?

88
00:04:09.722 --> 00:04:12.284
For those you would have to go and
get a driver, and

89
00:04:12.284 --> 00:04:14.726
you really need to do
the research beforehand.

90
00:04:14.726 --> 00:04:18.030
Don't buy a printer unless you
know that driver is available.

91
00:04:18.030 --> 00:04:21.860
Well, Apple finally said all right,
enough is enough, this is a mess, and

92
00:04:21.860 --> 00:04:25.350
when they switched from being
dedicated Mac OS over to OS 10,

93
00:04:25.350 --> 00:04:29.068
when they switched to BSD under the hood,
that was the UnixWorld.

94
00:04:29.068 --> 00:04:30.350
In the UnixWorld,

95
00:04:30.350 --> 00:04:34.340
printer support was even worse
because nobody made drivers for Unix.

96
00:04:34.340 --> 00:04:36.020
And so, the Unix admins,

97
00:04:36.020 --> 00:04:39.470
the developers there were having to make
their own drivers, it was the Wild West.

98
00:04:39.470 --> 00:04:42.170
And so
Apple created something called CUPS.

99
00:04:42.170 --> 00:04:48.320
CUPS is the Common Unix Printing Service,
C-U-P-S.

100
00:04:48.320 --> 00:04:51.840
And they assigned developers to it,
they created this platform.

101
00:04:51.840 --> 00:04:56.390
And then, they did something crazy,
they open sourced it, they gave it away.

102
00:04:56.390 --> 00:05:01.470
And today, every Mac,
pretty much every Linux distribution,

103
00:05:01.470 --> 00:05:07.660
every BSD, and
on the Unix side are all using CUPS now.

104
00:05:07.660 --> 00:05:12.060
And so, if I'm a printer manufacturer and
I create some brand new shiny printer.

105
00:05:12.060 --> 00:05:15.890
Instead of having to create
a Windows driver, Mac, Linux, BSD,

106
00:05:15.890 --> 00:05:20.280
all these different things,
I just need to create a Windows driver and

107
00:05:20.280 --> 00:05:22.540
a CUPS driver, and that's it.

108
00:05:22.540 --> 00:05:24.430
And I can support all
these different platforms.

109
00:05:24.430 --> 00:05:28.202
So now a manufacturer's a lot
more likely to create drivers for

110
00:05:28.202 --> 00:05:31.630
Mac OS, because it covers all
of these other platforms too.

111
00:05:31.630 --> 00:05:36.882
So the drivers are available,
and when you go to a website like

112
00:05:36.882 --> 00:05:42.538
here I'll show you, if I go to HP,
and whoops, or I go to twitter,

113
00:05:42.538 --> 00:05:47.288
apparently I am just getting
a little click crazy here.

114
00:05:47.288 --> 00:05:53.549
But if we go to HP's website and we go to
download drivers for an HP printer well,

115
00:05:53.549 --> 00:05:59.830
what you'll find is they'll have drivers
that are for both Windows and Mac OS.

116
00:05:59.830 --> 00:06:03.040
So if I come in here and search, I'm just
picking a printer that we have here in

117
00:06:03.040 --> 00:06:05.091
the office an HP LaserJet M506, right?

118
00:06:06.110 --> 00:06:09.430
So I can find that printer
I can click on it.

119
00:06:09.430 --> 00:06:11.710
We go in here, and
it's gonna ask me to pick my driver.

120
00:06:11.710 --> 00:06:18.160
And I'll see Linux, Mac OS,
OS Independent, SAP, UNIX, Windows.

121
00:06:18.160 --> 00:06:22.400
Well, if I pick Windows,
that's usually a Windows specific driver.

122
00:06:22.400 --> 00:06:29.480
But if I pick Linux, SAP, UNIX, Mac OS,
those are all actually the same driver.

123
00:06:29.480 --> 00:06:31.500
They're all that same CUPS driver.

124
00:06:31.500 --> 00:06:34.549
The only thing that's different is
the installation package, right?

125
00:06:34.549 --> 00:06:36.560
In Mac OS, it has the nice little GUI.

126
00:06:36.560 --> 00:06:39.918
If I choose Linux, it's a little
command line utility that you run.

127
00:06:39.918 --> 00:06:42.980
And then, you can pick the operating
system version, so I got 10.13.

128
00:06:42.980 --> 00:06:44.350
I can download that driver.

129
00:06:44.350 --> 00:06:47.790
Now, I'll tell you most printers
will work without the driver,

130
00:06:47.790 --> 00:06:51.540
but you'll just get
basic printing support.

131
00:06:51.540 --> 00:06:53.160
Printers can usually do a lot more.

132
00:06:53.160 --> 00:06:54.840
Some of them have staplers built in,

133
00:06:54.840 --> 00:06:57.610
they've got full duplex where
they can print double sided.

134
00:06:57.610 --> 00:07:01.840
Some of them have folders and
hole punchers built into them.

135
00:07:01.840 --> 00:07:05.350
All sort of craziness, sometimes
scanners and fax machines built in.

136
00:07:05.350 --> 00:07:09.160
None of that's gonna work unless you
have the driver from the vendor.

137
00:07:09.160 --> 00:07:12.330
So you go, you download the driver,
and you get it loaded.

138
00:07:12.330 --> 00:07:16.830
So that may well be something you need to
do just to get the driver up and going.

139
00:07:16.830 --> 00:07:21.470
Now, if the printer supports AirPlay, then
what'll happen is your Mac will talk to

140
00:07:21.470 --> 00:07:27.290
the printer, will learn about it, and
automatically download the driver for you.

141
00:07:27.290 --> 00:07:31.500
So you don't have to load it,
that's really cool if it supports AirPlay.

142
00:07:31.500 --> 00:07:33.210
But not every printer does.

143
00:07:33.210 --> 00:07:36.437
So if it doesn't support AirPlay, you
just need to go to the vendor's website,

144
00:07:36.437 --> 00:07:39.103
whoever made that printer, and
download their official driver.

145
00:07:39.103 --> 00:07:41.250
And that'll give you that
additional functionality.

146
00:07:41.250 --> 00:07:43.480
And let you get in there and function.

147
00:07:43.480 --> 00:07:46.891
If you wanna know what printers
are supported natively,

148
00:07:46.891 --> 00:07:48.880
you can drop into your terminal,

149
00:07:48.880 --> 00:07:53.230
and in the terminal if you browse into
/ took into two different places.

150
00:07:53.230 --> 00:08:00.130
If you wanna see the ones that are built
in you can go to /system/library/printers,

151
00:08:00.130 --> 00:08:04.990
that folder right there,
/system/library/printers.

152
00:08:04.990 --> 00:08:09.440
Normally, extensions go in
/system/library/extensions, but

153
00:08:09.440 --> 00:08:12.280
the printer drivers are special,
so they put them over here.

154
00:08:12.280 --> 00:08:14.800
And if you take a look you
can see what's built in.

155
00:08:14.800 --> 00:08:17.730
And apparently,
I just have a libraries folder.

156
00:08:17.730 --> 00:08:21.130
There we go, and so we can start
to see what's kind of built in.

157
00:08:21.130 --> 00:08:22.530
Now, on mine I don't have much.

158
00:08:22.530 --> 00:08:26.350
I just see USBGenericPrintingClass.

159
00:08:26.350 --> 00:08:29.640
All right, so that's kind of a generic
printer driver, and then you'll see

160
00:08:29.640 --> 00:08:36.030
the Internet printing protocol and
the Printing Protocol Daemon, PPD.

161
00:08:36.030 --> 00:08:40.450
The CUPS drivers are actually
files that end in .ppd and so

162
00:08:40.450 --> 00:08:43.940
this is what's connecting Internet
printing protocol to the ppd system.

163
00:08:43.940 --> 00:08:45.513
So that's all part of CUPS.

164
00:08:45.513 --> 00:08:48.700
But I'm not seeing a lot of third party
drivers or anything special here.

165
00:08:48.700 --> 00:08:52.620
Which means I'm gonna have basic printing
services unless I add a printer and

166
00:08:52.620 --> 00:08:53.750
download something.

167
00:08:53.750 --> 00:08:58.520
If I go into /Libraries/Printers,

168
00:08:58.520 --> 00:09:02.460
this one is where my third party
software would show up, and

169
00:09:02.460 --> 00:09:05.930
in here, I see a Canon folder,
I see an Epson folder.

170
00:09:05.930 --> 00:09:07.130
You might not see those on yours.

171
00:09:07.130 --> 00:09:10.070
I'm seeing them because apparently at
some point, I've taken this laptop

172
00:09:10.070 --> 00:09:13.140
near a Canon or near an Epson, and
so it started loading a driver.

173
00:09:13.140 --> 00:09:17.714
If I go into PPDs, into that folder,
And take a look around,

174
00:09:17.714 --> 00:09:21.499
well I just see Contents
nothing too crazy there.

175
00:09:21.499 --> 00:09:25.393
And then, if I get inside of it I can
start to find any drivers that may or

176
00:09:25.393 --> 00:09:26.850
may not have been loaded.

177
00:09:26.850 --> 00:09:28.605
And so, here's this Epson Fax,

178
00:09:28.605 --> 00:09:31.814
I don't remember connecting
to an Epson printer recently.

179

00:23:45.883 --> 00:23:53.289
It puts it into /System
/Library/CoreServices.

494
00:23:53.289 --> 00:23:54.614
That folder right there.

495
00:23:54.614 --> 00:23:58.219
If you browse into
/System/Library/CoreServices, and

496
00:23:58.219 --> 00:24:03.700
take a look at all the files in there,
there's quite a bit of stuff in there.

497
00:24:03.700 --> 00:24:07.630
Buried in here somewhere,
you'll find a file called boot.efi.

498
00:24:07.630 --> 00:24:13.430
There it is right there,
that's it, boot.efi, okay.

499
00:24:13.430 --> 00:24:14.430
It's a binary file.

500
00:24:14.430 --> 00:24:15.850
I can't open it and show you the contents.

501
00:24:15.850 --> 00:24:17.390
But it's a very small file.

502
00:24:17.390 --> 00:24:22.720
And basically, what it says is all
the information that the booter needs to

503
00:24:22.720 --> 00:24:26.430
be able to boot Mac OS, it says, there's
an operating system here called Mac OS.

504
00:24:26.430 --> 00:24:28.220
And if you want to boot it,

505
00:24:28.220 --> 00:24:31.390
let me tell you where you can find
the kernel, here's where the kernel is.

506
00:24:31.390 --> 00:24:35.450
And then it points it over to that, and
that's enough for the booter to get in and

507
00:24:35.450 --> 00:24:36.140
do its job.

508
00:24:36.140 --> 00:24:38.140
It can say, thank you for
sharing that with me.

509
00:24:38.140 --> 00:24:39.140
>> That's a handy file.

510
00:24:39.140 --> 00:24:39.960
>> It certainly is.

511
00:24:39.960 --> 00:24:41.350
>> So don't delete that.

512
00:24:41.350 --> 00:24:42.360
>> If you delete

513
00:24:42.360 --> 00:24:43.000
that-
>> [LAUGH]

514
00:24:43.000 --> 00:24:45.180
>> Then you'll get operating system not

515
00:24:45.180 --> 00:24:48.340
found, that one file is enough to
derail the whole boot process,

516
00:24:48.340 --> 00:24:51.430
so pretty important file to have.
>> Find, I don't know,

517
00:24:51.430 --> 00:24:55.530
write a virus right now [LAUGH].
>> Yeah, it's not a hard one to target.

518
00:24:55.530 --> 00:24:56.160
>> I guess not.

519
00:24:56.160 --> 00:24:57.460
>> It is a protected folder so

520
00:24:57.460 --> 00:25:00.490
you would have to have administrative
privileges to remove that file.

521
00:25:00.490 --> 00:25:05.330
And Mac OS has something called
system integrity protection that

522
00:25:05.330 --> 00:25:07.200
stops you from modifying these files.

523
00:25:07.200 --> 00:25:09.940
Cuz malware could inject
itself in that boot.efi file,

524
00:25:09.940 --> 00:25:11.550
it'd be loaded before the OS was loaded.

525
00:25:11.550 --> 00:25:15.480
The OS wouldn't even be able to see it,
that's a great way to hide malware.

526
00:25:15.480 --> 00:25:19.310
So a lot of this stuff is protected
if it's checksum changes,

527
00:25:19.310 --> 00:25:22.730
if it's modified in any way,
it's a red flag and the system won't boot.

528
00:25:22.730 --> 00:25:25.040
Fortunately, it's easy to replace this,
right?

529
00:25:25.040 --> 00:25:29.170
If something is damaged here, if
the booter can't find my operating system,

530
00:25:30.310 --> 00:25:33.970
typically, it's either gonna mean
I've got a failed hard drive, right?

531
00:25:33.970 --> 00:25:36.030
People don't accidentally
delete their operating systems.

532
00:25:36.030 --> 00:25:37.635
That just doesn't happen.
>> It's very rare.

533
00:25:37.635 --> 00:25:39.700
[LAUGH]
>> I guess you could, right?

534
00:25:39.700 --> 00:25:44.392
So if I browse into my hard drive, and
I start taking a look at the content.

535
00:25:44.392 --> 00:25:47.240
There is the system folder,
it's got an X on it, right?

536
00:25:47.240 --> 00:25:49.000
That's where the operating system is.

537
00:25:49.000 --> 00:25:52.600
And that EFI file was in
/System/Library/CoreServices.

538
00:25:52.600 --> 00:25:58.010
So couldn't I do a two-finger click and
choose Move to Trash?

539
00:25:58.010 --> 00:25:58.700
Well, no.

540
00:25:58.700 --> 00:26:01.630
I can't,
there's nothing here in my list, right?

541
00:26:01.630 --> 00:26:02.772
So it's not gonna-
>> [CROSSTALK] option you get delete?

542
00:26:02.772 --> 00:26:04.940
>> I don't know

543
00:26:04.940 --> 00:26:06.050
>> I think if you hold down option,

544
00:26:06.050 --> 00:26:09.380
it will give you the delete option.
>> I don't know.

545
00:26:09.380 --> 00:26:10.570
We'll find out though.

546
00:26:10.570 --> 00:26:12.540
It doesn't cost us any
money to hold down option.

547
00:26:12.540 --> 00:26:13.690
Yes.
>> Yes.

548
00:26:13.690 --> 00:26:15.400
>> So I could get creative and

549
00:26:15.400 --> 00:26:17.430
try to drag and drop it, right?
>> There you go.

550
00:26:17.430 --> 00:26:19.670
>> Which if I just take that and

551
00:26:19.670 --> 00:26:21.870
come down here and find my trash.

552
00:26:23.040 --> 00:26:25.030
Right.
So here I get that big warning.

553
00:26:25.030 --> 00:26:27.010
This is system integrity protection,
right.

554
00:26:27.010 --> 00:26:31.240
System can't be modified you deleted
because it's required by Mac OS.

555
00:26:31.240 --> 00:26:34.676
So if it's telling us it's missing
something bad, [CROSSTALK]

556
00:26:34.676 --> 00:26:36.310
>> Yeah, something real bad has gone down.

557
00:26:36.310 --> 00:26:38.050
>> And it usually is a failed hard drive.

558
00:26:38.050 --> 00:26:40.650
I'd say nine times out of ten,
it's a failed hard drive.

559
00:26:40.650 --> 00:26:43.360
But it could just be that
the operating system got corrupted or

560
00:26:43.360 --> 00:26:45.510
it could be a recoverable error.

561
00:26:45.510 --> 00:26:48.920
Maybe something was happening that
made that hard drive vibrate for

562
00:26:48.920 --> 00:26:51.730
a moment and so it did a bad read.

563
00:26:51.730 --> 00:26:54.690
But now it's not vibrating anymore and
so now it's fine.

564
00:26:54.690 --> 00:26:58.040
So in those cases,
I usually take two approaches on this.

565
00:26:58.040 --> 00:27:00.648
First, I boot into recovery.

566
00:27:00.648 --> 00:27:04.800
And inside of recovery, you can use
the Disk Utility to run First Aid.

567
00:27:04.800 --> 00:27:08.150
We've seen that in a few episodes now, so
I won't bore us with a repeat of that.

568
00:27:08.150 --> 00:27:12.020
But you fire up the Disk Utility,
click the First Aid button, and

569
00:27:12.020 --> 00:27:14.370
it'll check the drive for errors,
and it'll fix permissions.

570
00:27:14.370 --> 00:27:16.690
Maybe it's a permissions problem and
it just can't find that file, right?

571
00:27:17.940 --> 00:27:20.623
Or you might go into Disk Utility and
the drive doesn't even show up.

572
00:27:20.623 --> 00:27:22.683
There's your [CROSSTALK].
>> Answer, yeah.

573
00:27:22.683 --> 00:27:24.730
[LAUGH]
>> You really know that has gone bad.

574
00:27:24.730 --> 00:27:26.300
So that could be it.

575
00:27:26.300 --> 00:27:31.365
But if the hard drive repair is fine,
and it shows up, and it's detected.

576
00:27:31.365 --> 00:27:35.140
But it's still not booting, it's not
able to find that operating system,

577
00:27:35.140 --> 00:27:38.460
the best thing you do is to boot
your recovery and reinstall the OS.

578
00:27:38.460 --> 00:27:43.220
Remember that when you reinstall Mac OS,
it's a non-destructive install by default.

579
00:27:43.220 --> 00:27:46.570
And it replaces all of
the protected system files.

580
00:27:46.570 --> 00:27:49.170
So a boot.efi is missing, it puts it back.

581
00:27:49.170 --> 00:27:52.020
If any other system files are missing,
it puts them back too.

582
00:27:52.020 --> 00:27:53.530
It puts them all back so

583
00:27:53.530 --> 00:27:57.690
that at least the core operating system is
going to function, work, and do its job.

584
00:27:57.690 --> 00:28:01.640
And that's the easiest way to fix that
one, as far as the booter's concerned.

585
00:28:01.640 --> 00:28:04.070
There's no configuration options for
the booter.

586
00:28:04.070 --> 00:28:08.180
It boots up and it looks for the operating
systems, it goes to find them.

587
00:28:08.180 --> 00:28:11.680
And if it can't find them,
that's it, you're out of luck.

588
00:28:11.680 --> 00:28:13.770
It doesn't say, hey,
do you wanna type in a path?

589
00:28:13.770 --> 00:28:15.240
You don't get that option.

590
00:28:15.240 --> 00:28:17.620
So it's just gonna find it,
nothing really to tweak there.

591
00:28:17.620 --> 00:28:19.490
So pretty easy one to troubleshoot.

592
00:28:19.490 --> 00:28:22.950
But the main thing on it is that
we just need to make sure that

593
00:28:22.950 --> 00:28:26.570
it's able to find those system
files it needs to get us up and

594
00:28:26.570 --> 00:28:27.140
running.
>> All right.

595
00:28:27.140 --> 00:28:28.370
Well, Don, I hate to cut you short.

596
00:28:28.370 --> 00:28:29.830
Our clock has run out of time.

597
00:28:29.830 --> 00:28:31.690
It's screaming for mercy over there.
>> [LAUGH]

598
00:28:31.690 --> 00:28:33.040
>> I know we've gotta get into the other

599
00:28:33.040 --> 00:28:35.130
three phases we haven't
even touched on yet.

600
00:28:35.130 --> 00:28:38.040
Any tips, tricks or
afterthoughts before we close this show

601
00:28:38.040 --> 00:28:40.680
though?
>> You know if we boil this whole show

602
00:28:40.680 --> 00:28:44.230
down, we really talked about
those first two phases which

603
00:28:44.230 --> 00:28:46.080
are mostly hidden from us, right?

604
00:28:46.080 --> 00:28:48.850
We see black screens when
the stuff is going on, so

605
00:28:48.850 --> 00:28:52.400
the troubleshooting tools that we used, if
we wanted to really summarize this down,

606
00:28:52.400 --> 00:28:54.960
is the hardware diagnostic but holding D.

607
00:28:54.960 --> 00:28:59.730
And then there's booting to recovery and
using disk utility to run disk checks and

608
00:28:59.730 --> 00:29:01.380
replacing hard drives as necessary.

609
00:29:01.380 --> 00:29:04.540
But I also did mention restoring
from Time Machine is another option,

610
00:29:04.540 --> 00:29:06.450
instead of reinstalling Mac OS
you could do a restore.

611
00:29:06.450 --> 00:29:08.623
That would replace all
of your files as well,

612
00:29:08.623 --> 00:29:11.455
reinstalling Mac OS just
replaces the system files.

613
00:29:11.455 --> 00:29:15.955
So either approach works but
all of them leave your data intact so

614
00:29:15.955 --> 00:29:18.055
that's usually a good thing.
>> All right, well, Don,

615
00:29:18.055 --> 00:29:18.700
thanks for dropping by.

616
00:29:18.700 --> 00:29:21.775
Looking forward to seeing you in the part
two of this here little series we

617
00:29:21.775 --> 00:29:22.665
got going on.

618
00:29:22.665 --> 00:29:25.425
But thank you good folks out there for
watching us as well.

619
00:29:25.425 --> 00:29:27.085
We are going to go ahead and
call it a day though.

620
00:29:27.085 --> 00:29:30.065
Signing off ITPro TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie

621
00:29:30.065 --> 00:29:30.725
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

622
00:29:30.725 --> 00:29:31.438
>> And we'll see you next time.

623
00:29:31.438 --> 00:29:38.862
[MUSIC]

624
00:29:38.862 --> 00:29:41.620
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don takes on the task of troubleshooting issues with macOS High Sierra if/when they arise. He explores the troubleshooting process starting with the boot process through to the loading of the operating system, login, and logout. He also covers system recovery options and some "hidden" system shortcuts and diagnostics.
episodes.title: System Troubleshooting Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.034 --> 00:00:06.464
Welcome to ITPro.TV [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.464 --> 00:00:08.337
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.337 --> 00:00:12.652
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.
>> All right,

4
00:00:12.652 --> 00:00:16.420
greetings everyone and welcome back
to another episode of ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:16.420 --> 00:00:19.640
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and
today's episode, we're continuing on,

6
00:00:19.640 --> 00:00:20.980
with our ACSP series.

7
00:00:20.980 --> 00:00:24.550
Specifically, today we're looking at
part 2 on system troubleshooting.

8
00:00:24.550 --> 00:00:25.960
Joining us back in the studio yet

9
00:00:25.960 --> 00:00:28.990
again the man the myth the legend,
you know him as Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:28.990 --> 00:00:31.220
Don, good to have you in again,
how's it going today?

11
00:00:31.220 --> 00:00:32.300
>> Glad to be back, and

12
00:00:32.300 --> 00:00:38.750
we're gonna continue our three
hour of the Mac OS boot process,

13
00:00:38.750 --> 00:00:42.610
We've been talking about how we can
troubleshoot our system when it fires up.

14
00:00:42.610 --> 00:00:45.920
And maybe it doesn't quite get into
the operating system like we expect.

15
00:00:45.920 --> 00:00:47.980
There's a lot of things that can go wrong,
so

16
00:00:47.980 --> 00:00:51.820
we're just kinda looking at all of them
and seeing what tools are available.And

17
00:00:51.820 --> 00:00:56.380
what's the right tool to match the right
symptom when we find a Mac that just won't

18
00:00:56.380 --> 00:00:59.020
boot up and won't get us in.
>> Well, Don, in the previous episode,

19
00:00:59.020 --> 00:01:02.900
you mentioned the five phases that we
go through when we start up our system.

20
00:01:02.900 --> 00:01:04.440
I think it would be a good idea for

21
00:01:04.440 --> 00:01:09.510
you to remind us what those phases are.
>> It's kind of like the phases of grief,

22
00:01:09.510 --> 00:01:10.168
right?

23
00:01:10.168 --> 00:01:11.801
[LAUGH]
>> Denial.

24
00:01:11.801 --> 00:01:15.250
[LAUGH]
>> My Mac won't move what?

25
00:01:15.250 --> 00:01:17.842
My data's gone.

26
00:01:17.842 --> 00:01:19.010
The five phases though.

27
00:01:19.010 --> 00:01:20.030
They're pretty straight forward, right?

28
00:01:20.030 --> 00:01:22.770
We've got the firmware which is
what's built into the motherboard.

29
00:01:22.770 --> 00:01:23.560
You press the power button.

30
00:01:23.560 --> 00:01:24.680
It does something.

31
00:01:24.680 --> 00:01:28.120
Then we go to the booter, and the booter's
job is to find the operating system.

32
00:01:28.120 --> 00:01:31.510
And we were pretty exhaustive in the last
episode, looking at those two phases, and

33
00:01:31.510 --> 00:01:32.400
what happens from there.

34
00:01:32.400 --> 00:01:36.860
The next phase, though,
that we didn't get to, is the kernel.

35
00:01:36.860 --> 00:01:40.860
The booter finds the operating system,
and it runs the kernel.

36
00:01:40.860 --> 00:01:44.630
What actually starts that operating
system up, it's the very first thing.

37
00:01:44.630 --> 00:01:47.110
So it's really,
really important From there,

38
00:01:47.110 --> 00:01:50.060
the kernel fires up
a service called launch D.

39
00:01:50.060 --> 00:01:54.390
And launch D fires up all the other
services that make up Mac OS.

40
00:01:54.390 --> 00:01:57.990
And once that's done,
it then turns over to the log in window.

41
00:01:57.990 --> 00:02:02.630
And that's where we, as the end user,
can log into the Mac and begin to use it.

42
00:02:02.630 --> 00:02:05.690
All five of those phases have to
complete successfully in order for

43
00:02:05.690 --> 00:02:07.800
us to get into our Mac and
start to use it.

44
00:02:07.800 --> 00:02:11.760
If something goes wrong, it will have
happened in one of those phases.

45
00:02:11.760 --> 00:02:14.630
And we can use various tools to
be able to look in and try and

46
00:02:14.630 --> 00:02:16.850
find where that failure is.
>> Well Don, like you said,

47
00:02:16.850 --> 00:02:19.240
we had left off on the third phase.

48
00:02:19.240 --> 00:02:20.850
My favorite Fix, right.

49
00:02:20.850 --> 00:02:23.070
Which was the kernel if I'm not mistaken.

50
00:02:23.070 --> 00:02:25.170
So let's go ahead and jump back in and

51
00:02:25.170 --> 00:02:28.040
tell us about the kernel.
>> All right, now the kernel

52
00:02:28.040 --> 00:02:32.200
I said in the last episode that it was the
heart and soul of your operating system.

53
00:02:32.200 --> 00:02:33.150
Well what do I mean by that?

54
00:02:34.350 --> 00:02:38.830
Your operating system,
deep deep down, is one program.

55
00:02:38.830 --> 00:02:41.050
There's one program that starts it all,
right?

56
00:02:41.050 --> 00:02:44.869
But that program is super
anti-user friendly.

57
00:02:44.869 --> 00:02:45.450
>> [LAUGH]

58
00:02:45.450 --> 00:02:47.060
>> That program is not expecting to talk

59
00:02:47.060 --> 00:02:47.730
to people.

60
00:02:47.730 --> 00:02:49.940
It's expecting to talk to other programs.

61
00:02:49.940 --> 00:02:55.020
It is the gateway in between software and
hardware.

62
00:02:55.020 --> 00:02:59.060
It's what's facilitating who gets
to the CPU, who gets to the memory,

63
00:02:59.060 --> 00:03:00.770
who gets to the network card.

64
00:03:00.770 --> 00:03:04.310
And if you don't pass through the kernel,
it gets angry.

65
00:03:04.310 --> 00:03:08.480
And there's only specialized things,
like sometimes video graphics rendering,

66
00:03:08.480 --> 00:03:11.320
can go to a discrete graphics card and
bypass the system.

67
00:03:11.320 --> 00:03:14.140
But even that it's still touched
at least lightly by the kernel.

68
00:03:14.140 --> 00:03:16.720
The kernel is involved in everything.

69
00:03:17.730 --> 00:03:20.290
Now, I said that it's the heart
of the operating system,

70
00:03:20.290 --> 00:03:22.890
it isn't the operating system.

71
00:03:22.890 --> 00:03:26.180
An operating system is
a user interface and

72
00:03:26.180 --> 00:03:29.190
a collection of tools
combined with a kernel.

73
00:03:29.190 --> 00:03:34.570
So in the Linux world we talk about the
Linux kernel, well nobody installs Linux.

74
00:03:34.570 --> 00:03:39.440
They install Ubuntu or Debian or
Redhat and it runs the Linux kernel.

75
00:03:39.440 --> 00:03:43.790
Well, in Mac Os, we install Mac Os,
that's the operating system.

76
00:03:43.790 --> 00:03:46.850
The kernel is actually called Darwin,
kernel's a different name.

77
00:03:46.850 --> 00:03:51.410
I know I've said earlier that
while we have this nice GUI and

78
00:03:51.410 --> 00:03:53.540
everything's all user friendly,
it's Mac OS.

79
00:03:53.540 --> 00:03:57.260
Under the hood,
we're actually running BSD Unix.

80
00:03:57.260 --> 00:04:00.620
Well it's the kernel that's
running BSD Unix and

81
00:04:00.620 --> 00:04:02.710
we can interface with that
through our terminal.

82
00:04:02.710 --> 00:04:05.940
But everything else we're doing
through this GUI which is Mac OS.

83
00:04:05.940 --> 00:04:09.110
So we don't really have to deal with
that Unix side of things, right?

84
00:04:09.110 --> 00:04:11.580
In fact, it's largely invisible to us.

85
00:04:11.580 --> 00:04:13.278
For example, let me show you.

86
00:04:13.278 --> 00:04:18.697
If I go into my GUI here and
I pull up my about this Mac window.

87
00:04:18.697 --> 00:04:19.700
Which is gonna be a little tiny here.

88
00:04:19.700 --> 00:04:21.983
Let me zoom in on that.

89
00:04:21.983 --> 00:04:27.962
When we look at about this Mac, it tells
me, I'm running macOS High Sierra 10.13.3.

90
00:04:27.962 --> 00:04:31.470
Doesn't say, hey, you're running BSD Unix.
>> It does not, I've noticed that.

91
00:04:31.470 --> 00:04:32.560
>> Doesn't say Darwin,

92
00:04:32.560 --> 00:04:33.640
doesn't say any of that.

93
00:04:33.640 --> 00:04:35.410
If you fish around on the system report,

94
00:04:35.410 --> 00:04:37.870
you can start to find if this
information is in there.
