it may have third-party software that's
created some Startup Items in there.

554
00:27:21.160 --> 00:27:23.650
So if you're trying to disable and
if you've booted the recovery and

555
00:27:23.650 --> 00:27:24.980
you're trying to dig
something out of there and

556
00:27:24.980 --> 00:27:27.890
delete file,
check those directories as well.

557
00:27:27.890 --> 00:27:30.226
They do hang about.
>> All right, well Don,

558
00:27:30.226 --> 00:27:33.671
I know we didn't get to the fifth stage,
or phase as we like to call it, but

559
00:27:33.671 --> 00:27:35.393
I know we can just make another show,

560
00:27:35.393 --> 00:27:37.262
so that's what we're gonna do.
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

561
00:27:37.262 --> 00:27:41.008
[LAUGH] So thanks for dropping by,
anything you wanna leave us with before we

562
00:27:41.008 --> 00:27:42.741
call this one a show?
>> All right, so

563
00:27:42.741 --> 00:27:44.820
we do have one more phase,
the login window.

564
00:27:44.820 --> 00:27:47.410
We'll talk about it, it sounds boring,
but there's actually a good bit to it.

565
00:27:47.410 --> 00:27:50.880
So we'll get a chance to get it, and then
there's a handful of other troubleshooting

566
00:27:50.880 --> 00:27:53.810
tools that I wanna show you guys that
aren't necessarily tied to a particular

567
00:27:53.810 --> 00:27:56.320
phase, but are pretty darn handy.

568
00:27:56.320 --> 00:28:00.510
So in the next episode we'll cover phase
five, and I'll throw in those other tools,

569
00:28:00.510 --> 00:28:03.210
so definitely tune in for that one.
>> All right, well Don, thanks again for

570
00:28:03.210 --> 00:28:03.810
joining us.

571
00:28:03.810 --> 00:28:05.644
And thank you good folks out there for
watching.

572
00:28:05.644 --> 00:28:09.350
But as we've said it's time for us to
call it a day, signing off for ITProTV,

573
00:28:09.350 --> 00:28:11.930
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.
>> I'm Don Pezet.

574
00:28:11.930 --> 00:28:14.138
>> And we'll see you next time.

575
00:28:14.138 --> 00:28:20.786
[MUSIC]

576
00:28:20.786 --> 00:28:22.909
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don takes on the task of troubleshooting issues with macOS High Sierra if/when they arise. He explores the troubleshooting process starting with the boot process through to the loading of the operating system, login, and logout. He also covers system recovery options and some "hidden" system shortcuts and diagnostics.
episodes.title: System Troubleshooting Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.004 --> 00:00:05.202
Welcome ITPro.TV

2
00:00:05.202 --> 00:00:09.136
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're

3
00:00:09.136 --> 00:00:13.586
watching ITPro.TV.
>> All right, good night, everyone,

4
00:00:13.586 --> 00:00:16.249
and welcome back to another
great episode of ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:16.249 --> 00:00:18.087
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

6
00:00:18.087 --> 00:00:21.566
in today episode we continue on
with more in our ECSB series.

7
00:00:21.566 --> 00:00:24.482
Joining us yet again for
a part three and system troubleshooting,

8
00:00:24.482 --> 00:00:25.960
I know, the fun never ends.

9
00:00:25.960 --> 00:00:27.410
Our good friend Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:27.410 --> 00:00:29.360
Don, we're glad to have you yet
again, how's it going today?

11
00:00:29.360 --> 00:00:30.320
>> Thanks for having me back,

12
00:00:30.320 --> 00:00:33.195
Daniel, and my chance to redeem myself-
>> [LAUGH]

13
00:00:33.195 --> 00:00:34.386
>> Our troubleshooting

14
00:00:34.386 --> 00:00:35.443
in the boot process.

15
00:00:35.443 --> 00:00:40.094
In the first couple of episodes [LAUGH]
we've been covering the five phases of

16
00:00:40.094 --> 00:00:43.146
the boot process,
we talked about the firmware,

17
00:00:43.146 --> 00:00:45.414
the booter, the kernel, launch D.

18
00:00:45.414 --> 00:00:48.606
And now we're ready to talk about
the log in window which sounds like

19
00:00:48.606 --> 00:00:52.500
one of the more boring ones, but
is actually pretty darned important.

20
00:00:52.500 --> 00:00:55.524
So we're gonna get a chance to see
how it works and what it does and

21
00:00:55.524 --> 00:00:58.829
then I had a few other troubleshooting
tools that I wanna highlight and

22
00:00:58.829 --> 00:01:02.371
show because they're pretty handy and
they span across all of the phases.

23
00:01:02.371 --> 00:01:04.236
So we'll do that here in
this episode as well.

24
00:01:04.236 --> 00:01:05.316
>> Well, that's funny, Don,

25
00:01:05.316 --> 00:01:07.575
you started talking about the fifth phase,
the login phase.

26
00:01:07.575 --> 00:01:10.417
I'm thinking, I forgot my password and

27
00:01:10.417 --> 00:01:12.350
that's the only thing.
>> Yeah.

28
00:01:12.350 --> 00:01:13.652
>> But I'm sure there's more to it than

29
00:01:13.652 --> 00:01:16.518
that, so without further ado I'll kick it
back to you and you tell us what's up.

30
00:01:16.518 --> 00:01:17.479
>> All right, so

31
00:01:17.479 --> 00:01:20.443
the login window is pretty darn important,

32
00:01:20.443 --> 00:01:25.530
because if you can't get to the login
window, you can't run, right?

33
00:01:25.530 --> 00:01:29.490
But this one is actually
a lot easier to break,

34
00:01:29.490 --> 00:01:32.730
because it's built around
the idea of permissions, right?

35
00:01:32.730 --> 00:01:35.300
When I fire up a computer, so
if I take a look at my Mac here,

36
00:01:35.300 --> 00:01:38.460
I'm at the login screen and it's just
sitting here asking me for a password.

37
00:01:38.460 --> 00:01:43.330
Now technically there's two different
login screens that happen in MacOS.

38
00:01:43.330 --> 00:01:48.560
If you have File Vault turned on,
you see a File Vault log in screen and

39
00:01:48.560 --> 00:01:52.330
you provide it credentials which are used
to unlock your encrypted hard drive.

40
00:01:52.330 --> 00:01:55.430
And by the time it gets to the regular
log in window, which is this one,

41
00:01:56.600 --> 00:02:00.040
it's already got your credentials,
so it passes you right through.

42
00:02:00.040 --> 00:02:02.650
You don't even see this log in window,
but it does run,

43
00:02:02.650 --> 00:02:04.530
it is in the background, right?

44
00:02:04.530 --> 00:02:08.650
If you have File Vault turned off,
you power on, you see the Apple logo, and

45
00:02:08.650 --> 00:02:11.860
then you're brought to this login window
and it does ask for a password, cuz it

46
00:02:11.860 --> 00:02:16.020
doesn't have your credentials unless you
enabled auto-login and stored them, right?

47
00:02:16.020 --> 00:02:18.404
So it's just sitting here waiting.

48
00:02:18.404 --> 00:02:21.320
When this login window runs,
it's a program.

49
00:02:21.320 --> 00:02:23.244
It's a program that's
running on your system.

50
00:02:23.244 --> 00:02:27.180
And it's running with root privileges.

51
00:02:27.180 --> 00:02:27.820
In other words,

52
00:02:27.820 --> 00:02:32.410
it's running at the highest elevated
privileges possible on the system.

53
00:02:32.410 --> 00:02:35.130
So this window,
it could do a lot of damage.

54
00:02:35.130 --> 00:02:38.320
Well, there's only so
much we can do from here.

55
00:02:38.320 --> 00:02:40.650
I can type in my password to log in.

56
00:02:40.650 --> 00:02:42.838
If I had more than one user,
I could hit the back arrow and

57
00:02:42.838 --> 00:02:44.293
change to a different user account.

58
00:02:44.293 --> 00:02:46.702
I can shutdown, restart,
or go to sleep and

59
00:02:46.702 --> 00:02:51.110
that's pretty much the extent of
the damage that I can do from this screen.

60
00:02:51.110 --> 00:02:53.707
So it's pretty safe for
this to run as root.

61
00:02:53.707 --> 00:02:57.550
The reason it runs as root is that
I'm gonna provide it credentials.

62
00:02:57.550 --> 00:03:00.020
I'm gonna type in my password.

63
00:03:00.020 --> 00:03:05.990
And when I do that, the log-in window
is going to switch its identity.

64
00:03:05.990 --> 00:03:06.750
And it's gonna say,

65
00:03:06.750 --> 00:03:11.500
I'm not running as root anymore,
now I'm running as Don Pezet, right?

66
00:03:11.500 --> 00:03:16.470
The moment I press Enter,
log-in window changes its identity and

67
00:03:16.470 --> 00:03:18.170
now it's Don Pezet.

68
00:03:18.170 --> 00:03:24.750
And now any program that I run
Is gonna be run as Don Pezet.

69
00:03:24.750 --> 00:03:28.540
The window manager is now
being powered by that, okay?

70
00:03:28.540 --> 00:03:32.440
And when I login,
the login window is now running as me.

71
00:03:32.440 --> 00:03:34.810
And it looks at my profile and it says,

72
00:03:34.810 --> 00:03:38.900
okay, what programs did you
have open in your last session?

73
00:03:38.900 --> 00:03:40.250
A let me reopen them.

74
00:03:40.250 --> 00:03:41.666
Here, Google Chrome came on.
>> It's very nice,

75
00:03:41.666 --> 00:03:45.371
actually, I love this feature.
>> It is, especially if you have a power

76
00:03:45.371 --> 00:03:47.995
out, everything just pops
back the way you want it.

77
00:03:47.995 --> 00:03:50.250
It can be problematic too, though, right?

78
00:03:50.250 --> 00:03:54.140
Let's say there's something
wrong with Google Chrome, and

79
00:03:54.140 --> 00:03:57.020
every time I log in,
it auto launches Google Chrome and

80
00:03:57.020 --> 00:03:59.029
my computer reboots.
>> Fun.

81
00:03:59.029 --> 00:04:00.512
[LAUGH]
>> And then, I log in again and

82
00:04:00.512 --> 00:04:02.520
it launches Chrome and it reboots, right?

83
00:04:02.520 --> 00:04:05.510
I've had this happen, not with Chrome,
but with other programs.

84
00:04:05.510 --> 00:04:10.091
Sometimes, the nice, convenient, features
can be the cause of all your problems.

85
00:04:10.091 --> 00:04:10.603
>> [LAUGH]

86
00:04:10.603 --> 00:04:12.850
>> That's certainly just happened.

87
00:04:12.850 --> 00:04:15.110
Well, it's the log in window
that's doing this, right?

88
00:04:15.110 --> 00:04:19.690
The log in window, it collected your
user identity, your credentials.

89
00:04:19.690 --> 00:04:20.770
It's a token-based system.

90
00:04:20.770 --> 00:04:22.182
So, it's got your user token.

91
00:04:22.182 --> 00:04:26.040
And now it's attaching it
to every program I run.

92
00:04:26.040 --> 00:04:29.917
So if I pull up the Activity Monitor,
and my spotlight's working now,

93
00:04:29.917 --> 00:04:31.349
cuz I'm out of safe boot.

94
00:04:31.349 --> 00:04:33.533
If you watch part two you'll know
I was frustrated about that.

95
00:04:33.533 --> 00:04:37.107
But if I pull up the Activity Monitor and
I come in here and

96
00:04:37.107 --> 00:04:40.225
start to look at the programs
that I'm running,

97
00:04:40.225 --> 00:04:44.502
I can see here in the beginning
things like launchd and the kernel.

98
00:04:44.502 --> 00:04:46.189
See how they run as root?

99
00:04:46.189 --> 00:04:47.641
They run as the root user.

100
00:04:47.641 --> 00:04:49.161
Those are system services.

101
00:04:49.161 --> 00:04:51.154
We need them to run as root.

102
00:04:51.154 --> 00:04:55.450
But if I start following the PID numbers,
and I go down.

103
00:04:55.450 --> 00:05:00.960
They increase as each program runs,
until I get to the loginwindow.

104
00:05:00.960 --> 00:05:02.750
And here's the login window.

105
00:05:02.750 --> 00:05:04.080
Process ID 96.

106
00:05:04.080 --> 00:05:07.590
And see how it says it's
being run by D Pezet.

107
00:05:07.590 --> 00:05:09.310
That's because I just logged in.

108
00:05:09.310 --> 00:05:14.510
It was being run as root until I
logged in and now it switched.

109
00:05:14.510 --> 00:05:16.210
And now it's being run as me.

110
00:05:16.210 --> 00:05:18.880
If I had fast user switching enabled,
and I had more than one account,

111
00:05:18.880 --> 00:05:20.850
I would actually see two login windows.

112
00:05:20.850 --> 00:05:25.993
One that's still being run by root, run by
root, because someone else could log into

113
00:05:25.993 --> 00:05:31.151
the system, and then one that's being run
by me, because I'm currently logged in.

114
00:05:31.151 --> 00:05:36.140
So you might have multiple login windows
depending on how your system is set up,

115
00:05:36.140 --> 00:05:37.489
but that one is mine.

116
00:05:37.489 --> 00:05:40.560
This is my login window, there are many
like it, but this one is mine.

117
00:05:40.560 --> 00:05:42.015
>> This one is mine, that's right.

118
00:05:42.015 --> 00:05:46.560
[LAUGH] So now whenever I run a program,
which I have to move the higher process

119
00:05:46.560 --> 00:05:51.020
IDs, because most of the others
are things that came up when we booted.

120
00:05:51.020 --> 00:05:54.810
And so now when I look down here I start
to see things like the Activity Monitor

121
00:05:54.810 --> 00:05:57.150
which is running as me.

122
00:05:57.150 --> 00:05:59.810
I should be able to find the Terminal,
it's right there.

123
00:05:59.810 --> 00:06:03.850
Google Chrome should be in here somewhere,
did I close it by accident?

124
00:06:03.850 --> 00:06:05.440
I might've closed it by accident.

125
00:06:05.440 --> 00:06:09.190
Spotlight, right, these are all
things that are being run as me, and

126
00:06:09.190 --> 00:06:11.010
the login window is what's managing that.

127
00:06:11.010 --> 00:06:16.680
Now if every time I log in, Google Chrome,
there it is, Google Chrome is crashing,

128
00:06:16.680 --> 00:06:21.160
but it's set to auto start,
then I've got a real problem, right?

129
00:06:21.160 --> 00:06:23.770
And this is a far more common issue than

130
00:06:23.770 --> 00:06:26.540
any of the other troubleshooting
scenarios we've let out so far.

131
00:06:26.540 --> 00:06:29.840
And it is very unlikely
to be a hardware problem.

132
00:06:29.840 --> 00:06:32.200
This is a software problem, right?

133
00:06:32.200 --> 00:06:37.180
So fortunately we've got an easy
way to be able to stop those types

134
00:06:37.180 --> 00:06:40.584
of things from firing up automatically.
>> You buy a new Mac, right?

135
00:06:40.584 --> 00:06:41.103
>> You could.

136
00:06:41.103 --> 00:06:41.639
>> [LAUGH]

137
00:06:41.639 --> 00:06:42.532
>> You could buy a new Mac,

138
00:06:42.532 --> 00:06:43.370
that would do it.

139
00:06:43.370 --> 00:06:45.300
Although if you restore
a Time Machine backup and

140
00:06:45.300 --> 00:06:46.800
the program's still auto launching,

141
00:06:46.800 --> 00:06:48.660
you're right back where you started.
>> That's true.

142
00:06:48.660 --> 00:06:50.736
>> So you've gotta plan accordingly.

143
00:06:50.736 --> 00:06:54.220
But we can set up these
a few different ways, right?

144
00:06:54.220 --> 00:07:00.661
The easiest way is to do what's called a,
well, this gets a little confusing,

145
00:07:00.661 --> 00:07:05.280
because we saw safe boot
in the last episode, right?

146
00:07:05.280 --> 00:07:09.400
Safe boot was where I told the computer,
when it boots up, don't load third party

147
00:07:09.400 --> 00:07:16.660
kernel extensions and don't load
third-party launch team and services.

148
00:07:16.660 --> 00:07:20.380
So just kinda trying to keep
it really small and narrow.

149
00:07:20.380 --> 00:07:24.790
That doesn't apply to user applications,
right?

150
00:07:24.790 --> 00:07:27.150
Our user applications
are controlled in two places.

151
00:07:27.150 --> 00:07:32.640
If I go into my system preferences,
one place is in the user account window.

152
00:07:32.640 --> 00:07:38.550
So if I come into my Users & Groups and
I find my user account in here.

153
00:07:38.550 --> 00:07:41.980
So there's Don Pezet and
I have Login Items right here.

154
00:07:41.980 --> 00:07:45.720
These things, there I can see
Google Chrome and Resilio Sync,

155
00:07:45.720 --> 00:07:50.760
ITunesHelper, Moon, all these different
programs I run when I log in.

156
00:07:50.760 --> 00:07:53.313
If I can log in, I can always
come in here and remove items.

157
00:07:53.313 --> 00:07:56.981
I don't want Chrome to launch when
I log in, so I can pick Chrome,

158
00:07:56.981 --> 00:07:59.274
I can hit that minus, I can knock it out.

159
00:07:59.274 --> 00:08:00.214
Don't hit Hide.

160
00:08:00.214 --> 00:08:01.320
That just hides it from the menu bar.

161
00:08:01.320 --> 00:08:02.306
It doesn't do you any good.

162
00:08:02.306 --> 00:08:07.020
You hit the minus to actually remove it
from the list in order to take that out.

163
00:08:07.020 --> 00:08:09.740
If I can't even log in,
I can't get to this tool.

164
00:08:09.740 --> 00:08:10.625
That doesn't help me.

165
00:08:10.625 --> 00:08:14.405
If you had terminal access, or
if you can log in as another user,

166
00:08:14.405 --> 00:08:16.160
you might be able to fix this.

167
00:08:16.160 --> 00:08:20.110
Now, if I log in as another user, you
actually don't see the log in IM screen

168
00:08:20.110 --> 00:08:23.900
for other users, even if you're
an administrator, if you're unlocked and

169
00:08:23.900 --> 00:08:26.540
everything you don't see
other users log in IMs.

170
00:08:26.540 --> 00:08:30.010
But you could go into the terminal and
find it.

171
00:08:30.010 --> 00:08:32.680
These guys are hidden away usually
in what are called launch agents.

172
00:08:32.680 --> 00:08:35.970
I say usually cuz they're
not always a launch agent.

173
00:08:35.970 --> 00:08:37.900
In fact, here, let's see if these show up.

174
00:08:37.900 --> 00:08:40.580
I know that Chrome was set to auto-launch,
right?

175
00:08:40.580 --> 00:08:41.957
So is that a launch agent?

176
00:08:41.957 --> 00:08:43.210
Well, we'll find out.

177
00:08:43.210 --> 00:08:48.606
I can browse on the hard drive and I can
go into /Library/, let's see it'll be,

178
00:08:48.606 --> 00:08:52.482
actually I need to look at the user
cuz it's a per user basis.

179
00:08:52.482 --> 00:08:56.134
So, remember that there's
more than one library,

180
00:08:56.134 --> 00:09:01.446
there's four domains, we saw that way
back in the beginning of the series,

181
00:09:01.446 --> 00:09:06.011
the user library is stored in
the users home folder, so if I go into

182
00:09:06.011 --> 00:09:11.990
/users/deposit/Library/LaunchAgents, that
folder right there.

183
00:09:11.990 --> 00:09:17.600
Launch agents are programs that start when
you boot up, all right or when you log in.

184
00:09:17.600 --> 00:09:22.133
And so that's what I'm seeing right here
is there's something from google.com.

185
00:09:22.133 --> 00:09:24.730
Keystone, maybe that's keystone agent?

186
00:09:24.730 --> 00:09:28.110
I don't know what that is, but it's some
kind of launch agent that Google has.

187
00:09:28.110 --> 00:09:31.930
Which, it may be what's launching Chrome
or this may be some other Google service.

188
00:09:31.930 --> 00:09:35.147
But I'm gonna assume it's Chrome,
cuz I don't see anything else running, but

189
00:09:35.147 --> 00:09:36.054
it's a launch agent.

190
00:09:36.054 --> 00:09:38.760
There were other items in my
startup though, like Moom, right?

191
00:09:38.760 --> 00:09:42.771
Moom is my little windows resizing utility
that I installed from the App Store.

192
00:09:42.771 --> 00:09:44.590
It's not showing up here
on the launch agents.

193
00:09:45.660 --> 00:09:48.260
And so, it's launching some other way.

194
00:09:48.260 --> 00:09:51.840
When you go into that settings screen,
and you go into your users groups and

195
00:09:51.840 --> 00:09:55.280
you pull up your logging items,
you see everything there, right?

196
00:09:55.280 --> 00:09:57.970
Here, it's not a guarantee
that you're going to spot it.

197
00:09:57.970 --> 00:10:00.330
And it might not be in this library.

198
00:10:00.330 --> 00:10:02.110
It could be in one of the other libraries.

199
00:10:02.110 --> 00:10:03.790
It could be a global one,
